directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: If you are keen on coffee cocktails, then Coffee With Gianni will definitely hit the spot. The thing that makes grapefruit taste sour is also the thing that helps to stretch your caffeine high, so if you’re a little tired, it’s time to mix up some Grapefruit Vodka, Cold Brew Coffee and a little Simple Syrup.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass. Squeeze the zest over the drink to make the most of the aromatic oils

description: Toby Maloney at The Violet Hour in Chicago wanted to pay an homage to the Last Word, but by adding the egg white and the absinthe, as well as making the Chartreuse flaming, the effect is one of Neptune’s fury in a stormy sea.

directions.instructions: Shake the first five ingredients in an ice-filled shaker. Strain back into the shaker, then dry shake before fine straining into a chilled glass. Pour Chartreuse into a long-handled metal measuring cup, ignite, then carefully pour flaming Chartreuse into the drink.

description: Created by Roison Garcia and his team at Ocean Prime restaurant in New York, the Prime Margarita is a bright and balanced Margarita riff that is nothing short of a flavourful fiesta!

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker tin, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: The Black Ships were the name given to the naval vessels commanded by Commodore Matthew Perry, whose arrival, in 1853, forced an end to Japanese isolation. It is also the name of our Japanese Whisky Cocktail that also includes Pomegranate Juice, Port & a little Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake, and strain into a chilled Martini glass.

description: The perfect after-dinner digestif, the Port Of Spain has a sizable amount of Angostura Bitters. It is, therefore, no surprise that this drink has been named after the capital of Trinidad, which is, of course, also the home of the brand.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: The Saigon Cooler is the perfect cocktail if you are after a fruity and well-balanced drink. Incorporating Raspberries, Gin, Chambord, Cranberry Juice and a little Lime Juice, this is a drink that is all about refreshment.

directions.instructions: Muddle Raspberries in the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients and shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass./
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created at Bam-Bou in London

description: Well, it’s about time that we presented a medicinal solution. And at least with this drink every ingredient (except the sugar) has been used medicinally at some time (and if Mary Poppins is to be believed, it’s sugar that makes the medicine go down). So grab Genever, Green Chartreuse, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup, Angostura Bitters & top with Tonic Water for a cocktail that is definitely A1.

directions.instructions: Shake first five ingredients in an ice-filled shaker tin and strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Tonic and lightly stir.

description: If you’re looking for a drink to get the party started, then why not give your guests a Strawberry Zing? Mixing Strawberry & Lime Flävar, Vodka, Watermelon Liqueur, Lime Juice and a little Simple Syrup this refreshing aperitif is the perfect drink for the festive season.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: Originally created by Sean Cadger at The Outhouse in Edinburgh, the Bakewell Tart Sour has all the jammy, almond-y tastes you would expect with a mix of Cognac, Amaretto, the syrup from Maraschino Cherries, Bitters and Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain over a large block of ice in a chilled glass

description: Adapted from a recipe created by Matthias Lataille in 2016 in London, the Carré Nouveau is reminiscent of a Vieux Carré but with Lillet Blanc replacing the Sweet Vermouth and Gentian replacing the Angostura Bitters

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: The Red Hook cocktail is a modern classic that comes to us from bartender Enzo Errico, formerly of NYC’s Milk & Honey. With Rye, Punt e Mes & Maraschino Liqueur, this drink is, of course, another Manhattan riff with a Brooklyn theme.

directions.instructions: Stir ingredients with ice in a mixing glass until well chilled. Strain into a cocktail glass.

description: If you are a Coconut fan, then there’s no better way to express your love than with a Coconut Margarita. Both the Coconut Milk and the Coconut Water add a true tropical nature to this summer libation.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients together and strain into a glass filled with ice.  with a lime wedge
directions.garnish: Shredded Coconut for the rim and a Lime wheel

description: Crisp, bright and summery, the Mid-Summer Cocktail truly lives up to its name. With Vodka as the base, the Fino Sherry adds a little nuttiness, while the Yellow Chartreuse add sweet, mellow, herbal notes

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Created for Perle Skirvin Mesta, the US ambassador to Luxembourg, the Black Russian was devised by bartender Gustave Tops at the Metropolitan Hotel in Brussels in 1949. A simple mix of Vodka and Coffee Liqueur, this classic is deep and rich, while also being the older brother of the White Russian.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into an Old Fashioned glass

description: As the name suggests, the Lunes Aperitivo should perhaps have been the first Aperitivo of our week. Either way, the Tequila, Americano Bianco and the Suze combine to create a drink that sits nicely on the dry side of bittersweet.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

ingredients: 3.38 oz. Rocket Fuel (Orange + Grenadilla Juice + Citric Acid)
description: Citrusy and bright, The Rocket cocktail is a rum-based highball that truly shines. With both white and spiced Rum and an orchestra of Citrus & Grenadilla Juice (Passionfruit), this is a drink that will send your taste buds into the stratosphere.

directions.instructions: Build the first six ingredients in an ice-filled glass, then top with Soda Water

description: Created by Sylvian Solignac at Citrus, London, the Eden is a wonderful long Tonic cocktail made for summer days. With Vodka, St Germain, Apple Juice and topped with Tonic Water.

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Tonic Water

ingredients: 0.5 oz. John D. Taylor’s Velvet falernum
description: If you are looking for an unconventional, modern tiki drink, then Brother Hal might be the drink for you. The Rum is, of course, the star, but the Mezcal mixes seamlessly with the Orange and Lime Juices, while the Falernum and the Green Chartreuse bring added complexity.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a Tiki glass over fresh crushed ice

description: Inspired by a Pina Colada, the flavours of Jalapina are all about the Blanco Tequila. The drink adds a bit of spice to compliment the creamy notes and the toasted coconut playing against the caramel and banana of the agave spirit.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain over cubed ice into a chilled glass

description: Created by French bartender Nico de Soto, the Pandan-quiri offers a Southeast Asian twist on the classic Daiquiri. The cocktail offers the grassy, slightly bitter taste of Pandan Syrup to sweeten the drink before adding the usual Rum and Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe.

description: The name Blushing Monk, of course, refers to the inclusion of Benedictine in this aromatic bittersweet sour. Added to that is Aperol, Lillet for a little brightness, Suze to offset the sweetness, and Lime Juice to add a bit of zing.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with. ice and then strain back into the shaker. Dry shake and fine strain into a cocktail glass.
directions.garnish: A line of Angostura Bitters. across the middle of the foam
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Sam Finch at The Milk Thistle in Bristol (UK)

description:
Strong yet well-balanced and herbaceous, Quill is a riff on a Negroni that is definitely not one to be left in the wings. With the usual suspects of Gin, Campari and Sweet Vermouth, this drink adds a rinse of Absinthe for an Anise and Woodworm undertone.
“With Negroni Week in full swing, Vanessa knew she had to get back to the city. Although Juan (her faithful PA) seemed to have gone to the birds under the careful tutorage of the forest ranger they had befriended, Vanessa knew that if she didn’t get a Campari in her hand quick-smart, even the sight of her in a negligee could not negate her neglect of the Negroni.”

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and fill it 3/4 with ice. Stir until chilled, about 20-30 seconds. Strain into a cocktail glass (or over ice in a rocks glass if you prefer)

description: As the name suggests, the Mexican Mule is simply a Moscow Mule variation that uses a nice Reposito Tequila as the base spirit instead of Vodka. So add the Tequila to Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup and Ginger Beer. It really isn’t more complicated than that but it is super tasty.

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients with ice, then fine strain into an ice-filled Collins glass. Top with Ginger Beer and stir

description: A twist on the classic Vieux Carré,  the Vieille Place is a balanced, yet spirit-forward, bittersweet aperitif. Created by Robbie Neskens at Bruut in Hassselt , Belgium, this drink incorporates Bourbon, Suze, Cognac, Dry Vermouth, Simple Syrup, a dash of Amaretto, aswell as both a dash of Peychard & Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Strain all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: Created at Atlas Singapore and inspired by the Place Vendôme outside of the Ritz in Paris, the Vendome Spritz incorporates citrus flavours and some sweetness for a drink that is crisp, bright and easy to sip

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a highball glass with ice

description: If you’re looking to add a bit more complexity to your next Old Fashioned, then don’t look any further than the Elderfashioned. The addition of St Germain not only compliments the whisky notes but also adds a certain ‘je ne sais quoi’ to the mix.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: With Dark Rum, Creme de Cacao, Sweet Vermouth, Lime Juice & Cinnamon Syrup, the Julie Paradise has been created by the New York bar Nobody Told Me. And while nobody has told us who Julie is, but we can certainly tell you that this is one drink that will definitely take you to paradise.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and double strain into a coupe glass

description: If you’re looking for a sophisticated after-dinner cocktail, then the French Connection is just as thrilling as its name-sake. With Cognac and Amaretti Liqueur, this is a drink you sip and savour slowly.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and pour into heated balloon glass

description: If you assumed this drink was named after the first pub of the ‘crawl’ from the 2013 film World’s End, then you’d be right. At that time, bartender Alastair Walker was at The Everleigh in Melbourne, where he mixed Gin, Suze, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup, a dash of Absinthe and it’s all topped with Soda Water to create the First Post.

directions.instructions: Shake the first five ingredients before straining into an ice-filled glass, then top with Soda Water

description: Light, refreshing and easily drinkable, the Miami Spritz is the perfect cocktail to have by the pool. With Vodka, Watermelon, Campari, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup, this is a drink has an effervescent lightness with a topping of Soda Water

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Originally created by John E. Haas, a bartender from Pennsylvania at the turn of the century, The Modern Cocktail was promoted by Charles, S. Mahoney in his 1905 book, The Hoffman House Bartender’s Guide (1905). With equal amounts of Blended Scotch and Sloe Gin, it also has Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and a dash each of Absinthe and Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description:
Created by Garrett Flanagan for New York’s Pebble Bar, Night Train is the perfect after-dinner drink. A Manhattan-Boulevardier hybrid, this drink combines two Amari that adds an extra layer of bitterness.
Recipe and cocktail image from @imbibe

directions.instructions: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. Stir to chill and strain into a chilled glass.

description: Pétanque may be a French game (similar to Boules) but the Amaretto in this drink is Italian and the Fino Sherry is Spanish. Go figure … To add a little more geographical confusion, the drink was created by an American, Andrew Bohrer from Mistral Kitchen in Seattle.

directions.instructions: Stir first three ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass.Then carefully float hold a teaspoon of Absinth on the surface of the drink.

description: Dry & aromatic, the French Canadian is a wonderful aperitif created by Dan Corum Fisher at Hawksmoor, London. With Cognac, Gin, Maple Syrup, Lemon Juice and Angostura Bitters, with muddled cucumber adding freshness.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients then shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: It’s typical that the week would end with one lousy goat … The Negroni & The Goat is a riff that comes from The Girl And The Goat Restaurant in Chicago back in 2014. It combines Gin, Aperol, Sweet Vermouth and Averna for a drink that’s far from gamey.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: If you ever thought that your Martini needed a little something extra, then the Obituary Cocktail is where you might find it. With the usual Gin and Dry Vermouth, this cocktail also adds a splash of Absinthe to the mix.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: The sweet notes of Bourbon are lifted and amplified by the almond flavours of Amaretto in this Old Fashioned riff. In addition to the Bourbon and Amaretto, the Almond Old Fashioned has Demerara Syrup and Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: If flavour is truly your jam, then you’ll love the taste of a Fig & Rye. With Autumnal tones, this Cocktail has Rye, Fig Jam, Lemon Juice & a little Sugar Syrup to warm you from the inside out.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. Shake vigorously and then double strain into a Couple glass

description: If you are looking for a late summer cocktail that reflects the colours as the seasons change , then Autumn In The Tropics is a good place to start. With Aperol, Rum, fruit juice and bitters, this is a tropical drink that crosses the seasons.

Designed to perfectly pair with cheese, the Pavoni cocktail was a winner in the finals of the Heering Cocktail Classics competition in 2018. Created by bartender Odd Strandbakken at Himkok in Oslo, Norway, the drink combines Cherry Heering with Fino Sherry, Maraschino Liqueur, Angostura di Amaro and Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.garnish: Orange Zest Twist (discarded) & Blue Cheese Stuffed Olive

description: Easy to make and even easier to drink, the Stone Fruit Sangria uses a selection of versatile stone fruits, such as peaches, nectarines, plums, and cherries, soaked in white wine, with the addition of Peach Liqueur to make this sweet yet refreshing Sangria.

directions.instructions: Cut the peaches, nectarines, and plums into ½-inch wedges, then add them to a pitcher or bowl with cherries, peach liqueur, and white wine. Stir to combine and refrigerate for 1 hour (or up to overnight). To serve, add ginger ale and ice.

ingredients: 3 barspoon Honey Syrup (3 honey to 1 water)
description: It may not have the healing properties of an antibiotic but the Penicillin Cocktail, with its soothing yet spicy flavors of Scotch, Honey, Lemon Juice and Ginger Liqueur, is a surefire cure for a chilly autumn night.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.more_on_this_drink: Adapted by Simon Difford  from the 2005 by Sam Ross at Milk & Honey, New York. The original calls for 0.75oz of Honey-Ginger Syrup instead of Ginger Liqueur & Honey

description: Served at GG Tokyo New York, The Tomodachi is a beautiful riff on a Margarita. As well as the usual Lime Juice, Agave Syrup and Tequila (in this case pea-flower infused), the drink also has the tart and subtle sweet Ume Plum Liqueur

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker and served over ice in a rocks glass
directions.garnish: Rim the glass with Furikake Seasoning

description: If a wine-like cocktail with strong hints of bitter orange is what your taste buds are crying out for, then the Sanctuary cocktail could be your sanctum. With Dubonnet, Amer Picon and Cointreau this is a. classic well worth the name.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: When the weather is sweltering, would you reach for a beer, some juice, or Tequila? What if you could have all three. The Gingo combines tequila, St Germain, Grapefruit Juice & Pale Ale into a cocktail that will cool you down in no time.

directions.ingredients: Shake tequila, elderflower, and grapefruit with ice. Strain over fresh ice. Top off with pale ale. Serve in a salt-rimmed glass.

description: An early champion of Mezcal, Phil Ward created a few modern classics with the spirit, among them, Division Bell. A riff on the Last Word, Ward swapped Mezcal for Gin and Aperol for Chartreuse.

The Gibson uses a pickled cocktail onion in place of the typical briny olive to add an umami undertone to the classic cocktail. With Gin, Dry Vermouth, and a Cocktail Onions as garnish, this is often thought to be the connoisseur’s Martini of choice.

directions.instructions: Add the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: If you are looking for a cocktail that is not only elegant but unmistakably timeless than a Dry Martini is the most obvious port-of-call. With Gin, Dry Vermouth (we like a six-to-one ratio) & Orange Bitters, this is one potation that always brings an air of sophistication.

directions.instructions: Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until very cold. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: One of the modern classics to emerge from Milk & Honey, the Star Daisy, is a bright citrus-based drink that mixes of Gin, Apple Brandy, Dry Curacao, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: A floral twist on the bitter classic, the Lanique Rose Negroni exchanges Vermouth for Lanique which gives this drink a delicate rosy finish while still packing a high-spirited punch

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in an ice-filled rocks glass, then stir

description: There is nothing more classic than a dry Martini and the Belvedere Martini fits that bill with vodka and just a hint of Vermouth. The trick is to ensure that there is enough ice in your stir and your martini glass is chilled.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir for 15/20 seconds to chill and dilute. Strain into a chilled martini glass

description: Have you ever thought that the one thing the classic Paloma cocktail is missing is a delicate bitter complexity? Well, thankfully the Monte Paloma with it’s Montenegro, Tequila, Grapefruit Juice and Lime Juice is here to solve that little problem.

directions.instruction: Stir first four ingredients in an ice-filled highball glass, then top with Soda Water

description: For a fun, easy, tropical drink that looks as good as it tastes, you can’t go past a Midori Splice. With Midori, Coconut Rum, Pineapple Juice and a head of Coconut Cream, this is one drink that combines the best flavours of summer.

directions.instructions: Add Midori & Coconut Rum to an ice-filled highball glass. Add Pineapple Juice and stir. Carefully pour Coconut Cream over the back of a bar spoon to add as a top layer.

description: Fernet Branca is almost a national drink in Argentina, so it’s not surprising that this bitter, spicy drink is named after the country’s best known first lady. With Fernet Branca, Sweet Vermouth, Ginger Liqueur, Lime Juice and Ginger Beer, the Eva Peron is definitely an attention-getter.

directions.instructions: Combine Fernet Branca, Sweet vermouth, Ginger Liqueur and Lime Juice in an ice-filled shaker and shake well. Strain to an ice-filled Collins glass and top with Ginger Beer.

description: There’s an old story about J Edgar Hoover (no, not that one) that recounts that the former-FBI Director spent so much time at the Stork Club in NY that they actually named a cocktail after him. That cocktail is the FBI Fizz, with Cherry Heering, Jamaican Rum, Bourbon & Soda Water. And yes, we think you’ll find it quite arresting.

directions.instructions: Fill a Cocktial Shaker with ice and then add in Cherry Liqueur, Bourbon Whiskey and Jamaica Rum. Shake, then strain into a Highball Glass and top with Soda Water

description: Like many hot coffee drinks, the Italian Coffee is defined by a single liqueur, in this case, Strega. When Strega is mixed with Coffee and whipped Cream, it creates a drink that makes an excellent after dinner indulgence.

directions.instructions: Pour Strega into an Irish Coffee glass, then fill with hot Coffee and top with Whipped Cream

description: Best described as being a little like a Ramos but without the cream, the Fabulous Fizz is bright and refreshing with Grapefruit Gin and Triple Sec but just a touch bitter with the addition of Campari

directions.instructions: Hard shake all ingredients (other than Soda Water), then add ice and shake again. Fine strain into a Collins glass and top with soda water

description: For a light and fizzy cocktail that’s slightly sweet, a little tangy, and totally delicious, you can’t go past Autumn In Paris. The Ginger Wine gives a little spice, while St Germain makes it truly refreshing and perfect for any time of year.

directions.instructions: Add the St Germain, Ginger, Luxardo, lemon juice, and ice cubes to a shaker. Shake well. Strain into an on the rocks glass and top with club soda.

description: Let’s be honest, no matter how cool the name is, this cocktail is just a Greyhound with a salt rim. Again, historically a Gin drink, where the salt was used to dial down the tart and bitter notes of the Grapefruit. For this Salty Dog recipe, we’ve used the more popular Vodka, but you can sub in Gin if you’d like.

directions.instructions: Wet the rim of a highball glass and dip it in coarse salt. Fill the glass with ice, then build the drink by adding Vodka (or Gin) and Grapefruit Juice before stirring gently to combine.

description: Although it may have a distinctly Gothic feel, the Gargoyle and Spire Cocktail has a wonderfully bitter but refreshing taste. Strega (Italian for the Witch) joins Gin, Orange Bitters and Champagne in what would have to be the perfect sipping drink to watch the creatures of the night.

directions.instructions: Combine the Gin, Strega, Simple Syrup & Bitters in a mixing glass. Add ice then stir and strain into a Highball glass and top off with Champagne or Sparkling Wine.

description: Simple, yet classic in nature, the Cathy Olé is a gin-based cocktail where the richness of the Vanilla Liqueur of Licor 43 is beautifully balanced by the bone-dry sherry and the Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Pour ingredients into a glass half-filled with ice and stir. Top with more ice before serving.

description: If you want to elevate and balance the flavours in a Tequila Negroni riff, then just add saline. With the San Diago bartender, Eric Gigers’ has created the Jalisco Stroll that uses the usual Blanco Tequila, Dry Vermouth & Campari mix in equal measure but added a few drops of concentrated saline to change the game completely.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a rocks glass over ice
directions.garnish: Saline solution: Combine 4 oz. of room-temperature water with 1 oz. of kosher salt and stir to dissolve.

description: The Strawberry Scotch Cocktail is a refreshing complex and delicious summer sipping drink. Light fruity strawberries mingle with peaty Scotch and tart lemon juice in a beverage that will just leave you happy.

directions.instructions: Muddle the strawberries and thyme springs in a cocktail shaker. Add ice, Scotch, Lemon Juice, and Vanilla Simple Syrup. Shake, then strain into a Collins glass and top with Soda Water.

description: Flavour forward Anejo Tequila is not the only star in The Allstar Cocktail. Accompanying it, it Allspice Dram, Italian Amaro and a dash of Chocolate Bitters for a drink that has not only spice but a good bit of depth.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients in a mixing glass; stir with ice until well chilled. Strain into a martini glass or coupe

description: Created in 1950 by Giovanni Raimondo at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome, this Negroni riff is a drier and more complex cocktail that swaps Campari for the slightly spicy Contratto Bitter and sweet vermouth for dry.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir and strain over ice into a chilled rocks glass.
directions.garnish: Express lemon twist over top and discard

description: Believed to have been created in the 1970s, the Tootsie Roll cocktail is a drink that’s sweet, rich, and chocolatey, with a hint of citrus and is, as you might assume from the name, inspired by the famous US candy.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled Martini glass
directions.garnish: Orange twist and a Tootsie Roll candy

description: Created by Simon Difford in 2008 at The Cabinet Room in London, Damn It Jimmy is a cocktail that is delicate yet very slightly sweet. The Sake, White Rum mixes with the faint salty taste of Fino Sherry and herbal Dry Vermouth complexity.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and then strain into a chilled glass.

description: Named after a house in Haut Bay, South Africa, which is haunted by the ghost of Elsa Cloete, who died of a broken heart. The liquid honours the lovers with a mix of Gin, Elderflower, Cucumber, Lemon & Hibiscus Juice, and Soda Water while being garnished with a stir of edible blue shimmer

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in an ice-filled rocks glass
directions.garnish: Stir with a small paintbrush with edible blue shimmer

description: As you might imagine this is a very fruity Margarita riff featuring watermelon. So throw a little Reposado Tequila in a shaker and add Lime Juice as you normally would but then add a little fresh watermelon and a nice amount of Watermelon Simple Syrup and you’ve got the one summer drink that you’ll be making on repeat.

directions.instructions: Cut watermelon slice into chunks and muddle at the base of a shaker, before adding all of the other ingredients. Shake with ice and then fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: The mother of all Brazilian cocktails, the Caipirinha is a simple, refreshing, 3-ingredient drink that mixes Cachaça, Lime wedges and sugar for the perfect drink to have on a summer afternoon with your amigos and familiar, no matter where in the world you are.

directions.instructions: Cut half a lime into wedges and put it in the base of a shaker. Add 3 bar spoons of sugar (or 0.5 oz Simple Syrup) and muddle until the sugar dissolves. Add ice to an Old Fashioned glass, pour in the limes and sugar, then add cachaça and gentle stir

description: Fusions, both in restaurants and in bars, can create some wonderful if not unexpected flavour combinations. Created in a restaurant that creates a fusion of Peruvian & Japanese, the Sake Tonic is a perfect blend of popular Sake and aromatic Elderflower for a fresh and fruity aperitif.

directions.instructions: Cut the Apricots into small slices and add them to a Collins Glass. Then add the Sake, Vodka and Elderflower Liqueur , followed by ice cubes and Elderflower Tonic water
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Marc Alvarez Safont for Pakta in Barcelona, Spain.

description: If you are looking to add a little richness to a classic Martini, the Olive-Oil Washed Martini achieves that by mixing Dry Vermouth with the creamy nature of Oil-Washed Vodka as a base and then adding Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir to chill and strain into a chilled glass.

description: If you like your drinks to have a definite caffeine flavour while remaining non-alcoholic, then Brew For Two is a winner. Mixing up non-alcoholic Tequila, Little Drippa and honey, this is a drink that will keep you coming back for more.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain over a large square ice cube in a rocks glass

description: If you are after a Daiquiri but not as you know it, then a Witches’ Daiquiri may be just the drink. Aniseed, Sweet Almond and a delicate spice subtly influence this riff on the original.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: If you thought that Jägermeister was just for shots, then the Kraken Meister will show you that it’s all grown up. Add the spice of The Kraken Rum with the herbal flavour of Jägermeister, add some lime for balance and top with coke.

directions.instructions: Fill an old fashioned glass with ice. Pour in Kraken, Jägermeister, and fresh lime juice, then top with coke.

description: Created at the (now defunct) Starlight Room in San Francisco, the Starlight Reverse Martini is the perfect drink for summer, but its Vermouth-forwardness might be a bit of a problem for Vermouth-shy Martini purists.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: There’s no need for grief or sorrow with Lindsey’s Lament with its potent mix of Bourbon, Becherovka and Maple Syrup. Created by the Midnight Cowboy in Austin, Texas, this is the perfect digestif on which to end the night.

directions.ingredients: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, stir and strain into a chilled glass.

description: If you are after a simple yet complex aperitif, then the beautifully balanced La Perla is well worth mixing up. It combines the slight saltiness of the Manzanilla sherry with the delicate fruit of Pear Liqueur and the mellow oak and vanilla flavours of Reposado Tequila.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled coupe
directions.more_about_this_drink: La Perla was created by Jacques Bezuidehout at Tres Agaves in San Francisco in 2005.

description: In case you’re curious, the name of this drink translates from the Spanish to mean “Old Fashioned”, so if you were guessing that this was a Tequila Old Fashioned, then you’re probably right. In fact, the Estilo Viejo, with Tequila, Agave & Angostura Bitters, it actually is.

directions.instructions: Stir half the Tequila with ice cubes. Add Agave Syrup and Angostura Bitters. Stir some more and add another two ice cubes and the rest of the Tequila. Stir more and add more ice, until you feel the dilution is correct.

description: Light, bright and effervescent, with just a little hint of tang, the Rhubarb Spritz is best drunk outdoors with friends. The mix of Rhubarb Gin and Prosecco is brought up a notch by the inclusion of Ginger Ale.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: Life would be so much simpler if every cocktail was as easy and flavoursome as the Redheaded Ginger. With Lillet Rouge, Ginger Beer and a dash of Grapefruit Bitters, this tasty aperitif is light, refreshing and perfect for a bit of day drinking.

directions.instructions: Add chilled Lillet Rouge to an ice-filled collins glass. Top with ginger beer and a dash of Grapefruit Bitters, then stir.

description: With fruity elements from muddled berries and apple juice, Courtside is a vodka-based cocktail perfect for balmy afternoons, as the name suggests, courtside. Elevated with Elderflower Liqueur and offering effervescence with a Soda Water top, this drink is a smash, no matter where you serve it.

directions.instructions: Muddle berries at the base of a shaker. Add all other ingredients (except Soda Water) and shake with ice. Fine strain into an ice-filled Collins glass, then top with Soda Water

description: While being a tasty little drop, La Coquette is a frisky little minx. With Cognac, Lillet Rose, Creme De Peach and Lemon Juice, she is certainly easy to drink but in typical French style can be difficult to forget.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and shake hard with ice. Strain into a cocktail glass.

description: Created by Jody Davids, When Adam Met Eve provides a misty journey through the ‘original’ botanical gardens. The drink plays with botanicals and citrus with highlighted herbaceous notes of juniper, rosemary and basil.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into an ice-filled clay “vase”
directions.garnish: Dry ice with a bouquet of basil and rosemary

description:
Created by Ricky Agustin, Smoke Follows Beauty tkes the muddled cucumber, cilantro and heat from the Poquito Picante cocktail and the lime juice and double agave (Mezcal & Agave Syrup) from the Spicy Margarita for a drink that is sure to be your next favourite.
“Although Vanessa personally loved Mezcal cocktails, the spirit had become so prolific that she felt that these were now the only drinks she created. The advantage, of course, was the she had the opportunity to drink quite a few (in the name of research) before deciding which ones to use as the basis of her new riffs.”

directions.instructions: In a shaker, muddle the cucumber and cilantro. Add the Mezcal, infused Triple Sec, Lime Juice, Agave Syrup, and ice, and shake until well-chilled. Double-strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
directions.serrano-infused_triple_sec: Chop and freeze 100 grams of serrano peppers overnight in an inert container. When ready to infuse, pour in 1 liter of triple sec and allow to steep at room temperature. Taste every 20 minutes or so, stopping when the heat is where you want it.

description: Created by Julia Momose at Kumiko in Chicago, The Grey Wolf is a Japanese Whisky riff on the classic Old Fashioned, with the inclusion of the savoury-sweet acidity of Plum Vinegar and the complex sweetness of Benedictine.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over an ice block chipped into a gumdrop shape.

description: Created by Rob Gourlay of Esquire Tavern in San Antonio, the Philly Smash combines muddled berries (Raspberries & Blackberries) with Sugar Syrup. Add to that, Rye Whiskey, Averna & lime Juice and this drink will produce maximum flavour for minimum effort.

directions.instructions: Muddle the berries and simple syrup in the bottom of an Old Fashioned glass. Add rye, Averna, and lime juice. Pack the glass with crushed ice or small ice cubes and stir.

description: Jim Kearns from Slowly Shirley in New York has created this Orgeat riff on a 19th-century classic. The Whiskey Daisy No.2 juxtaposes the subtle softness of the drinks original Bourbon with the addition of the bright spice of Rye Whiskey.

directions.instructions: Shake the ingredients with ice to chill, then strain into a chilled coupe.

description: At the end of a long day, there is nothing better than kicking back with a little fresh citrus and sweet bourbon that are both made more complex and earthy with the bitter-sweet addition of Averna. Combine that mix with egg white for a creamy, delightfully foamy finish of an Averna Sour.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a shaker tin and dry shake. Add ice to the shaker, then strain into a rocks glass with ice.

description: While you might think the Cosmo Rita is an expected mashup of a Cosmopolitan and a Margarita, you shouldn’t discount it as a gimmick. The Tequila’s earthy nature stands up more strongly than the neutrality of Vodka, and the changed ratios mean the Cranberry Juice is more pronounced.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: Sitting somewhere between a Mimosa and Moscow mule, the Morning Mule can be enjoyed at any time of the day. Mixing Vodka, Orange Juice & Ginger Beer this is the ultimate easy, brunch-style drink.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: A riff on the Manhattan, the Bensonhurst was created by Chad Solomon at Milk & Honey in New York in 2016 and named after a neighbourhood close to his home in Brooklyn. With Rye, Maraschino, Dry Vermouth & Cynar, this is a riff you’ll grow to love.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass and stir. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora.

description: If you want an example of the sweetness of the Kumquat rind adding that extra dimention to a cocktail then try this St Germain & Kumquat Cocktail. With Gin, St Germain, Kumquats, Sugar Syrup and Soda Water, this is a low ABV and low sugar drink with a beautiful citrusy edge.

directions.instructions: In the base of a shaker, muddle together the Sugar Syrup and the Kumquats. Add ice, then Gin and St Germain and shake. Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass, then top with Soda water

description:
A delightful riff on a Margarita, Cóctel Al Pastor (which means “shepherd style” in Spanish) is adapted using spices and herbs to create a cocktail that is balenced but with a little bit of a bite.
“Vanessa strongly believed that the best bar in the world always has to be the one you’re sitting in right now. But that belief, of course, did not create award shows … so she, like so many, had come to Singapore to see the offical results. While the event itself was always fun, Vanessa found the best part of flying 9,526 miles was catching up on gossip.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a glass rimmed with tortilla salt

description: Who doesn’t love a Spritz in the summer and Everything Is Coming Up Rosé is the perfect pitcher cocktail (we have written this with pitcher measurements – if you want to make it by the glass, then divide by four).  Combining Rosé with the pleasantly bitter Aperol and delicate, floral Hibiscus Tea, this is one cocktail you’ll have on stand-by all summer long.

directions.instructions: In a pitcher or punch bowl, combine the Rosé, Lillet, Tea, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and Aperol. Fill the pitcher with ice and stir well. Stir in the club soda and serve in chilled wineglasses.
directions.garnish: Grapefruit wheels, lemon wheels and sliced strawberries or even edible flowers
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Natasha David, co-owner of Nitecap, NYC

description: If you’re trying to decide how to use your gin in Spring, one of the most delightful choices is a Bees Knees riff like the Easy Beesy. With Gin, Lemon and Honey Ginger Syrup, this is wonderfully beesy and truly easy and made memorable with the scent of Rosemary.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double strain into a chilled glass

description: A riff on a Tom Collins, the Grand Collins playfully swaps out Old Tom Gin for Grand Marnier, creating an intriguing, layered flavour profile to match its lively effervescence.

directions.instructions: Place ice cubes in a highball glass and add Grand Marnier®, and then fresh lemon juice. Top up with soda water and stir.

description: As you will probably assume, this is a nice twist on the classic Manhattan. The Manhattan Island highlights Cognac as the main base spirit and adds to that Rosso Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur & Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Probably the most famous of the Last Word riffs, the Last Ward was created by Phil Ward at Death & Co New York in 2007. Replace the gin from the original with Rye and the Lime Juice with Lemon Juice and add that to the usual Green Chartreuse and Maraschino Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: The key to a good Bourbon Blackberry Smash is the muddling of the Lime wedges, Blackberries and mint leaves. And it’s only once all the oils and juices have been released that it’s time to add the Bourbon, Sugar Syrup and a good topping of Soda Water

directions.instructions: In a shaker tin, combine mint leaves, lime wedges and blackberries and muddle. Add bourbon, ice, and simple syrup and shake. Pour full contents into a rocks glass (no straining) and top with 1 ounce of club soda.

ingredients: 0.125 oz. Marachino Cherry Juice (from the jar)
description: Very much doing what it says on the box, the Cherry Bold Sour, is filled out with a touch of the flavour of Maraschino Cherry Juice. Otherwise, it’s basically a Vermouth Sour with the added benefit of lemon juice and egg white.

directions.instruction: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake and then fine strain into a small chilled Rocks glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: This drink has been adapted from the original recipe created by Mark Ward, the owner of Regal Rogue Vermouth

description: Moonshine, also known as White Whiskey, takes the place of Bourbon in this fruity Julep. Mixing Strawberries, with the crisp flavour of Moonshine, Lemon Juice and Mint is the perfect way to ease into the weekend.

directions.instructions: Combine cut strawberries, sugar, mint leaves in a cocktail shaker. Stir and let stand until strawberries are macerated, up to 10 minutes. Add moonshine, lemon juice, and ice to fill the shaker, and shake vigorously for an additional minute. Pour out contents into an ice filled glass.

description: What do rabbits drink when they are just kicking back and relaxing over the Easter long weekend, well, a Carrotini, of course. They hop to it with a mix of Ginger Vodka, Carrot “C” speciality spirit and a muddling of Mint, Lemon peel and cucumber slices.

directions.instructions:
Combine lemon peel, mint, and cucumber in a cocktail shaker and muddle well. Add vodka, C, and ice, then shake and strain into a chilled martini glass
Garnish with carrot twist and serve

description: A close relative of the Moscow Mule, the Palma Fizz is a classic Vodka Cocktail inspired by the principal city of Ibiza. Rose Water and the spicy taste of Ginger combine to create a drink as intoxicating as the islands themselves.

directions.instructions: Add first four ingredients to an ice-filled Highball glass. Stir well and top with Ginger Beer

description: Nothing brightens up the middle of the week better than an Elderflower Martini. Based on a standard 50/50 Martini recipe of Gin and Dry Vermouth, with the addition of the citrus and herb notes of St Germain & Lime.

directions.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker halfway with ice cubes. Pour in all ingredients and shake until very cold.

description: Created by H. Joseph Ehrmann of San Fransisco’s Elixir Saloon, the Peppermelon Cocktail combines sweet watermelon, smooth gin, and spicy black pepper honey syrup for a drink with an intriguing twist.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.garnish: Black Pepper Honey Syrup – combine 1/2oz water and 1/2oz honey and black pepper to taste and mix thoughly.

description: A bit earthy and a little bit spicy, Rabarbaro (which is basically a dried Rhurbard Amaro) is a perfect edition for a Margarita riff. Similar in flavour to the Tequila itself, the Rabarbaro balances the Jalapeño in this variation while mixing beautifully with the expected Reposado Tequila, Lime. Juice and Agave Syrup.

directions.instructions: In the bottom of a shaker (without ice) muddle 3 x quarter-inch (half-cm) slices of Jalapeño. Add ice and the rest of the ingredients, then shake and double strain into a rocks glass.

description: This is one of those cocktails that feels like a modern classic, the Ginger Rogers is of course named after the famous Hollywood actress. Created by Marcovaldo Dionysos, the drink mixes Gin, Lemon and both Ginger Syrup and Ginger Ale with a whole mass of Mint.

directions.instructions: Muddle the mint in a glass, then pour in the remaining ingredients, add ice and stir

description: Ideal for summers spent around the pool, this riff on the Tiki tropical classic is what refreshment is all about. Wonderfully Spritz-ified, this version of a Mai Tai pares down the Rum content in lieu of a Prosecco topper.

directions.instructions: Combine the Lime Juice, Orgeat, Curaçao, and Rum in a small container and refrigerate for an hour or two. Pour the chilled mixture into a Collins glass, fill to the rim with ice, top with Champagne.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Martin Cate, Smuggler’s Cove, San Francisco

description: There is something rather special about a herbal, bittersweet tequila-based cocktail that gets you every time. With Tequila, single malt Scotch, Agave Syrup, Angostura Bitters and of course Amer Picon, Something Familiar is different enough to stand out yet familiar enough to indeed feel reassuring.

directions.instructions: Stir malt with ice, then strain, leaving the ice and mixing glass coated. Add other ingredients and stir and then strain into ice-filled glass

description: First seen on the bar at Dutch Kills in New York, the Mezcaletti is strong, nutty, buttery and (as the name suggests) made with a combination of Mezcal and Amaro Meletti, built in the glass over ice.

directions.instructions: Put a large ice cube in a chilled glass then add all ingredients and stir.

description: There is nothing nicer than a little Honey and spice and no-where better to get this flavour than in the Honeysucker Cocktail. Combining Kraken Spiced Rum with the Honey Syrup and a little Lemon Juice, this cocktail will leave you wanting more.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and add ice and shake. Fine strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: Created at the Oxo Tower Bar in London in the early 2000s, this is a citrus-forward cocktail that is more floral than tart. This drink has Vodka, Apricot Brandy & Lemon Juice, but it is the delicate flavour of the Rose Syrup that truly shines through.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: It’s commonly been said that the only thing better than a Negroni is a Coffee Negroni. And considering the drink is an equal part mix of Coffee Liqueur, Campari & Gin, we’ve got to agree.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: If you are after a drink that is short and evil then Ted Kilgore’s the Devil’s Soul may just be the drink for which you are looking. Combining everything that really shouldn’t be in a glass together, including Rye, Mezcal, Avena, Aperol & St Germain this drink has a smokey, boozy, bitter complexity that will delight.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass and stir till chilled. Stir into a cocktail glass

description: While the Unnamed Go-To may sound as if it was thrown together as a bit of an afterthought, once you taste the combination of  Cocchi Americano, Fino Sherry and Prosecco, it will truly become one Spritz you’ll never forget.

directions.instructions: Assemble all ingredients in a Highball glass over ice
directions.garnish: Peel of an Orange, Lemon & Lime
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created by Greg Best in Atlanta

description: A perfect after-dinner cocktail, the Orange Brûlée combines the sweet almond flavour of Amaretto with the wonderful bitter Orange flavour of Grand Marnier. This is then topped with cream and chocolate powder, which gives this drink the look of a traditional Crème Brûlée.

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients with ice and then stained into chilled glass. Float thin layer of cream on the top of the drink and turn glass to spread evenly.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Xavier Laigle at Bar le Forum in Paris.

description: Not too keen on Christmas pudding? Then make this festive season all about the flavours of a Banoffee Pie with the dessert cocktail, the Banoffee Martini. With Salted Caramel Schnapps, rich Banana Rum, Vanilla Syrup, a little chocolate bitters and some lush cream, this drink will fulfil all your Christmas dreams

directions.ingredients: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled collins glass

description: If you are after a divine flavor experience, then the Kumquat-Ginger Caipirinha should definitely be on your list of drinks to make this week. This drink is a simple variation of the popular Brazilian Caipirinha cocktail, in which fresh kumquats and ginger add to the flavour of the sugar and Cachaça.

directions.instructions: In an old-fashioned glass, muddle Kumquats, Ginger, and Sugar. Fill the glass with ice, then add the Cachaça and stir well.

description: If you’ve ever mucked up a cocktail then the Negroni Sbagliato is here to show you that mistakes can still be delicious. Sbagliato, in Italian, means “mistaken”, which is what the original bartender was when he used Prosecco rather than the traditional Gin, with the Campari and Dry Vermouth.

Traditionally, after a hard day on the range, cowboys wanted good water but a little bit spiked. In this riff, Seedlip Ranch Water, we come close with all the traditional Ranch Water flavours, but due to the Notas de Agave, no spike at all.

directions.instructions: Fill a glass with ice. Add Seedlip Notas de Agave and ¼ oz. of fresh lime juice. Top with Mineral Water.

description: As you would assume from the name, the Passion Play cocktail utilises the exquisite summer flavour of passionfruit. Playing off this is a wonderful mix of Don Julio Rosado, Lime Juice and a little Honey

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a rocks glass over ice.
directions.garnish: Grapefruit Chili Salt Rim and Grapefruit Peel

description: Created by American bartender Jefferey Morgenthaler in 2009, the Caneflower Cocktail is a riff on the Comte de Sureau cocktail created by German bartender Gonçalo de Souza Monteiro. This drink mixes Cachaça, Aperol & St Germain for a beautiful sipping cocktail.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass and stir. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

description: The Knickerbocker is a classic cocktail from the mid-1880s, the name is derived from the nickname of the city’s Dutch settlers who wore their pants—knickers—rolled up just below the knee. With Rum, Raspberry Syrup, Dry Orange Curacao & Lime Juice, this drink provides perfect sweetness.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice.

description: Created by Ryan Fitzgerald at ABV in San Francisco, High Altitude gets its name from the Mountain origins of both the Hakushu Japanese Whiskey and the Génépy des Alpes. It is a nice riff on a Japanese Highball.

directions.instructions: Combine Japanese Whiskey and Génépy in Collins glass, the top with Soda Water

description: Named after the Scottish poet, Robert Burns, the Bobby Burns Cocktail had a wonderful mix of Scotch, Vermouth & Benedictine. A riff on the Rob Roy (which is, itself, a riff on a Manhattan), this cocktail is set apart by the addition of herbal Bénédictine, which turns it into a wonderfully full-bodied digestif-style drink.

directions.instructions: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir, and strain into a cocktail glass. Twist a lemon peel over the glass to release its oils

description: A fun, flirty twist on a classic Margarita recipe, this Ruby Grapefruit Margarita is amazingly refreshing and perfect for any party! The addition of the Ruby Grapefruit, not only amps up the colour up also the flavour of this Tequila classic.

directions.instructions: Rim a rocks glass with salt. Combine all ingredients in a shaker, then strain into the ice filled glass.

description: Starting with a strong backbone of Cognac, the Seventh Son then adds a combination of the rich flavour of Cherry Heering and the more delicate flavour of Rose Syrup, then tops it off with Pilsner

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass. Then carefully pour the beer top float on top of the drink.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2015 by Richard Grimsey at Encore Brasserie in Londonderry.

description: There’s nothing more tempting on a summer evening than the luscious taste of strawberries, so we’re lucky that the Fragaria Martini has not only Strawberry Jam but also Strawberry Liqueur to help impart the juiciness.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: Sometimes, that Margarita just doesn’t have the citrus bitterness you crave, but if you make an Italicus Margarita and swap out the Triple Sec for Italicus, your craving is satisfied in the most Margarita way.

If you’re at a bit of a loss as to what to drink tonight after dinner but you have Bourbon, Sweet Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur and Cynar at hand, then why not make the boozy but subtly bitter and earthy Five Keys.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled glass

description: If you’ve ever wondered if you could have cocktails for breakfast, then a Breakfast Martini should answer that question with a resounding ‘yes!” A fun mix of Marmalade, Gin, Cointreau & Lemon Juice, this is the ideal drink to have while you contemplate your day.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker. Shake and then double strain into a chilled Martini glass.
directions.more_on_this_drink: Created in 2000 at the Library Bar at the Lanesborough Hotel in London, by Salvatore Calabrese.

description: This long and refreshing Raspberry and Champagne cocktail was created in 2014 for Laurent-Perrier by Sean ware of the London Cocktail Club. A variation of Dick Bradsell’s Russian Spring Punch, it mixes Vodka, Chambord, Raspberries, Lemon Juice and Champagne.

directions.instructions: Muddle the raspberries in the base of a shaker before adding Vodka, Chambord and Lemon Juice. Shake with ice, then strain to an ice-filled glass. Top with Champagne.

description: If you are after a bright, citrus-forward Daiquari then a Derby Daiquiri really should be your first choice. Created at the Mai-Kai in Fort Lauderdale, the addition of Orange Juice to the tradition Daiquari base will delight.

directions.instructions: Combine rum, juices, and syrup in an ice-filled shaker; shake. Strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: The Derby Daiquari was invented in 1959 to be the official drink of the Florida Derby horse race.

description: If green beer and Guiness aren’t you’re jam, then a Boozy Iced Coffee with Irish Cream Liqueur is a cocktail that will definitely scratch that Irish itch and provides a perfect sweet, coffee and creamy dessert-style drink.

directions.instructions: Pour the iced coffee/cold brew coffee into a tall glass filled with ice. Add the Irish Cream liqueur and chocolate liqueur to the coffee, then Add the milk/half and half/cream to the coffee

description: A riff on a Paloma, the Montenegro Paloma is made all the better with a touch of one of the lightest Amari. Montenegro plays especially well with the Reposado Tequila to create a sweeter take on this quintessential warm-weather tequila drink.

directions.instructions: Shake the first four ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass, then top with Soda Water

description: Trust a Platinum Blond to be complex, with the floral nature of St Germain taming the tart, zesty, citrus of both Grapefruit Juice and Grapefruit Vodka. Added to that, there is an herbal twist from the Rosemary and much-needed balance from the simple syrup and Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Muddle Rosemary in the base of a shaker. Add the other ingredients, shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Adam Gamboa at Il Posto in Denver

description: Created by chef Jimmy Bradley, from The Harrison in New York, the Canale Torino is the perfect three-ingredient cocktail. This refreshing aperitif is a mixture of Aperol, Dry Vermouth, and Cointreau.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: A riff on Trader Vic’s original Honolulu cocktail, Honolulu #2 swaps out the Simple Syrup and dash of Grenadine for the brilliant colour and flavour of hibiscus syrup and Pomegranate Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Blend all ingredients with one cup of crushed ice and pour into a large cocktail glass

description: Just to reassure you that not all Midori Cocktails are green, we have the Midori Cranberry Lime. A simple little drink but perfect if you’ve had a long day, it mixes Midori, Cranberry Juice and a squeeze of Lime before you drop the wedge into the glass.

directions.instructions: Fill the glass with ice and pour in Midori and Cranberry Juice. Squeeze 1 wedge of lime and stir gently.

description:
Pear might not be the obvious choice for fall flavour, but Pear Brandy is very much a harbinger of the season. The foundation of the Pear Sour, the Brandy and Pear Juice gives a big pear flavour, while the lemon adds tartness and the simple syrup adds the right amount of sweetness.
“Since Juan (Vanessa’s faithful PA) went off to further explore the avian population of upstate New York with the ranger, Vanessa decided to play around with a few Fall cocktail ideas. As she measured out the lemon Juice she realised that while you can take the girl out of the bar, but you can’t so easily take the bar out of the girl.”

directions.instructions: Shaker all ingredients with ice and then strain into a coupe glass.

description: Ginger spice and all things nice are what you are going to find in the Black Spring. With a good mix of Rye, Byrrh, Nardini Amaro and Ginger Beer, this drink has a bittersweet, fruity Rye bread bite.

directions.instructions: Stir first three ingredients. with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Ginger beer and lightly stir.

description: Unlike what it’s name implies, the Sloe Savage Thorn is a drink that does more to dull the pain than cause it. A neat mix of Sloe Gin, Tequila, Lime Juice and Agave, this is what happens when you send the English south of the border.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled rocks glass.

ingredients: 0.5 oz. Clear Creek eight-year-old Apple Brandy
description: Created by Harrison Ginsberg while he was at The Dead Rabbit NYC, True Blue puts a different spin on an Irish Whiskey cocktail, by adding complexity through ingredients like Pedro Ximénez sherry and white miso cane syrup.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: A variation on a Dirty Martini, the Weenie Martini makes the most of s summer barbecue by adding a tomato infusion to the Dry Vermouth and a hot dog garnish to the Vodka, Pickle Brine and Celery Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all (but the oil) until chilled, then pour into a chilled coupe.
directions.garnish: Sesame oil + skewer with sliced tomato, cornichon, and hot dog wheel

description: In a desert area like South Africa’s Karoo, the water spirit, Mama Wata, has her own allure. In liquid form, her homage, The Karoo Beauty, mixes Tequila with White Creme de Cacao, Strawberry Syrup and a Chilli Tincture to bring a spicy, fruity, tart taste to your glass.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker. Fine strain into a coupe glass

ingredients: 30ml Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description: Perfect for brunch or a late afternoon soiree, the Summer Royale is made like all Royale’s, by building from the base (in this case Hickson Rd Summer Cup), and topping it with Champagne (or an acceptable sparkling wine) in the glass.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in a flute glass

description: A Bacardi Legacy winning Cocktail by Constantinos Kazelis from Lost & Found Drinkery in Nicosia, the Black In Black has all the makings of a modern classic. Inspired by a Cuba Libre, this drinks has White Rum, Averna Amaro, Simple Syrup, Lime Juice, Angostura Bitters & Tonic Water.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled glass and stir.

description: If you are after a Margarita with a bit more of a sweet floral yet tart profile, then the Blood Moon Margarita, with its use of Blood Orange Juice rather than Triple Sec and the inclusion of Agave Nectar is a good place to start.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: While you might think of Vodka as the spirit of choice in a Greyhound, the drink’s original spirit of choice in the Prohibition era was actually Gin. So we thought we’d put a vintage spin on this simple yet classic drink by mixing our Grapefruit Juice with Gin for the ultimate Grapefruit cocktail.

directions.instructions: Pour gin and Ruby

description: The Amaretto Sour has gotten a bit of a bad rep over the years, so Jeffrey Morgenthaler, the bar manager of Clyde Common in Portland embarked on a project to make a better version. He boosted the alcoholic strength by mixing in nearly a full ounce of overproof Bourbon, replaced the sour mix with real Lemon Juice and added an Egg White.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake without ice to integrate. Add ice and shake until chilled. Strain over fresh ice in an old-fashioned glass.

description: This wonderful Rose Syrup Cocktail was one of the winning Cocktails in the 2016 Bacardi Legacy Competition. Embracing White Rum, Lime Juice, Rose Syrup, Egg White & Angostura Bitters, it’s a little like a Rose flavoured Daiquiri, so what is not to love …

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and then strain back into the shaker. Dry Shake (without ice) and fine strain into a chilled glass.
directions.garnish: Dash of Angostura drawn through the foam
directions.more_about_this_cocktails: Indian Bacardi Legacy 2016 winning Cocktail created by Yogesh Kumar, Delhi Pavilion, ITC Sheraton, Delhi

description: In the same way, you can’t physically stop a runaway train; you can’t stop drinking this riff on a Ramos Fizz. Created at New York’s Calico, the Runaway Train combines Gin, Añejo Tequila, Aperol, Rose Combier, Grapefruit & Lime Juices and egg white.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker and pour into a chilled glass. Top with soda

description: A twist. on a classic whiskey sour, the Alexis’ Bordeaux Sour gets its colour and flavour from muddled Maraschino cherries and Lillet Rouge. Add to that Whiskey, Lemon Juice, Maple Syrup, Egg White and Orange Bitters and then this cocktail is bound to delight.

directions.instructions: Muddle lemon juice, maple syrup, and cherries in a cocktail shaker. Add Whiskey, Lillet Rouge, egg white, bitters, and ice, then. shake vigorously and strain into an old fashioned glass filled with ice. Top with Soda Water

description: If you’re after the taste of a Dark ‘N’ Stormy but with a bit of a twist, then a Kumquat-Ginger Smash is the drink you should be making tonight. With dark Rum, Kumquats, Kumquat-Ginger Syrup and Soda Water, this is a citrus and spice twist on the original.

directions.instructions: Place the syrup (including a few slices of kumquat) in the bottom of a rocks glass. Using a muddler or the back of a spoon, smash the kumquat until lightly pulped. Add the rum and ice. Stir gently. Top with Soda Water

description: With a mixture of Chinese Baijiu, Brazilian Cachaca and French St Germain, this one accord we can definitely get behind. Add to that a little Lime Juice, Honey Syrup and Orange Bitters and this is a light, fruity drink that will make you want to travel more often.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a cocktail tin with ice. Shake and fine strain into a coupe glass

description: If you love a Tom Collins than you’ll find this riff, the Juan Collins, a pure delight. With Tequila, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and topped with Soda Water, this cocktail adds a little Mexican spirit to the classic

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Soda Water.

description: If you are looking for a more Caribbean riff on a Mule Cocktail then why not take your taste buds on a trip and mix yourself up a Jamaican Mule. With Jamaican Rum, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & Ginger Beer, this is not only quick and easy but has a wonderful spicy Ginger taste.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled Collins glass and lightly stior

description: An exceptionally tasty cocktail (and one of our simple favourites), the Ginger Scotch is as the name describes a highball of Scotch Whisky that’s topped with Ginger Ale. Cool, refreshing, yet a little spicy, this is a winner at any time.

directions.instructions: Add both ingredients to an ice-filled highball glass

description: If you are after a boozy, berry bomb then you should really be making a Blackberry Tequila Smash. After gently muddling some Blackberries, add in Sugar Syrup, Grapefruit Juice and Tequila for a drink that combines the best of summer.

directions.instructions: Muddle blackberries and Sugar Syrup in the base of a shaker tine. Add Tequila and Grapefruit Juice and shake well. Pour into a rocks glass with crushed ice.

description: If you are after an elegant cocktail that is also devilishly sweet, then the Mezcal-based Aventura will surprise you. It mixes the smokiness of the Mezcal with the sweetness of seasonal berries and the lively flavours of St. Germain and Grand Marnier.

directions.instructions: Add the Sugar and citrus juices to a cocktail shaker and stir. Add Raspberries and muddle. Add ice and the remainder of the ingredients and shake. Fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by the guys at bevvy.co

description: Who doesn’t love a pun? And especially when it created with a bitter French apéritif made from the gentian root. But more than just the Suze Liqueur, Suze You, Sir, incorporates Tequila, the herbal complexity of Dry Vermouth and the sweetness of Agave.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Created by German blogger Matthias Friedlein (@mjm_augustine), the Two Trains is a fantastic liquorice-laced riff on the 20th Century cocktail. This is the perfect drink for train watching with Gin, Vermouth, Creme de Cacao, Lemon Juice, and Liquorice Syrup.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled glass

description:
“Singularly shaped by the elements, Mezcal’s aroma and character are a natural pairing with Earthen, which mixes marvellously with tangy fresh-squeezed pink grapefruit juice.” – Jim Meehan
Image – AJ Meeker

directions.ingredients: Measure all ingredients into a cocktail shaker, then add ice cubes. Shake and strain into a salt-rimmed Collins glass filled with ice cubes.

description: Hopefully we don’t actually need to be stain in battle for the valkyries to lead us to Valhalla Rising. But either way, it’s easy to believe that the combination of Ginger Syrup, Sherry, Pilsner and Aquavit are definitely flavours worthy of the gods.

directions.instructions: In an ice-filled cocktail shaker, combine the Spicy Ginger Syrup, Aquavit, Sherry and Lime Juice and shake well. Strain into a chilled, ice-filled highball glass, then stir in the Pilsner.

description: With the ingredients of the cocktail also making up the foam top, the Longest Sip, created by Nkosinathi Shabangu from Saint in Johannesburg, is a wonderfully complex drink with a robust mouthfeel. The aroma and spice of the Lavender Ricard Syrup blends seamlessly with the bitters that open up the flavours of the Cointreau and Cognac

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a Nick & Nora glass
directions.garnish: Add the same ingredients + cellulose into a second shaker and dry shake before pouring into a Soda Syphon to carbonate. Add the carbonated thick foam to the top of the uncarbonated drink.

description: If you’ve ever thought a Moscow Mule would be perfect, if only it had Grapefruit Vodka, then a Grapefruit Mule is the solution. Add to that the usual Lime Juice and Ginger Beer and you have a light, refreshing riff on the classic.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled glass and stir

description: A nice little riff on the Negroni, the Amaroni has all the usual suspects (Gin & Sweet Vermouth) but swaps out the Campari for Amaro di Angostura for a drink that has rich, spicy, Cinnamon & Licorice notes that are distinctly Angostura.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass and stir. Strain over ice into an Old Fashioned glass.

description: We won’t go as far as to say it’s healthy but the Cascade has enough Raspberries in it that there must be some vitamin C and antioxidants floating around. Add to that Vodka, Cranberry Juice, Lemon Juice and Chambord for a drink that’s as good as it looks.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Like an almond cookie in drink form, a Disaronno Fizz is an impossibly fresh, zesty aperitif. Marrying the zing of lemon with the sweet almond of Amaretto, this drink comes to life with the addition of Soda Water.

directions.instructions: Add ice cubes to a large wine glass, then add Amaretto, a squeeze of Lemon Juice and then top with Soda Water

description: If you want a nice little riff on the Bramble, why not throw all your chips in and make yourself a Gamble cocktail. With Gin, Sloe Gin, Grapefruit Juice, Sugar Syrup & Cherry Heering, this is an easy to drink, gin-laced, fruity drink.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients and fine strain into a chilled glass with crushed ice

description: Created by Alex Richer at the Red Bar in London, you can think of the Green Beetle as Tequila and lemon aromatized by Absinthe. In other words, an absinthe wash gives body to Reposado Tequila, Agave Syrup and Limoncello.

directions.instructions: Pour Absinthe into a glass and top with water and leave to stand. In a shaker, add all ingredients with ice. Discard Absinthe from glass. Strain content of shaker into the Absinthe-coated glass.

description: An early variation on the classic Martini, the Turf cocktail has a multitude of variations. This one here is based on the 1922 Harry MacElhone’s version with Gin, Dry Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur & Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir well and strain into a chilled glass.

description: Created by Eryn Reece at Mayahuel in New York, this cocktail really is, as its name suggests, The Real Deal. This deep-flavoured nightcap combines  Mezcal, Punt e Mes, Sweet Vermouth and a touch of Fernet Branca.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir and then strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: This recipe is taken from Robert Simonson’s book Mezcal & Tequila Cocktails

description: The Montreal Cocktail is a wonderful Rye cocktail created by a collaboration of 15 Montreal bartenders. Intended to represent Montreal’s French (through the use of Suze) & English (through the use of Gin) influences, it also throws a little Italian (Aperol) in for good measure.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: While you might initially think the name of this cocktail, the Cuban Heal is a typo and we’re talking about shoes, it is in fact from the healing qualities of the ingredients that the name derives. With Rum (the Cuban part) and Cynar, Limoncello, Honey Syrup & Peychaud’s (the healing part), this drink is sweetly herbal.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Named after Dutchess County in New York State, the Dutchess owes part of its spelling to the addition of Genever, this Angostura heavy cocktail was created by Theo Lieberman of Lantern’s Keep and Milk and Honey in NYC.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: A little like an aged rum-based Espresso Martini, Out To Sea adds unexpected depth and character with the inclusion of Fernet Branca and Falernum for a drink that is ideal as an aperitif (and is far less salty than the name implies).

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and then fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created for Bacardi Legacy in 2017 by Allen Fang from Barules Cocktail Club in Shanghai

description: Take the Martini into a teeny-tiny cocktail with Tayēr + Elementary’s One Sip Martini. Using Vodka, Vermouth di Torrino and Fino Sherry, sometimes one sip is enough (especially if you have a few of them).

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a tiny martini glass

description: The 3G may sound a little antiquated as we enter a 5G world, but once you realise that those G’s stand for Gin, St Germain and Ginger Liqueur, then the light, crisp and refreshing taste of this drink seems completely appropriate.

directions.instructions: Coat a chilled Coupe glass with Absinthe, then discard Absinthe. Add the rest of the ingredients to an ice-filled shaker, then strain into the Absinthe-coated glass.

description: Taste Of Life was created by John Ng from MO Bar in Hong Kong and combines sweet, sour, salt and a little bitterness for a complex but refreshing drink inspired by the citrus-adorned streets of Hong Kong’s lunar new year celebration.

directions.instructions: Muddle the kumquats and sea salt together in a cocktail shaker. Fill shaker with ice and add Aperol, Pimm’s, orange liqueur, lemon juice, orange juice, and honey syrup. Shake thoroughly, and strain the mixture into an old-fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.

description: Sometimes you need a cocktail that will raise your spirits and what better name for that cocktail than the Gloom Lifter. It’s basically a Cognac and Irish Whiskey sour (with a little Grenadine Syrup), served straight up – and if that doesn’t get your spirits up, we don’t know what will.

directions.instructions: Dry shake all ingredients (without ice), then shake with ice, before fine straining into a chilled Coupe glass

description: Paying homage to the Swiss roots of the famously French liqueur Suze, the Swiss Account is a bittersweet aperitif with herbal notes. Created by Griffin Cox at Lot Six in Halifax, this drink mixes Vodka, Suze, Benedictine and Grapefruit Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled glass

description:
Created by bartender John Hall at the Australian bar, Justin Lane on the Gold Coast, comes the Australiano. A cheeky riff on the Americano, with Australian-made Vermouth, Amaro and a housemade native botanical Soda
Image by Declan Roache

directions.instructions: Add Vermouth and the Aperitivo to an ice-filled highball glass, then top with native botanical Soda

description: If you’re after a cocktail with a gentle pink blush and subtle taste of Rose then you can’t do better than an Indian Rose. With Gin, Apricot Brandy, Rose Water & Rose Syrup, this is a gentle but potent little drink.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Discovered by Simon Gifford at Mie N Yu in Washington DC in 2005.

description: What happens when Campari and Italian Vermouth meet the sand and sun of the Caribbean? Well, that would be a Kingston Negroni. Overproof Jamaican Rum stands up to the bombastic chocolate and bitter orange notes in the vermouth while drying out the Campari’s richness and tempering its bitterness.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients and stir with ice. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2009 by Joaquín Simó at New York’s Pouring Ribbons. He suggests the use of Smith & Cross overproof Jamaican rum.

description: Although offering savoury notes from the H by Hine Cognac, the Rosa di Roma is the perfect floral and light aperitivo that offers citrus notes from both the Bitter Bianco and dry Curaçao

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: Although you are swapping Bourbon for Pomegranate Juice, the Pomegranate Amaretto Sour is definitely a vibrant crowd-pleaser that attempts to make up for the lack of brown spirits with a dash of Bitters.
