directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and briefly dry shake before adding ice. Shake again and strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Nothing is better in the lead up to Burns Night than a good solid Scotch Cocktail and you can’t get better than a Return To Alcatraz. With blended Scotch, Grand Marnier, Lemon Juice, Orange & Vanilla Syrup & a touch of Ginger Liqueur this is a warming drink that will do your tartan proud.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in an Old Fashioned glass with ice and stir

description: A story as old as time, a Titan falls in love with a nymph, rebels against the gods and is subsequently turned into a jagged mountain at the southernmost tip of Africa. The Adamastor, as he was known, literally became Cape Peninsula, which in liquid form is represented by Gin, Dry Vermouth, Lychee Syrup, all top with a delicate Salted Aloe Air

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a coupe glass
directions.garnish: Top with Salted Aloe Air and an edible flower

description: If you are looking for a highball with a bit more of a luxurious taste, then the Grand Smash might be the right drink to have beside the courts this summer. Offering the complexity of Cognac as a base, it is given added depth with key notes of citrus and mint.

directions.instructions: Muddle lemons and mint in a shaker, then add Grand Marnier and ice. Shake, then pour into an ice-filled rock glass and top with soda water.

description: The only cocktail that we know to combine Whiskey, Port & Rum, the Suburban is a bit of an unusual Classic Cocktail. Originating in the 1930s, the combination of Bourbon, Tawny Port, Aged Rum, Orange Bitters and Angostura Bitters is definitely a riff on a Manhattan.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created at New York’s old Waldorf-Astoria Hotel (the site that the Empire State Building occupies today) for James R Keene, who’s steeds ran in the Suburban Handicap in Brooklyn.

description: If you’re looking to add a bit of colour to your Old Fashioned, then there is no better way to do it than by swapping out the sugar for Grenadine. As well as the obvious Grenadine, the Grenadine Old Fashioned mixes Wheated Bourbon and Angostura Bitters for a vibrant version of this old favourite.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass and stir. Stain into an Old Fashioned glass with a large ice cube

description: You’ve got to love a cocktail that looks crazy on paper but is actually half-decent in real life. The Blinker is a refreshing drink that incorporates Rye, Grapefruit Juice and Grenadine – see what we mean but don’t pass judgement until you give it a try.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients except the grapefruit twist in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe.

description: Created by Damon Boelte of Brooklyn’s Prime Meats, the Glasgow Mule is a mule variation that uses Scotch instead of Vodka. The result is a tart and spicy cocktail that retains the Ginger Beer from the original but adds Lemon Juice, Angostura Bitters and a little St Germain.

directions.instructions: Fill a Copper Mug or Collins Glass with ice, then add Scotch, Lime Juice, St Germain & Angostura. Top with Ginger Beer and stir with a bar spoon.

description: Created by the late Jim Meehan, The Nose To Cocktail incorporates bacon-infused Irish whiskey, dark maple syrup, and lemon and orange juices and, of course, a whole egg.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry shake, before adding ice and shaking again. Strain into a highball glass

description: In the drink, Bitter harbour, the lushness of Tawny Port finds a strong partner with smoke-laced Mezcal. These ingredients are then held together with the Gran Classico Bitter for a bittersweet cocktail that is not only ideal in a single-serve but is also wonderful when batched.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. Stir and strain into a Rocks glass.

description: It’s not often that you get a cocktail gets named after a horse but when Simon Difford Created this drink in 2015, Velvet Maker was the filly that won the horse-race he was listening to in Ireland. The drink itself is well balanced with a botanical complexity from the Vanilla-infused Vodka, zesty Grapefruit and Dry Vermouth.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: If you are after an easy alternative to a G&T, why not replace the Gin with the bitter complexity of Suze, for Le Petite Bouche (then simply add Rum, Orange Bitters  and, of course, Tonic Water). This dry and refreshing aperitif was created by Danny Wilson at Tabouche in Cambridge, UK.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: Referred to in the “Bar La Florida” recipe booklet of 1935, the Golden Glove is, as liquor.com points out, ‘like a Daiquiri-Margarita hybrid’ that combines familiar flavours into a drink that is strong, refreshing and citrusy.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a rocks glass over crushed ice

description: Made famous by NYC’s Waldorf Astoria Hotel, the Foghorn is a classic cocktail that utilises Gin, Ginger Beer (although Ginger Ale can be used), and Lime Juice (which is the one ingredient that differentiates it from a Gin Buck) for a refreshing drink that is classically made in an Old Fashioned glass but can also be made (as we have done) in a highball.

directions.instructions: Build the Gin and Lime Juice in an ice-filled Collins glass, then top with Ginger Ale

description: If you’ve spent time thinking that Bourbon would be even more amazing if only it had a clean mint finish, then grab your shaker, son, ’cause we’ve got a cocktail to make. The Dixie Dew is as fresh as the name implies, with Bourbon, White Creme de Menthe & Cointreau.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain ito a chilled Martini glass

description: With Lemon & Basil flavours shining through, the Black Basil Cocktail is perfect for summer sunset sipping. With Basil, Vodka, Limoncello, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and topped with a good dose of Tonic Water

directions.instructions: Muddle Basil leaves in the base of a shaker tin, add Vodka, Limoncello, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup, shake and strain into an ice-filled Highball glass. Top with Tonic Water and lightly stir.

description: Smoke & Mirrors does as the name implies and distracts you from its non-alcoholic nature with a satisfying amount of froth and creaminess. With Little Drippa, this drink will provide the solid cold extracted coffee hit you need.

directions.instructions: Shake Little Drippa, No-Alc Bourbon and Maple Syrup in an ice-filled cocktail shaker, then strain over a large square ice cube in a rocks glass. Slowly pour cream over the top.
directions.garnish: Rasher of crispy bacon (For a smokier flavour, add 1⁄4 teaspoon of liquid smoke into 1 cup of water and freeze to create smokey ice cubes).

description: It’s hard to not smile when a refreshing and fruity concotion like the Poker Face is put in front of you. With a solid base of Tequila, the nice brightness of Cointreau and a good dose of almost tropical Pineapple Juice, this drink is a cure for whatever ails you.

directions.instructions: Fill a highball glass most of the way with ice cubes. Pour in your three ingredients, and stir.

description: When the wind is up, there is nothing better than pulling out the Ginger Wine and making a cocktail like the Stone & Gravel. Popular in Jamaica, this drink combines White Rum & Green Ginger Wine for a simple, easy and surprisingly good little drink.

directions.instructions: Pour ingredients into a glass filled with ice and stir.

description: While this might look like the typical recipe for an Espresso Martini, this Belvedere version has shifted the proportions. This drink has a little more Coffee Liqueur than usual but less Vodka and less Simple Syrup (while the Espresso shot remains the same).

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to cocktail shaker and shake over cubed ice. Fine strain into chilled martini glass.

description: If you’re after something bitter and boozy, yet dangerously drinkable, then then the Sharpie Moustache might just be your cocktail. Easy to make with equal parts of Rye, Gin, Meletti Amaro & Sweet Vermouth, this spicy, herbal cocktail will definitely hit the spot.

directions.ingredients: In a mixing glass, combine the Rye, Gin, Amaro, Vermouth and bitters. Fill the glass with ice, stir well and strain into a chilled rocks glass. Pinch the orange twist over the drink and add to the glass.
directions.more_on_this_drink: Created by Seattle mixologist Chris Elford

description: If you’re going to do an after-dinner sipper then why wouldn’t you make a Parle-vous Irish Cocktail, where your Cognac is accompanied by Irish Whiskey that has been stirred in with rich orange and herbal liqueurs.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass
directions.garnish: Orange zest twist and freshly grated nutmeg

description: As you might assume from the name, this Tequila based drink is a riff on the classic Gimlet. As everyone knows Tequila and Lime are divine and the earthiness of this spirits certainly makes up for the loss of Gin’s botanicals.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created in 2017 By Simon Difford at the Cabinet Room in London

description: Created in 2014 by Márcio Silva, the Lavarello cocktail is a nice, boozy riff on the Rabo-de-Galo which swaps out the sweet vermouth for Cynar and then adds that to the Cachaça, Aperol & Chocolate Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a rock glass with a square block of ice.

description: One of the Soho House groups’ House Tonic cocktails, the eastern Standard is based on the Eastside Cocktail which is of course itself based on the classic Southside. With Gin, Lime Juice, Simple Syrup, Mint and Cucumber, this is a drink that is cool and refreshing with the right amount of zing.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker, then add all other ingredients. Shake with ice and fine strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.garnish: Cucumber ribbon around the inside of the glass

description: If you’re after a rich, somewhat indulgent cocktail at the end of the week than a Jungle Fire Sling ticks all the boxes. Cognac balances out Cherry Heering, Parfait Amour Liqueur & Benedictine with the zing of Ginger Ale.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice and then strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Ginger Ale

description:
If you are after a liquid representation of a vivid sunset in a cocktail glass, then the Vivid Gibson is the cocktail for you. Created by Joey Tai for Clooney By XO in Melbourne, this drink creates a symphony of citrus sweet & savoury refreshing notes.
Image by Sam Bygrave – kindly provided by Australian Cocktail Month

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and double strain into a Nick & Nora glass

description: If you are after a cocktail with a truly summer flavour, then perhaps its time to give the Raspberry Thyme Margarita a try. With the Tequila and Cointreau from the original, this drink adds Lemon Juice, Raspberries & Thyme to the mix, so that all you’ll need to add is the sun.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: This drink comes from cointreau.com

description: Although the Chancellor is very much a classic, its origin story is pretty much unknown. But our lack of knowledge aside, the Scotch, Dry Vermouth, Tawny Port, and Sugar Syrup result in a complex, sophisticated drink with fruity notes.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: Nothing puts hope in your mind and love in your heart more than the summer flavours of Lillet Rose and Raspberries in a Sweet Charity Cocktail. With Lillet Rose, St Germain, Soda Water and Raspberries to garnish, this is an elegant, floral drink that certainly impress.

directions.instructions: Fill a wine glass halfway with ice. Add Lillet Rosé and St-Germain Elderflower. Top gently with soda water and stir

description: It may sound contradictory, but this drink has elements of saline and smoke,  like if you were eating sushi at a BBQ. Gia It Laldie! is a verb that means to give one all. With Laphroaig 10-year, Cachaça, cardamom ginger cordial, soda water and a garnish with cucumber ‘seaweed’, this drink has a beautiful vigour and energy.

directions.instructions: Stir ingredients in a beaker without ice, then pour over the cubed ice in a goblet

description: Sophisticated? ✅ Refreshing? ✅ Fresh and dry ✅✅. This version of a Cucumber Martini is a clean, natural take on the classic. With Vodka, Bison Grass Vodka, Cucumber and Simple Syrup, you’ll find that cucumber has never tasted so good.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker. Add all other ingredients and shake with ice before straining into a chilled glass

description:
If you love a White Russian but always wanted it to be more Christmas-y, then the Peppermint White Russian needs to be in your glass right now. Using the Kahlúa, Cream and Vodka of the original, this drink ups the Xmas factor with the addition of Peppermint Schnapps.
“While Vanessa had been prepared for most of the horrors that the hospitality industry goes through during the festive season, she had not expected the number of times she would need to duck or suddenly change direction to avoid random guests with unexpected sprigs of mistletoe”

directions.instructions: Shake peppermint Schnapps, Kahlúa and Vodka in an ice-filled shaker, strain into a chilled rocks glass and then top with milk
directions.garnish: Crushed candy canes and sugar rim

ingredients: 15ml Simple Syrup (star anise and black tea-infused)
description:
Spicy, sweet and a touch floral, The Ginger Rabbit offers heady aromatics, with a Ginger, a Bourbon base and infusions of black tea and star anise. Rounded off with Creme Yvette, this drink is packed with flavour and a perfect way to end the day.
“As Vanessa continued to play with tea-in-cocktail combinations, she found her ideas were multiplying faster than a rabbit on heat. But it wasn’t until she whipped up a nice little Bourbon number, that she noticed the tea was bringing out the background notes, and that really started to spice things up.”

directions.instructions: Add the syrup and ginger to a mixing glass. Twist the lemon peel over the glass to express the oils. Drop the peel into the glass and muddle with the syrup and ginger. Add the bourbon, Creme Yvette and bitters with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

description: If you’re a gin drinker, a G&T is probably your go-to and why not, it does exactly what it says on the tin by mixing Gin with Tonic Water. You can get overly fancy with garnishes but to our mind, as long as its namesakes are good quality, you can’t beat a simple lime.

directions.instructions: Add Gin to an ice-filled Highball or Collins glass then top with Tonic Water

description: If you are after a bittersweet but mellow aperitif, then Reno with Montenegro, Suze, Americano Bianco, and Italicus, is a good call. Named after the river in Bologna in Italy, this drink was created by Georgio Ferrarese at the Holy Birds in London.

directions.instructions: Mix by throwing all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: Designed as a variation on the delicious Trinidad Sour, the Surprise Sour is an equal parts cocktail that is truly more than its parts. With Amaro di Angostura, Scotch, Lemon Juice, Pineapple Juice & an Egg White, this is a drink you’ll come back to again.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients into a shaker and dry shake. Add ice and shake again. Double strain into a coupe glass

description: The Blood & Sand is a classic scotch-based cocktail that has withstood the test of time. The recipe first appeared in 1930 in The Savoy Cocktail Book by Harry Craddock and has become a mainstay on bar menus ever since with Scotch, Cherry Heering, Sweet Vermouth & Orange Juice

directions.instructions: Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: The Blood & Sand gets its name from a 1922 bullfighter movie and points to its ingredients: the “blood” represents Heering Cherry Liqueur, and the “sand” is for the Orange Juice.

description: A popular drink throughout Mexico, the El Torado is a delightfully fruity little number. With Dry Vermouth and Apple Juice, it has a dry sophistication with a backbone of Reposado Tequila.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Created by Wyn Vida, beverage director at The Cathedral in Austin, Texas, the Dulce Vida Prickly Pear is a refreshing, easy-to-construct Margarita riff with an eye-catching colour that will grab you every time.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double strain into a rocks glass over a large format ice cube.

description: You could easily say that the Crystal Clear cocktail is clearly refined. With Vodka, Italicus, Kummel Liqueur and Birch Water, this drink has a subtle citrus, pine and carraway flavour.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Raspberry fruit richness balances with bitter botanical complexity in the Irish Whiskey-based drink Super Seedy. With an affinity to an Old Fashioned, this cocktail uses Irish Whiskey (preferably Jameson’s Caskmate Stout Edition), Raspberry Syrup and Suze.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into an ice-filled glass.

description: With a rich colour, a robust fruit flavour, and depth from a combination of rums, this Strawberry Daiquiri will delight you at every sip. Refreshing and summer-ready, you can easily amp everything up by allowing the muddled fruit to sit in the tin with the other ingredients for a few minutes before shaking.

directions.instructions: Muddle the Strawberry with Simple Syrup at the base of a shaker tin. Add all other ingredients with ice and shake. Then fine strain into a coupe glass

description: Refreshing is the watchword when it comes to the Irish Mule. A twist on the classic Moscow Mule, this drink is super easy to put together, combining Irish Whiskey, Lime Juice and Ginger Beer

directions.instructions: Fill a glass tumbler (or copper mug) with ice, then add Whiskey and Lime Juice, before topping with Ginger Beer. Stir well.

description: The phrase, The Bees Knees, was used in Prohibition times as slang to mean ‘the best’. And the combination of Gin, Honey Syrup and lemon Juice, this classic drink is the definition of a  buzz-worthy cocktail.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to your shaker except for the garnish. Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: If you like your Margarita with a bit more of an international flair, then the Italian Margarita should be in your shaker tonight. The Amaretto adds a nice dash of Apricot and Almond flavour to the usual suspects of Reposado Tequila, Cointreau and Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: The Painkiller is a variation of the classic Pina Colada and was created at the infamous Soggy Dollar Bar in the British Virgin Islands using Navy Rum, fresh Pineapple Juice, fresh Orange Juice & Cream Of Coconut.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.more_on_this_drink: The Soggy Dollar Bar was so named because most of their clientele needed to swim ashore (due to the lack of a dock) which often results in them paying for their drinks with wet money.

description: If you want to show off the delightful sweetness of fig, then there is no better cocktail than a Figtini. With Fig Liqueur, Vanilla Vodka, Lemon Juice and a few dashes of Aromatic Bitters, this is a perfect cocktail to drink in an imperfect world.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: If you are after a coffee cocktail that’s not an Espresso Martini then a Pura Vida might be just the ticket. With the rich smokey flavour of Mezcal, the sweet earthy taste of Tia Maria, the smooth full-bodied taste of Averna, and the nice zesty flavour of Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: For an Eastern European version of a Gin & Tonic, you can’t go past a Beton Cocktail. Add the Czech liqueur, Becherovka to a good quality Tonic Water for a cool refreshing drink with a hint of spice.

directions.instructions: Fill a Collins glass with ice, pour Becherovka over ice, squeeze in lemon wedge, and top off with tonic.
directions.more_about_this_drink: The drink’s name is a mashup of the two ingredients, but also a word that translates to “cement” in Czech.

description: A beautifully balanced yet refreshing long drink, the Tennessee Berry Mule is a wonderful combination of berries, almond, and ginger, rounded off with a distinctive Tennessee Whiskey kick

directions.instructions: Muddle the raspberries in the base of a cocktail shaker and add ice. Add all ingredients except the ginger beer and shake Strain into a highball glass and top with ginger beer

description: My love for telling stories is the key behind my creations, to share and be part of the Patrón Perfectionists story is something I am immensely thankful for! My cocktail strives to bring the story of the Patrón Jimadors to life, and I am extremely proud of the outcome! – Aiden Rodriquez – Eau de Vie

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, stir over cubed ice. Strain into coupe glass then express lemon zest over the top, this is very important as it brightens up the cocktail and adds light citrusy aromas which balance perfectly with the heavier and sweeter notes. Add a quartered strawberry on the rim which pairs perfectly when eaten with the cocktail.

description: If you are after a spiritous and aromatic cocktail then the paycheck is a drink that pays off. The Honey Syrup balances the bitter Suze which both works nicely with the Earl Grey infused Gin, Dry Vermouth and Cointreau.

directions.instructions: Rinse a chilled glass with Absinthe and set aside. Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into the Absinthe rinsed glass

description: Sloe Gin replaces sweet vermouth in this simple Negroni riff. The Sloe Gin replaces the Vermouth and has just enough sweetness to balance the gin and Campari. The Sloe Gin adds some bright red berry notes to the drink and has a surprising amount of acid.
Sweet and creamy, the Celtic Frappe is a drink that offers more than just a boozy ice cocktail due to the mix of Irish Honey Liqueur, Vermouth & Pastis

directions.instructions: Shae all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double-strain into a rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

description: Watermelon takes centre stage in the Watermelon Elderflower Cocktail. Accentuated with rum, elderflower liqueur, and a hint of Lime Juice these ingredients combine to create a satisfying and refreshing drink.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber at the base of a shaker and add all other ingredients. Shake and then strain into a chilled ice-filled glass

description:
With notes of dried fruits, caramelized banana, and soft baking spices, the Emerald Cocktail is a riff on a Manhattan created at The Dean Bar in Rhode Island and made with Irish Whiskey instead of Rye or Bourbon.
“After making her fourteenth Espresso Martini that hour, Vanessa was delighted (and let’s face it relieved) when a guest asked instead for a bartender’s choice, stipulating only that the drink should match the colour of the red Christmas ornaments on the bar.”

directions.instructions: Stir the ingredients together in a mixing glass with ice. Strain into a chilled glass.

description: There’s nothing like a Witch Hunt to get the blood pumping. And with Strega (Italian for Witch) hidden beautifully in this cocktail among the Scotch and Dry Vermouth, we think you’ll enjoy the chase as much as we do.

directions.instructions: Build in an Old Fashioned glass that is nearly full of crushed ice.

description: Pulitzer Prize-winning author Viet Thanh Nguyen’s favourite tipple may be Scotch but when it comes to cocktails, he loves to shake up The Sympathizer. Named after this book, this Bourbon, Aperol, Cynar cocktail was devised by his book representative Andrea Tetrick and was served at the book launch for the novel.

directions.instructions: Shake Bourbon, Aperol, Cynar & Lemon Juice, in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a Champagne flute. Add Champagne to top.

description: If you are after a slightly more unusual margarita riff, then you can’t go past a Weaver. The Hibiscus Syrup melds wonderfully with the Saffron and Anise flavours of the Meletti creating a wonderful depth.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in mixing tin, add ice, shake hard, strain into rocks glass over fresh ice, garnish with a lime wheel.

description: At this time of year, there is no way to get away from the Mint Julep. And who would want to? With Bourbon, Simple Syrup and Mint, this traditional Derby Day cocktail is practically a southern ritual.

directions.instructions: Express the essential oils in the mint and rub them inside the glass. To the same glass, add simple syrup, bourbon, and crushed ice. Stir
directions.garnish: More ice, fresh mint, and powdered sugar.

description: No cocktail embodies the subtle Ginger flavour provided by a ginger Liqueur better than the Oooh Ginger. A delicate mix of Añejo Tequila, Ginger Liqueur and Dry Vermouth, this drink has an almost Martini-like quality.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Ada Coleman created the Hanky Panky for a customer who wanted a drink with a bit of punch to it. And with the combination of Gin, Sweet Vermouth and Fernet Branca, that is exactly what this drink provides.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in the early 1900s at the American bar in the Savoy in London

description: The wonderful aperitif wine, Lillet Rose, takes the driver’s seat in this fruity, summery Martini riff. The best way to describe a Reverse Rose Martini, is by referring to it as a Martini/Aperitif hybrid, which has less Gin than the traditional Martini but enough Lillet Rose (instead of Vermouth) to provide a much lighter, floral flavour.

directions.instructions: Place all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker full of ice. Shake, then pour into the glass using a cocktail strainer.

description: If you are faced with a little left over Champagne, then turn it into a syrup and throw it into this wonderful Daiquiri riff. The Rum, Lime and Champagne work beautifully together in a drink that you’ll be sipping all summer long.

directions.instructions: Shake all the ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a cocktail glass or coupe.

description: Cuba Libre is a fancy of way of saying a Rum & Coke. Translated from Spanish, the name means “Free Cuba,” a phrase that was popularized around the end of the Spanish-American War and used to celebrate that Cuba was freed from Spanish rule.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled glass and stir

description: With the citrus of Cointreau and the fruity palate of Rémy Martin 1738, it’s only natural to think of any riff on a Sidecar as having ‘breakfast cocktail’ overtones. This is very much the case with Purple Haze, created by Blessing Maphosa from Marble Restaurant in Johannesburg, which highlights this idea with a Foccaia and Raspberry Jam garnish

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice filled shaker and fine strain into a chilled coupe
directions.garnish: Toasted foccaia on the rim with raspberry jam.

description: For a classic mix of Caribbean flavours, you really can’t go past a Corn ‘n’ Oil. The “oil” in the Corn ‘n’ Oil is a reference to blackstrap rum, which sits atop this cocktail like a puddle of petroleum.

directions.instructions: Although historically this is stirred, if you shake the first three ingredients, it allows air to get into the cocktail and helps incorporate and brighten the citrus. Strain into a Collins glass, then add crushed ice.
directions.garnish: Float the black strap and bitters over the top of the drink. Stir to combine before drinking.

description: A Frenchified riff on a Greyhound, the Bichon Frisé cocktail is just as darling as you would expect. While its accent comes from the addition of St Germain, there certainly wouldn’t be any harm in adding a French Vodka like Grey Goose to the mix.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker, squeezing the juice out of the Lemon wedge as you add it. Shake, then strain into an ice-filled glass

description: Inspired by the modern classic, the Penicillin, the This & That Cocktail was created by Beth Willows at Seaworthy in New Orleans. This drink adds a healthy dose of Peach Liqueur to the Scotch, Lemon Juice & Ginger Syrup.

directions.instructions: Combiner the ingredients in a shaker with ice. Shake until chilled and strain into a Rocks glass with fresh ice.

description: This pretty pink, gin-based cocktail is closely related to the Pegu Club but comes from the Pendennis Club in Louisville, Kentucky. It uses Apricot Brandy instead of Curaçoa and Peychard’s Bitters which adds a bright flavour profile.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a chilled glass

description: The fun thing about the Lychee Colada is that you don’t need to enjoy long walks in the rain. In fact, all you’ll need to love is Rum, Coconut Milk, Coconut Water & Lychees to make this milky, frothy drink work for you.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a blend with ice. Puree until smooth, then pour into an ice-filled glass.

description: Apparently first served to actor Broderick Crawford back in 1941, the history of the Moscow Mule is one of oversupply. When you need to get rid of Copper Mugs, Ginger Beer and promote a new Russian Vodka in the US, you end up with this refreshingly spicy Cocktail.

directions.instructions: Squeeze lime juice into a Collins glass (or Moscow Mule mug) and drop in the spent shell. Add 2 or 3 ice cubes, then pour in the vodka and fill with cold ginger beer

description: Created by Zac Overman at the now-defunct Fort Defiance in Brooklyn, the Angostura Colada is a riff on a Pina Colada. While retaining the original’s Pineapple and Coconut, the drink replaces much of the Rum with Angostura bitters, which is balanced by the Overproof Rum and Lime.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then pour into a crushed ice-filled glass
directions.garnish: Orange slice, Pineapple leaves, grated nutmeg

description: Pleasant, unexpected and thirst-quenching. Teal is a combination of all green ingredients and 100% Blue Agave. It’s a celebration of the green top notes of Patrón Silver reminiscent of fresh-cut grass, lime zest and eucalyptus – Harrison Kenney – Cantina OK! – Sydney

directions.instructions: Shake first 6 ingredients in a shaker tin and fine strain into a couple glass
directions.garnish: Note – Kiwi slices should be around 3cm (or 1.25 inches) in diameter

description: With its name derived from the early 20th century was mayor of Dijon, France, Félix Kir, the Kir is an enduring classic. With Cassis and dry white wine, this simple yet elegant drink is the perfect aperitif.

directions.instructions: Add Cassis and dry white wine to a wine glass or champagne flute and stir

description: It may be Christmas Eve but if you can get your hands on some strawberries, then you really should throw as many as you can into this refreshing Sake-based cocktail. Take a moment to appreciate the fresh, refreshing taste of this drink before all the madness of tomorrow.

directions.instructions: In a mixing glass, muddle Strawberry, Lemon Juice and Vanilla Syrup in the bottom of a tall glass. Fill glass with ice and add Sake, then top with Champagne

description: Burrowing the art of whisking from the kitchen, the Port Cocoa Flip folds a depth of flavour from the Port into the aromatic spice from the Bitters and Brandy before creating a full mouth feel from the combination of Creme de Cacao, Cocoa Powder and Vanilla Syrup

directions.ingredients: Whisk all ingredients over ice and pour into an ice-filled glass
directions.garnish: Half eggshell with brandy (ensure the shell is thoroughly cleaned before the Brandy is added)

description: Bright and floral, the Esmeralda cocktail was created by Ben Sandrof at Drink in Boston. It mixes Cachaça with Lime Juice and St germain but it’s the futher addition of Islay Single Malt that really makes this drink.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Inspired by one of history’s greatest explorers – Columbus. Our shared passion for adventure, change and discovery and our personal experience of Mexico and Italy led me to fuse these ingredients while painstakingly and sustainably extracting their true feelings and flavours to perfection – Niccolo’ Maffezzoni – The Trader Bar – Darwin

directions.instructions: Shake all the ingredients with ice and double strain into an Old-Fashioned glass.
directions.garnish:
*Roasted cherry tomato juice:
Heat a splash of olive oil in a large pan, add 500g of cherry tomatoes and some salt, black pepper and 8 thyme sprigs. Allow the tomatoes to roast for 7 minutes. Squeeze the tomatoes, strain twice and you’re done.

description: Created by Dick Bradsell in the 1980s, this stunning red punch is a sledgehammer of a drink. With Vodka, Créme de Cassis, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and Champagne, this drink could have been defined as the perfect seasonal punch.

directions.ingredients: Add all ingredients (except Champagne) to an ice-filled shaker and shake. Strain into a highball glass over ice.

description: Created by Chaim Dauermann at Up & Up NYC, the Insanely Good Gin & Tonic is insanely good, due to the mix of the Gin & Suze to which Angostura and housemade lime cordial is added.

directions.instructions: Add Gin, Suze, Lime Cordial and Bitters into a chilled Collins glass. Top up with ice and Tonic

description: If you ever wondered what would happen if you put more than just a dash of Angostura Bitters in a cocktail, then let me introduce you to the Bitter Last Word. As you might assume this is another Last Word riff, so you’ll need to add Green Chartreuse, Maraschino and Lime Juice (as you’d expect).

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Nothing enlivens the classic Mint Julep Cocktail better than a little heat, as we find in the Jalapeño-Spiked Bourbon Julep. Jalapeño infused Sugar Syrup is muddled in with Mint before crushed ice and Bourbon is added for a cocktail with a bit of bite.

directions.instructions: In a Julep Cup, pour Jalapeño Simple Syrup and add Mint; gently bruise leaves with a muddler or wooden spoon. Add enough crushed ice to fill two-thirds of the cup. Add Bourbon and stir gently; then add a bit more crushed ice. Top with a splash of Soda Water.
directions.garnish: To make Jalapeño Simple Syrup – Combine 1 cup Water, 1 cup Sugar, and 2 sliced Jalapeños over heat until sugar dissolves. Remove from heat and let steep 20 minutes before straining syrup and discarding Jalapeños. .

description: While some may call it boring, others define the Vodka Soda as a timeless classic. Definitely simple, clean and crisp, this cocktail is the perfect drink when you don’t want anything too fussy.

directions.instructions: All both ingredients to an ice-filled glass

description: Nothing says summer like a mango and it works particularly well with a good dry Vermouth, as it does in a Mango Buck. Infuse the Mango in the vermouth and then mix with Ginger Beer for a refreshing summery drink.

directions.instructions: Add Mango infused Vermouth to an ice filled highball glass, then add Ginger Beer to top
directions.garnish: To make Mango infused Vermouth – cut the skin and flesh off a Mango, discarding the pit. Combine the Mango skin and flesh with the Vermouth in a scalable bag (preferably vacuum sealed but a zip lock with do in a pinch). Leave to macerate for 12 hours or overnight. Fine strain the Vermouth into a sterilised, sealable bottle. Will keep in the fridge for 2 weeks.

description: A classic but under-rated tequila cocktail, the El Diablo, is a wonderful mid-century drink that combines Tequila with Crème de cassis (a sweet blackcurrant liqueur), Lime juice and ginger.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients except ginger beer in a cocktail shaker and shake with ice to chill. Strain onto fresh ice in a collins glass. Top with ginger beer and drizzle Cassis over the top.
directions.more_about_this_drink: The recipe and the image come via Patrón

description: Created in 2003, by Eric Fossard at Cecconi’s in London, the Watermelon Cosmo is a fun, fruity riff on the original. With a mix of muddled Watermelon, citrus Vodka, Lime Juice, Cranberry Juice, Watermelon Liqueur and Orange Bitters this drink has poolside written all over it.

directions.instructions: Muddle watermelon in the base of a shaker. Add all other ingredients and shake with ice before straining into a chilled glass

description: Catrina, originally known as “La Calvera Garboncera,” was a cartoon created in 1913 to mock the emerging upper classes in Mexico who appeared to be denying their Mexican heritage by adopting more European styles of dress. La Catrina was a reminder that “everyone is equal in the end.” While true, the same can’t be said for this particular cocktail, which is elevated with Horchata, cinnamon syrup, and Patrón Añejo.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in a shaker with ice, then strain into a chilled glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: The recipe and image are courtesy of Patrón tequila.

description: Created by Sasha Petraske, of Milk & Honey fame, the Cosmonaut as a cheeky dig on the Cosmopolitan. Much simpler than the classic it only uses three ingredients – Gin, Lemon Juice and Raspberry Jam.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker and strain into a Nick & Nora glass

description: With overtones of a Paloma Cocktail, the Ginger Grapefruit Cocktail has the same refreshing qualities but with a little bit more spice. With Gin, Ginger Liqueur, Lime Juice, Ruby Grapefruit and Soda Water, this is a drink that is easy as Sunday morning.

directions.instructions: Add Gin, Grapefruit Juice, Lime Juice and Ginger Liqueur to a shaker and fine strain into a chilled glass, then top with Soda Water

description:
With Easter fast approaching, there is no better time to highlight a few Carrot based cocktails – and no better spirit to use than Carrot ‘C’ Specialty Spirit from Boardroom Spirits. Distilled from actual carrots, the spirit is a perfect addition to a Carrot Cosmo, especially when it is mixed with a little Triple Sec and Carrot Juice.
Image courtesy of Boardroom Spirits

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake and strain into a chilled martini glass before garnishing with a carrot twist

description: Named after the famous hotel in West Virginia, the Greenbriar was first recorded in Harry McElhone’s 1927 Barflies and Cocktails. In that recording and most others, the type of Sherry wasn’t actually listed, so through the skill of Simon Difford Oloroso Sherry was decided upon and then added to the Dry Vermouth and Peach Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients. with ice and fine strain to a chilled glass

description: Sometimes a spirit-forward cocktail is really your only option. With this in mind, we present The Addington, a beautifully balanced, stirred Cognac-based cocktail with Vermouth di Torino and Benedictine.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixer glass and strain into a chilled glass

description: If you are after a little spice in your Daiquiri, then you can’t fault a Ginger Daiquiri. Combining Spiced Rum and a little Ginger Syrup (sliced Ginger root with sugar and water) and the usual Lime Juice, this cocktail adds a bit of bite to the classic.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice filled shaker, then shake, before straining into a chilled cocktail glass.

description:
Created by Jim Kearns working at The Happiest Hour in New York City, Fall From The Tree is a cocktail that embraces an autumnal mix of baking spice, apple and brown spirits.
“While Vanessa was a little thrown by the amount of fall decorations that had suddenly appeared in the bar, she did appreciate the seasonal change to the cocktail menu. Sure, she couldn’t see the bartender over all the faux autumn leaves but after a few of his Applejack concoctions, she realised she really didn’t need to …”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: If you’re looking to create a lively cocktail that beautifully marries the earthy complexities of both Suze and Reposado Tequila than you will have found it in Suze-Tequila Sour. Simple add Lemon Juice and a bit of Agave to the mix and you’ll be all set.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and then fine strain into a cocktail glass

description: Found in fields and woodlands throughout County Meath, Jackdaw are highly adaptable, sociable crows that work together for the greater good of the flock.   The Jackdaw cocktail is based on the tropical Jungle Bird, with Irish Whiskey, Pineapple Juice, Campari, Simple Syrup & Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double strain into a coupe glass.

cocktail_name: A Few Of My Favourite Things
description: All Sound Of Music jokes aside, A Few Of My Favourite Things is a wonderful bittersweet citrusy cocktail that’s hard to resist. With Cognac, Sherry, Aperol, Green Chartreuse, Angostura Bitters & Orange Bitters, we assume this might just be one of your favourite things too.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and pour into an ice filled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Dale Bebington at Hawksmoor Air Street in London

description: Created by Meaghan Dorman at Raines Law Room in NYC, the Midnight Boutique makes it the perfect nightcap. Incorporating St-Germain alongside grapefruit, the drink balances these bittersweet flavours with the salinity and smokiness of Mezcal and Tequila.

directions.instructions: Stir all of the ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass with ice. Strain into a chilled coupe.

description:
Named after the sugar on the rim, the Brandy Crusta was invented by Joseph Santini, a bartender in New Orleans at his bar, Jewel of the South back in the late 1800s. One of the establishing classics, this drink is a mix of Brandy, Maraschino Liqueur, Orange Curaçao, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup, and Angostura bitters.
“Standing on the banks of the Mississipi River, Vanessa realised that a half-dozen ensuring classic cocktails had been born from these shores. The thought made her wonder whether any of the amazing new drinks she had tried as part of New Orleans Cocktail Week, would also add to the annuls and impact on the future with the same resonance as the brandy drink she held in her hands.”

directions.instrustions: Combine ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into the prepared glass.
directions.garnish: Rim a coupe glass with sugar and Orange peel

description: If you are finding the temperature starting to rise, then you can do no better than to make yourself The Two-One-Two. With Reposado Tequila, Aperol & Ruby Grapefruit Juice, this drink has the appearance of liquid sunshine and a crisp, tart flavour.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker and fill with ice. Shake well until chilled, about 10 seconds. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

description: A riff on a Sidecar, The Disco Waldo, created by Alex da Fonseca from The Blockman in Johannesburg, takes inspiration from the colours and flavours found in the disco era of cocktails. The tropical fruit notes in the Cape Vintage Port plays beautifully with the citrus of the Cointeau and the plum and fig notes of the Cognac.

directions.instructions:
Apply masking tape to the glass in straight lines about a finger width apart. Coat the glass in a thin layer of sugar syrup, then dust liberally with raspberry powder.
Add all liquid ingredients to shakers with ice. Shake then fine strain into the glass

description:
There’s nothing as lush as velvet and in this case, Red Velvet as created by Brendon Osmers at Gerard’s in Brisbane. The strawberry & lemongrass, red currants and dry fino create a zesty, fresh body which is carried through to the bubbles by the bittersweet Elderflower Tonic
Image – Sam Bygrave

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients (except Tonic Water) in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a highball glass with ice. Top with Tonic Water

description: The Beet Margarita puts a truly vegetal spin on the. classic. With the usual Tequila, Cointreau, and Lime Juice, this drink adds Beet Juice, Apple Cider Vinegar, and Sea Salt for a Margarita like no other.

directions.ingredients: Shake all ingredients with ice. Shake and fine strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

description: Created in 2016 by Rhys Wilson at Happiness Forgets in London, the Jerezana Cocktail (pronounced ‘hera-zana’) is a delicious stirred drink. Combining two Sherries and two Vermouths, this cocktail is heightened by Vanilla and the citrus of Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass.

description: Created by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in 2001, the Bourbon Renewal is essentially a fruity Bourbon Sour that punches above its weight. It is enhanced with Creme de Cassis for a juicy fullness and a dash of Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled highball glass over pebble or crushed ice

description: A riff on the Daiquiri, Against All Odds was created at New York’s Red Paper Clip. Showcasing the funky character and aromatics of Ten To One White Rum, the drink provides an unexpected yet flavoursome twist on the original with the addition of the Chinese 5-Spice Syrup.

directions.ingredients: Combine all ingredients with 4 cubes of good ice and shake vigorously. Double strain into a coupe glass. A froth cap should float on the top of the drink when poured.
directions.garnish:
Chinese 5-Spice Syrup
75 g Cortex Cinnamon
75 g Fennel Seeds
75 g Star Anise
75 g Cloves
75 g Sichuan Peppercorns
Toast all spices over medium-low heat until browned. Cover with simple syrup (800g water cooked with 800g white sugar). Steep over low heat for 30 minutes, cool to room temperature. Strain syrup through cheesecloth, bottle and refrigerate. Use for up to 30 days.
directions.more_about_this_drink: None

description: Created by Audrey Saunders of NYC’s Pegu Club, the Gin Gin Mule is often thought of as a Moscow Mule but with Gin. As the name suggests though, there are two Gins involved – the first is a good London Dry, the second is Ginger Beer, which when combined with the Mint, Lime Juice & Sugar Syrup gives this drink an almost Mojito feel.

Named after the New Orleans suburb, the Bywater was created in 2008 by Chris Hannah at Arnaud’s French 75 Bar. With aged Rum, Amer Picon, Green Chartreuse, Falernum & Peychaud Bitters, this is a spirit-forward, bittersweet, herbal cocktail that is perfect as an after-dinner digestif

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: If you’re looking for a drink with a tropical edge but a definite kick, the Snake Eyes may well be worth the gamble. With muddled Jalapeño and Basil, Pisco, Passionfruit Purée, Mango Purée, Lime Juice & Agave, the odds of you liking this drink are better than its namesake (1 in 36, if you’re curious).

directions.instructions: In a cocktail shaker, muddle the jalapeño and one basil leaf. Combine remaining ingredients in the shaker, and fill with ice. Shake vigorously, then strain into a Martini glass.

description: Fig season can seem relatively short but with the aid of Fig Liqueur, cocktails like Mr Fig Stuff can be created all year round. In addition to the Fig Liqueur, throw a little Gin, Marashino Liqueur and Lemon Juice, for a drink that will sate your fig desires every time.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an filled shaker and shake. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by the Wesley Yeung at Darby’s in London

description: Created by Salvadore Calabrese at Fifty in London, the Salty Martini is a drink that benefits from a long stir. As the name suggests, there is a saltiness that comes through the Caper Brine, as well as from the Fino Sherry, which also adds a distinct nuttiness.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a glass

description: The bright, citrus blend of Seedlip Grove mixed with Clementine Juice (or Orange Juice if you’d like) and topped with Soda Water in the Seedlip Mimosa, is the perfect way to have all the fun of brunch without the day-drinking.

directions.instructions: Add Grove and Clementine Juice to a flute glass and top with Soda Water

description: While Vermouth is mainly used as a modifier these days, that was not always the case and the Reverse Manhattan is a homage to those former days. With Sweet Vermouth, Rye and Angostura Bitters, this is a wildly delicious drink if balanced correctly.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

description: Refreshing and bubbly and easy to drink, The Cornell Special is usually served straight up but can easily be adapted to be served over ice. With Gin, Benedictine, Lemon Juice & Soda Water this is a truly classic Equal Parts Cocktail.

directions.instructions: In an ice filled cocktail shaker combine the Gin, Benedictine & Lemon Juice. Shake well and strain into a Coupe Glass and top with Soda Water
directions.more_about_this_drink: Adapted from Harry Craddock’s 1930s classic The Savoy Cocktail Book

description: If you are after a cocktail that’s bright and full of depth, then the Berlin Wall might be worth a visit. With Tequila, Lime Juice, Falernum and Orange Bitters, this is another drink that shows just how versatile Falernum is to your home bar.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients and double strain into a cocktail glass

description:
Created at New York City bar Mother’s Ruin by bartender Sylvanus Johnson, Word To Your Cardamom is a tongue-in-cheek riff on a Margarita that uses Mezcal, the aperitif Barolo Chinato and Cardamom Syrup in addition to Tequila and Lime.
“Returning to New York, Vanessa had been looking forward to celebrating the 75th anniversary of the Margarita at a friend’s bar. But staff shortages and her unparrelled knowledge of Margarita riffs quickly saw her mixing up some Tequila and Lime variations behind that bar, instead of drinking them in front of it.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and shake until chilled. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.

description: If you are after a cocktail with deep rooty and herbal notes, you’ll scream, ‘Jeez Louise’. Created by Chris McMillian at the Revel Cafe & Bar In New Orleans, this is a bittersweet drink highlighted by zesty citrus and subtle carbonation.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice, then strain into an ice-filled highball glass. Top with Soda

description: Oddly enough the name of this cocktail actually means ‘railway station’ in Italian, but that certainly doesn’t take away from the spiritous and herbal nature of this digestif. With Fernet Branca, Strega and Sweet Vermouth, the Stazione was originally conceived by Alex Frezza.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: If you and your friends love long afternoons with a Margarita in one hand, then the Seedlip Margarita provides a more elevated option with the inclusion of Notas de Agave into the mix of Lime Juice and Agave Syrup

directions.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add 2 oz of Seedlip with 1 tablespoon of agave syrup and ½ oz of fresh lime. Shake well and strain into a glass.
directions.garnish: Garnish with a salt rim and an expressed orange peel

description: Created by Beth Willow at Seaworthy in New Orleans, This & That is a riff on the Penicillin by Sam Ross. While it uses many of the original ingredients (although some in. different quantities) this drink deletes the Single Malt Scotch but adds Peach Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a rocks glass with ice

description: A bright green blast from the past, the Midori Sour is fun, fruity and definitely delicious. With Midori, Vodka, Lemon Juice, Lime Juice & Soda Water, this cocktail beautifully combines sweet and sour flavours.

directions.instruction: Build the Midori, Vodka, Lemon & Limes Juice in an ice-filled glass and stir. Top with Soda Water

description: Perfect for alfresco summer dining, the Elderflower Cooler uses Raspberries to add a vibrancy of both colour as well as flavour to any gathering. Easy to make, with the crisp additions of Gin, Lemon Juice and Mint, this cocktail is the perfect summertime tipple.

directions.instructions: Pour Gin & Lemon Juice into a rocks glass, then add Raspberries and muddle. Fill the glass with ice cubes, Tonic Water to taste and stir gently to bring all ingredients up to the top.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by the brand ambassador for Plymouth Gin

description: Nothing shines quite so bright in the cocktail world as a sparkly Gin Twinkle. With Gin, St Germain & Prosecco, this easy drink has a light floral flavour and bubbles for days.

directions.ingredients: Combine the gin and St Germain in an ice-filled mixing glass and stir. Stain into a champagne coupe.

description: Modestly named, the Improved Scotch Cocktail was created by Kyle Davidson of Blackbird in Chicago, and adds herbal Benedictine and Orange Bitters to a flavorful base of Scotch Whisky and Honey.

directions.instructions: Combine demerara syrup, Benedictine, Scotch, orange bitters, and Angostura bitters in a rocks glass. Stir with a large ice cube until chilled, about 10 seconds. Serve.

description: Austin Hartman created La Quebrada Spritz at Montana’s Trail House in New York. It is a delicate yet bracing drink inspired by Hartman’s grandfather, who was a cliff-diver in Acapulco.

directions.instructions: Express Grapefruit twist and place at the bottom of an empty stemless wine glass. Shake Mezcal, Aperol & Grapefruit Juice in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled glass

description: There’s no better way to while away an afternoon than throwing together a Fig cocktail (especially when you should be doing other things). In Full Fig is appropriate for any occasion and is simple to make by adding Fig Liqueur to Vodka, St Germain, Ginger Liqueur and Agave (we’ve been drinking it most of the afternoon, so totally time well spent).

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients (except Soda water) to an ice-filled shaker. Shake, then strain into an ice-filled highball glass. Add Soda Water to top

description: Similar to a Screwdriver, The Bocce Ball utilises the outstanding pairing of almond and citrus through the Amaretto and Orange Juice to create a tall, refreshing highball that is as easy to make as it is to memorise.

directions.instructions: Pour the vodka, amaretto, and orange juice into a tall Collins glass filled with ice. Add a splash of soda water.

description: While the cocktail is a riff on a Boulevardier, the name Smells Like Tea Spirit is a delightful pun on the Nirvana song as it uses Indian Whisky brand John Paul’s Nirvana and black tea, in addition to the usual Sweet Vermouth and Campari.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass then strain into an old fashioned glass with a single large cube of ice

description: There is an old saying that the Jägerita is the one drink that manages to mix a bartender’s favourite shot into a bartenders favourite cocktail. With Jägermeister, Cointreau, Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup, this will soon become your favourite too.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker tin and fine strained into a coupe glass

description: When cold-brewed Darjeeling Tea is mixed with Bourbon, for the Darjeeling Unlimited, it makes a truly refreshing cocktail. A pinch of salt helps enhance the tea’s savory flavours and when that is mixed with lemon and a little Sugar Syrup, you have the perfect summertime cooler.

directions.instructions: In an ice-filled shaker, combine the tea, bourbon, simple syrup, lemon juice and salt. Shake well. Strain the cocktail into a rocks glass

description:
As part of a collaboration with Patrón, Heidi’s Black Magic-Rita was created for Heidi Klum’s annual Halloween party in 2023. Utilising the brand’s prestige tequila, Patrón El Alto, the cocktail adds Blackberry Syrup, Fresh Lime Juice and Scrappy’s Fire Water Tincture for a drink that definitely casts a spell.
“In an attempt to fight off the effects of her jetlag, Vanessa finally emerged from her apartment and into the haze of a friend’s pre-Halloween Halloween party. While it may not have had the cache of Heidi Klum’s actually Halloween party, the broken smoke machine was doing its best to mist over that point.”

directions.instructions: Shake Tequila, Blackberry Syrup and Lime Juice in an ice-filled shaker. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass and top with 2 drops of the fire water tincture
directions.garnish: Black Salt rim and a sugar spider web garnish.

description: Although The Franklin in New Orleans has made subtle tweaks to the classic Rosita, swapping smoky tequila for mezcal and Aperol for Campari, the result is a softer take but one with plenty of character.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: A pre-dinner aperitif that is light, bitter and bright, Too Soon? was created by Attaboy’s Sam Ross. A mix of Gin, Cynar, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and orange slices, this is a drink that will surprise and subsequently delight.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain to a chilled coupe
directions.more_about_this_drink: Recipe from Sasha Petraske Regarding Cocktails

description: A riff on the classic Whiskey Sour, the Apple Sour Bourbon is a nice fruity twist on the original. Neither too sour or too apple-y, this drink creates a delicate balance with Bourbon, Apple Juice, Cointreau, Lemon Juice & Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain into an Old fashioned glass

description:
A little bitter, a little fruity but definately delectable, Uno Más is a cocktail that ois as easy to ddrink as it is to make. With Mezcal, Aperol, Agave Syrup, Lime Juice and Guava Purée, this is a drink that will definately have you coming back to the bar.
“Vanessa loved a good bar takeover, so when she heard that one of her favourite bartenders was doing a shift in Singapore, she had to go. Sure, it wasn’t exactly like following a rock band on tour, but she considered that, in this modern age when everyone is famous, she considered it the nearest thing.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description:
Created by Natasha David, Mountain Man is a riff on a Whiskey Sour utilizing a little peach through Pêche de Vigne, as well as the roundness of Maple Syrup and the spice of a little Ginger Syrup.
“With this latest cocktail consultancy gig now done, Vanessa decided it was the perfect time for both her and her faithful PA, Juan, to escape the heat of the city and enjoy the last of the summer weather upstate. So with a case of Bourbon, a tent and a fishing pole, the pair answered the call of the great outdoors in an effort to discover just how camp they really were.”

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled. Strain over a large rock into a rocks glass.

description: Now while technically a Tom Collins, has four ingredients, we’re assuming no-one really counts the Soda Water. So with Gin, Simple Syrup, Lemon Juice & Soda Water, we’re still counting this as a three-ingredient cocktail because it’s easy, delicious and definitely a drink that has endured.

directions.instructions: Combine the first three ingredients in a highball glass over ice. Stir well then top with soda water

description: Sometimes a long, clear drink with a grassy, Alpine aroma and a fresh pine finish is the only way to go. If this is the case, then a Pernelle with certainly fit the bill, with Vodka, St Germain, Poire William Eau De Vie, Lemon Juice & Soda Water.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled Collins glass. Top with Soda Water
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2007 by Colin Asare-Appiah in London. The drink is named after the wife of Alchemist Nicolas Flamel, who supported her husband’s search of the Philosopher’s Stone.

description: If you are after a boozy Rye Cocktail, there is no more enchanting cocktail than an Enchanted Field. With a nice slug of Strega added to the Rye base, this drink combines Orange Juice & Sugar Syrup, for a drink that is flavoursome and fresh.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a cocktail glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Adapted from A.J.Rathburn’s 2009 book Dark Spirits

description: Created by Cape Town bartender Leighton Rathbone, the Green Mach III is a riff on a Sidecar with a difference. Sure, it has the Cognac & Cointreau that you would expect. Still, it also incorporates Spanspek (a South African Muskmelon) and a white chocolate rim, which take it into the realm of a Midori Sour and Brandy Alexander, respectively.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled and rimmed glass

description: If you are after a little ‘hair-of-the-dog …’ that is actually restorative, then you can’t go past Jim Meehan’s cocktail Nurse. While Meehan created this drink with Noilly Prat, we’ve gone with the more fruity yet botanical Cucielo Bianco Vermouth di Torino to accompany the Soda Water and Cucumber wheel.

directions.instructions: Build both ingredients in a chilled, ice-filled wine glass

description: With bitter notes of gentian balanced with honey syrup, the Clandestine is an aperitif the also contain citrus bergamot and scotch spirit. This cocktail was created in 2017 by Simon Difford.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: The Rob Roy is, quite simply, a Scotch Manhattan. The cocktail pairs your favourite Scotch with Sweet Vermouth, allowing the Whisky to shine through. This is one cocktail where your premium Scotch will not go to waste.

directions.instructions: Pour the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir well, then strain into a cocktail glass.

description: Adapted from David A. Embury’s 1948 The Fine Art Of Mixing Drinks, the Club Cocktail is the perfect aperitif. This drink has survived due to its dry and aromatic nature and its mix of Fino Sherry, Tawny Port and Orange Bitters.

directions.ingredients: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass.

description: Inspired by the myth of Persephone, daughter of Zeus, who was abducted by Hades, king the underworld to be his bride. Queen of the Underworld is a Margarita variation that swaps in a Pomegranate shrub for Triple Sec (or Cointreau).

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients but garnish to an ice-filled cocktail shaker. Shake hard to blend the ingredients and dilute the cocktail. Strain into a chilled Old Fashioned glass

description: Delicately spiced and honeyed, the Argha Noah offers a flood of flavour. With blended Caribbean Aged Rum, Honey Syrup, Drambuie Liqueur, Oloroso Sherry and Cranberry Juice, this cocktail is almost biblical in its appeal.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a rocks glass

description:
A riff on the classic Cosmopolitan, the Kosmo Kramer uses the expected Vodka but swaps out Raspberry Syrup for Cranberry Juice, Lemon Juice in lieu of the usual Lime, and while it doesn’t give Triple Sec a look in, it does add Ginger Syrup, Aloe Water and Floral Bitters instead.
“As Vanessa watched one of the secretaries from the many office Christmas parties throw up near the bar, she suspected she was in with a chance in tonight’s Bad Behaviour Bingo. All she needed now was An inappropriate word from ‘Santa’ and Drugs in the bathroom, and she would have seen it all …”

directions.instructions: Rinse a chilled coupe with Floral Bitters. Shake the rest of the ingredients 9except Soda water) with ice. Double strain into the rinsed coupe and top with a small splash of chilled soda water.

description: If your taste buds are crying out for a smokey-Pineapple Cocktail, then its worth travelling to Scorpion Reef. This wonderful tropical potion combines just enough overproof heat to capture your attention,  while providing your taste buds with that sensation of caramelized pineapple fresh off the grill.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients, except the Angostura bitters, in a stemless wine glass and fill halfway with crushed ice. Stir with a swizzle stick, then add another scoop of crushed ice
directions.garnish: Float the Angostura bitters on top
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created by Marshall Davis at Gallo Pelón Mezcaleria in Raleigh

description: Created by Phillip Jeffrey at GE Club in London, the Zelda was apparently named after a patron who we have to imagine was as beautifully bright and herbaceous as the drink itself. With muddled Mint, Bison Vodka, Lime Juice and Orgeat, what’s not to love …

directions.instructions: Lightly muddle mint in the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients and shake, before fine straining into a chilled cocktail glass.

description:
With a tropical taste but a winter Christmas look, the White Christmas Margarita is a riff that combines traditional Margarita ingredients with a Coconut edge from Coconut Milk and Coconut Rum.
“Vanessa had hoped that by making her favourite Christmas-style Margarita riff for her favourite guest, she would be filled with all the goodwill and promise of the season. But sadly, the first “woohoo” of the evening hit her ears as a large group of women, obviously on a girls’ night out, descended on the bar.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: Created by Giovanni Burdi in London in the ’90s, the Bohemian Mule is a refreshing and herbaceous riff. The Absinthe holds its own with the Lime Juice, Simple Syrup and Ginger Beer.

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with ginger beer and stir

description: If you are looking for a Margarita variation that has a certain freshness and aromatic herbal notes, then the Garden Basil Margarita will certainly hit the spot. The crispness of Apple Cider and the aroma of fresh Basil, make this riff a true tribute to spring.

directions.instructions: Shake Tequila, Cointreau, Lime & Basil in an ice-filled shaker. Strain into an ice filled rocks glass, then top with Sparkling Apple Cider

description: After a long day, there is nothing better than sipping on a spirit-forward cocktail. The Nail In The Coffin is such a drink, as it combines Fernet Branca and Nadeira Wine with Japanese whisky and Licor43.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice and stir. Strain into a Nick & Nora or Coupe glass.
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created at San Francisco’s Dirty Habit

ingredients: 75ml Volcan de mi Tierra Tequila Cristalino
description: If you like your Martinis dirty, then why not swap out the Gin for Tequila and create a Mexican Martini. Similar to the original but distinctive enough to be intriguing, this drink adds Cointreau and Lime to the Tequila and brine.

directions.instructions: Shake the ingredients in a shaker full of ice, strain into a martini glass and spritz with the orange zest.

description: Nothing is more refreshing on a hot summer day than a tall glass of iced tea. Now if you mix that iced tea with some Lychees & Simple Syrup (& possibly a little Bourbon if you’re so inclined) then you’ve got a cocktail (either alcoholic or non-alcoholic) that really can’t be beaten.

directions.instructions: Chop Lychees into small pieces and then combine with Iced Tea & Sugar Syrup (& Bourbon if required) in a chilled highball glass with ice.

description: One of the best known and most widely drunk of the Spritz Cocktails, the Aperol Spritz is an old-school Italian aperitif that defines summer day drinking. With three simple ingredients – Prosecco, Aperol and Soda Water – this is the perfect Italian aperitif.

directions.instructions: Slice of Orange
directions.garnish: This cocktail traces its origins back to 1920s Venice when local bartenders began to add aperitivo bitters to wine and soda spritzers

description: For a slightly more herbaceous take on our Bee’s Knees theme, than a Bumblebee’s Knees is worth a try. The mix of the herbal Chartreuse and a nice herbal Gin, with Lemon Juice & Honey Syrup will create quite a buzz.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail mixing glass with ice. Stir and then strain into glass.

description: If you want a Mint Julep with a little bit more spice, then you can’t go past a Cinnamon Mint Julep. The strong, sweet and woody flavours of Cinnamon Simple Syrup mix beautifully with Bourbon and the Mint add an additional aromatic element.

directions.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice & dust with ground cinnamon. Add bourbon, cinnamon simple syrup, lime juice and mint. Shake, and pour into a glass.
directions.garnish: To make Cinnamon Simple Syrup – Mix equal oz. hot water, cinnamon, and sugar until sugar is dissolved.

description: It may have a funny name (and yes, our imaginations are making up all sorts of stories) but if you are after something light, then an Umbongo, may be just the ticket. With the pulp of a Passionfruit, Vodka, Passionfruit Liqueur, Orange Juice and finshed with Ginger Ale, this medium sweet, tropical drink it hard to resist.

directions.instructions: Cut Passionfruit in half and scoop out flesh into shaker. Add next three ingredients, then shake with ice, before fine straining into a glass filled with ice. Top with Ginger Ale.

description: Combining floral and sour notes, the Lanique Rose Margarita is a beautiful rose-tinted twist on the Mexican classic that mixes Tequila, Lime and Agave with the rose-based liqueur Lanique.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled glass

description: There is something undeniably refreshing about a Cognac Julep. With a mass of crushed ice, Cognac, Sugar Syrup and Mint, it is only a slight variation to a Mint Julep but well worth the deviation. We’ve used Martial Cordon Bleu for this recipe as it’s mellow fruit and spice finish adds a certain flair.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice then fine strain into a Julep Cup half filled with crushed ice. Use a bar spoon to churn the drink into the ice. Top with more ice and churn again, until the drink fills the cup
directions.more_about_this_drink: Although Bourbon is now commonly associated with the Julep, it was probably first made with Cognac

description: Nothing says summer like the combination of Grapefruit Juice and Rosé that is found in the Rosé Paloma cocktail.  Add to that mix the smokiness of Mezcal, a little Lime Juice and Agave and this wonderful Paloma riff will have you sipping all season long.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice and strain into an ice filled glass. Top with Grapefruit Soda and lightly stir
directions.garnish: Red Grapefruit wedge and a worm salt edge

description: If you want a bubbly version of a White Negroni, then a Rib Tickler Spritz is the cocktail for you. St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur lends a floral edge, while Suze preserves the bitter character of the original.

Stylish in its simplicity, the Stone Fence mixes Bourbon with Apple Cider in a highball style of drink. With a long history that dates back to the mid-1800s, not much is known of its history or the derivation of the name.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in a chilled highball glass, add ice and stir

description: There is nothing more refreshing than the classic Southern style of a Mint Julep. Known as the signature drink for the Kentucky Derby, it is a simple yet wonderful mix of muddled Mint, Sugar Syrup, crushed ice, and a good dose or two of Bourbon.

directions.instructions: In a Julep cup lightly muddle the Mint and Simple Syrup. Add the Bourbon and pack tightly with crushed ice. Stir until the cup is frosted on the outside. Top with more crushed ice to form an ice dome
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: First created in the southern United States during the 18th century

description: If you are looking for a delicate cocktail with a bit of a punch, then the Elder’s Fizz is your perfect summer drink. The St Germain creates the ideal bridge between the floral whisky and the sparkling wine.

directions.instructions: Chill a cocktail or champagne glass by filling it with ice and setting it aside. Stir the Whisky and St Germain in an ice-filled mixing glass. Discard the ice from the cocktail glass then strain in the mixture. Top the cocktail up with chilled sparkling wine.

description: Created by Bobby Heugel at Houston bar Refuge, Greenhorn is an easy-to-construct, fruit-forward drink that combines bright-green Midori with the bittersweet Suze and Blanco tequila.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled Nick & Nora

description: There are a few recipes out there for a Frisco Sour but we’ve used the original here. The drink marries the spiciness of rye with the sweet herbal qualities of Benedictine and then holds it all in check with Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker, then strain into a cocktail glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: If this mix is a little sour for your taste, 0.25oz of Sugar Syrup can be added.

description: What’s the dirty little secret of a Dirty Martini? Well, brine, of course! With Gin, Dry Vermouth, Olive Brine & Olives for the garnish, this riff brings a salty, savory note to the classic.

directions.instructions: Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: If you want a Hazelnut riff on the classic Black Russian, then a Nutty Russian should be ypour go-to cocktail. To make this work a good shot of Angelico is added to the Vodka and Coffee Liqueur that make up the original.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: A fearless riff on a Penicillin cocktail, the Honey Badger mixes up Rosemary, Ginger, Lemon, Honey & Bourbon. Yet, like its namesake, this drink is badass and should never be underestimated.

directions.instructions: De-stalk a sprig on rosemary and muddle the leaves with Bourbon at the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients, shake with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass.

description:
Although the deep red colour of The Half Bood Prince makes it a perfect Halloween cocktail, the mix of Bourbon, Chambord, Pomegranate Juice, Lemon Juice and a touch of maple Syrups takes the appeal of this drink far beyond magic and mystics.
“Having been sent a rather beautiful bottle of Bourbon by a PR friend, Vanessa decided to get into the Halloween spirit by making herself, and her faithful PA Juan, a rather nice little treat. Unfortunately, Vanessa was to discovered, as she turned into the hall, that Juan had decided to instead go with an arachnid trick.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: Created by Iain Meldrum at the Michael Neave Kitchen & Whisky Bar in Edinburgh, his version of The Dandy is a pale aperitif. The Single Malt Scotch, Suze and Dry Vermouth sit well together creating a drink that is dry and more on the bitter side of bittersweet.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into an ice-filled glass

description: If you are a fan of a good Tequila cocktail, then the Medicina Latina will be a hard drink to resist. Perfect as an after-dinner indulgence, this drink combines Tequila Blanco with a touch of Ginger Syrup and a little more Honey Syrup to even it all up.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Marco Tello at The Varnish, LA

description:
A featured offering at Cachette 1907 Bar during the inaugural New Orleans Cocktail Week, the Southern Gentleman is a riff on a Blueberry Bourbon smash and is, due to the addition of the fall sweetness of Pear Liqueur, just as gentile as its namesake.
“Since Vanessa believed that walking off a plane and straight into a bar was the only way to travel, her friends at New Orleans Cocktail Week were not surprised to see her down a sweet little bourbon number less than an hour after her arrival.”

directions.instructions: Muddle Blackberries., Mint and Simple Syrup in a shaker. Add Bourbon, pear Liqueur, Lemon Juice and ice, then shake. Strain into a rocks glass

description:
