Created by Anthony Mylott at Margo’s in Santa Monica, California, the Mezcal Avocado Margarita is a riff that offers a creamy texture from the avocado and a good dose of Mezcal.
“While Vanessa found making Margarita riffs all night made her happy, she quickly realised she had forgotten how truly difficult people could be. While she was used to certain guests making passes, she never saw the point in them loudly declaring their drinks should be comped because they ‘know’ the owner.”

directions.instructions: Shake the avocado and ice (to break down the avocado), then add Mezcal, Agave & Lime Juice and shake until chilled. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass
directions.garnish: Chile Salt: Add 2 parts of kosher salt to 1 part Aleppo pepper and a dash of cayenne

description: If you are after a deeply romantic looking cocktail then I’ll Wait For You is definitely one you shouldn’t wait to make. With Grapefruit-infused Gin, Lillet Rouge and Lambrusco, this drink is lush, dark and bittersweet.

directions.instructions: Combine Gin and Lillet Rouge in an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir well and strained into a chilled cocktail glass. Top with Lambrusco

description: A bit of a riff on the Sidecar Cocktail, the XYZ may be the end of the alphabet but it’s right up front when it comes to Rum based sours. You’ll never regret making this simple but tasty little number with White Rum, Cointreau & Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: Created by Simon Difford at the Cabinet Room in London in 2017, the Mexican in Manhattan swaps nearly everything out but is still a riff on the classic Manhattan. The Rye is replaced with Añejo Tequila, the Sweet Vermouth for Bianco Vermouth, the Angostura Bitters for Lavender Bitters and then a touch of Maraschino Liqueur is added for a little sweetness.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: More than the sum of its parts, the Zucca Sour is an extraordinary cocktail that is simple to make but bar-quality to drink. Mixing Rabarbaro’s earthy, herbal character that amplifies the gin, while the Lemon Juice and egg white transform it into a lively sour.

directions.instructions: Dry shake all ingredients & then add ice and shake again. Strain into a cocktail glass

description: When you can’t decide between Bourbon and Wine, the Rose & Rosé Bourbon takes you to a wonderful middle ground. With Bourbon, Rosé Wine, Rose Syrup, Ruby Grapefruit Juice and a topping of Soda Water, this is a wonderful light and bright drink.

directions.instructions: Mix all ingredients in a mixing glass, then fine strain over ice into a Rocks glass

description: With very much a Jamaica feel, the Street & Fly Special was created by Joseph Schwartz as a homage to the bon vivant lifestyle of Errol Fly and his friend Sam Street when they spent time in the Caribbean. This is reflected through the drinks use of dark Rum, Pimento Dram, Giger Syrup ad Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake the first four ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled Collins glass. Top with Soda water

description: If you are after a gin cocktail with a truly countryside feel, then you can’t go past the Rhubarb Rebel. Mixing those distinctly earthy flavours of Rhubarb and cloudy apple, this drink heightens the relaxed spritz vibe with the addition of Soda Water and Prosecco.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: Sometimes you just need to reach for a drink that’s not only simple but also refreshing. With good quality Cachaça, fresh Lemon Juice and a nice dose of Honey Syrup, the Lemon Beat is just one of those cocktails that will not be beat (especially in the heat).

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: Can’t decide what to drink? Then why not do a mashup of two cocktails as presented in the White Negroni Daiquiri. Combining Rum, Lillet Blanc, Suze, lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and Orange Bitters, this drink is the best of both worlds.

directions.instructions: Shake all the ingredients with ice, then strain into a chilled glass

description:
A twist on the classic Pinã Colada, the Pinã Cholada is made with Toasted Coconut infused Pisco, Coconut Water, Lime Juice, Falernum, and Pineapple Syrup. A true ode to tropical drinks, this cocktail is named after a tiny Thai Restaurant in LA.
To infuse the Pisco, toasted the Coconut in a 350-degree oven for ten minutes, then combine Pisco and Coconut in a large jar. Let sit at room temperature for three days, shaking once a day, then strain through cheesecloth

directions.instructions: Combine everything in a shaker and dry shake without ice, then add ice and further shake. Strain into an ice filled collins glass.

description:
A sweeter iteration of the classic Cosmopolitan, Not Your Cosmo was created at JJ Dak in New Jersey and uses Dry Curacao in place of Triple Sec and a lime and Cranberry Reduction instead of straight Cranberry Juice.
“While at first Vanessa found the constant stream of Christmas music enchanting, after two weeks of Holly Jolly Christmas and Jingle Bell Rock, she quickly came to the conclusion that all she really wanted for Christmas was a chance to drown her sorrows with a truly Silent Night.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled glass
directions.garnish: Lime Cranberry Reduction – Combine 6.4oz Sugar, 4oz Lime Juice & 4oz Cranberry Juice in a saucepan and put on low heat for about 15 minutes to reduce. Will keep refrigerated for up to a month.

cocktail_name: Breakfast at the Maison de Martin
description: South African bartender Alecs Besier has combined some of your favourite breakfast staples to create Breakfast At The Maison de Martin. She has mixed butter croissant washed Rémy Martin 1738, with coffee-infused Cointreau and pressed juice, all topped with a rich butter float.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled coupe

description: So, you want to keep it simple? There’s nothing simpler or tastier than a Barista Old Fashioned. It has enough Irish Whiskey to make it worthwhile, enough Coffee Liqueur to keep you pleasantly alert and 2 dashes of Angostura Bitters to balance everything out.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass. Add ice and stir until cold. Strain into a Double Old-Fashioned Glass over fresh ice.

description: My Patrón Perfectionists entry was inspired by sharing a drink with friends. I wanted to create something bright, approachable and refreshing while showcasing the versatility of Patrón Silver – Daniella Darakis – The Gresham

directions.instructions: Shake Tequila, Pomegranate Juice, Lemon Juice and Honey Syrup over ice. Strain into a wine glass, add ice, the top with prosecco and pink grapefruit soda.

base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description: A riff on the classic drink the Clover Club, the Hickson ‘Clover’ House, adds a bit more of a kick to mix. Using the Egg White and the Lemon Juice (all be it double the amount) from the original, this drink replaces the gin with Hickson Rd Summer Cup and adds to the Raspberry Syrup by transforming it into a Spiced Ginger and Raspberry Syrup.

directions.instructions: Hard shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled Coupe glass

description: If you’ve ever made a Martini, looked at it and thought ‘Why is there not almond in this?’, then we have a Martini variation that will answer that question and so much more. The Dis-a-Tini mixes up enough Vodka, Dry Vermouth and Amaretto to put a twist in your next cocktail hour.

directions.instructions: Stir the vodka and vermouth and pour into a martini glass. Add a splash of Disaronno and garnish with an olive.

description: Otro Palabra means Another Word in Spanish, so as you might assume,  this is yet another variation of a Last Word.  This is a milder but still herbal and earthy variation on the classic, using Reposado Tequila instead of Gin and Yellow Chartreuse instead of Green.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker. Then strain into a cocktail glass

description: The Airmail is a very elegant classic that was first published in 1949, in Esquire Magazine’s Handbook For Hosts. Aged Rum and Brut Champagne are balanced with a little Honey Syrup and Lime, for a drink that’s always a welcome delivery.

directions.instructions: Shake rum, lime juice and honey syrup in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a champagne flute and top with champagne

description: If you are looking for a way to elevate your next cosy night in, then a Crown Royal Vanilla Hot Chocolate has all the comfort of a hot chocolate but with the addition of rich crème brûlée and toasted oak flavours of the Crown Royal Vanilla.

directions.instructions: Make your favourite hot chocolate and add Crown Royal Vanilla, then top with Whipped Cream

description: Taking inspiration from the classic cocktail the Rusty Nail, Simon Gifford has added fruity and floral elements for his Galvanised Nail. Using the same base of Scotch and Drambuie, he has added St Germain, Apple Juice and Lemon Juice for an uplifting take on the original.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: If you like a French 75, then you’ll be completely charmed by the Southern 75. Made with IPA Beer, Bourbon, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup, this inventive drink is a must for the craft brew age.

directions.instructions: Pour the Beer into a chilled Collins glass. In a Cocktail shaker, combine the Bourbon, Lemon Juice, and Simple Syrup with ice, and shake vigorously. Strain the Bourbon mixture into the Beer

description: If you’ve been wondering what to do with your old Tom Gin, then this slightly Spirtzy Cocktail will be perfect. The Tom Terrific blends Old Tom Gin, Cherry Heering, Lemon Juice & a good dose of IPA, for a summer sipper that will have you coming back for more.

directions.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add all of the remaining ingredients except the beer and garnish. Shake well and strain into a highball glass. Top off with the beer.

description:
Playing with Mezcal’s savoury and salty side, Apium is a Margarita riff from the book Mezcal by Emma Janzen. The savoury notes of celery bitters add to the smoke of the Mezcal for a tantalisingly seasonal take on the original.
“To her mind, nothing broke up the tedium of a long shift better than those moments when the brand reps swaggered in. Although she was familiar with the expression, ‘don’t get high on your own supply’, it still surprised her that most reps asked for drinks that didn’t include the liquids they were supposedly selling.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: A simple savoury twist to a White Lady, Like A Lady has all the elegance you’d expect and a bit of a bite from the ground pepper garnish.  With a refreshing flavour from muddled Cucumbers, this drink also incorporates Gin, Suze, Lemon Juice, Egg White and a touch of Simple Syrup

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker. Add the rest of the ingredients and shake with ice.  Strain back into the shaker and dry shake. Fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by. Michael Hajiyianni at Ruby in Copenhagen, Denmark

description: For a nice twist on the Paloma, you’ve got to love the refreshing yet easy cocktail The Snitch. This cocktail merging smoky mezcal with grapefruit shrub (rather than the Paloma’s traditional grapefruit soda) and mixes in a dash of Campari for a slight kick of bitterness.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake well. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Ardit Dizdari at SIP bar in Chicago.

description: Throw a little Bourbon, Rye, Campari, Dry Vermouth & Crème de Cacao into a mixing glass and you end up being as the name of. this cocktail suggests, All In. This drink is obviously spiritous, with a little underlying chocolate and a general bittersweet taste.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: All In was created at Nitecap in New York

description: Long before Sex In The City got hold of it, the Cosmopolitan Cocktail looked a little different than it does today. Back in 1934, the drink utilised Gin, Cointreau, Lemon Juice and Raspberry Syrup for a more well-balanced version than what is often dished up today.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled Coupe glass

description: Moving away from heavy tropical drinks, Juyoung Kang at the Fontainebleau Las Vegas created The 9th Island, a light, bright, tropical Mezcal Highball that’s easy to drink. It has hints of roasted agave, pineapple, and spice, all softened by coconut water.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into the matcha-prepared ice-filled glass
directions.garnish: Rim a Collins glass with the matcha salt

description: If you want to give your Mule that sweet, tangy edge, there is no better way than with a Tangerine Mule. And nothing goes better with citrus than Bourbon topped with Ginger Beer.

directions.instructions: In a mule mug, add all ingredients but ginger beer. Top off with crushed ice and add ginger beer.

description: If you’re after the warm hug of a hot chocolate but with a definite boozy yet citrusy edge, then the Orange Hot Chocolate will be the perfect way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.

directions.instructions: Pour Gin & Cointreau in a glass, add Hot Chocolate Powder, then top up with hot water and stir

description: If you can find a gin that uses Bitter Orange Peel as one of the botanicals, then it will blend perfectly with the bittersweet Bergamot of Italicus and make the Gin & It a drink you will mix time and time again

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into chilled glass

description: As you might assume from the name, the Black Manhattan is a riff on the classic Manhattan cocktail. In this version, the Bourbon remains, as does the Angostura Bitters and Orange Bitters but the Dry vermouth is swapped out for Averna.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: If when you grab a jigger, you want Maraschino Liqueur, Yellow Chartreuse and Grapefruit Bitters to be mellowing and delicately flavouring your Anejo Tequila, then good job, you’ve made an Amatitan Twist.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a cocktail glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Dave West at Trio Bar in Leeds back in 2010

ingredients: pinch Lavender Rimming Sugar (Pink House Alchemy)
description: Bold, both in colour and flavour, the Vespertini is (as you might expect) a riff on James Bond’s Vesper Martini. This drink is fit for a king with a nice stir of Gin, Blanc Vermouth, Hibiscus Rose Syrup & Lavender Rimming Sugar.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in an ice-filled mixing vessel and stir, then strain into a coupe glass and top with Sparkling Wine.

description: Named after the Mexican dried salted fruit, the Saladito was created by Marco Tello as a riff on Sasha Petraske’s The Business (which in turn is a riff on the Bees Kees). The trick with this drink is to shake the Mezcal, Honey Syrup and Lime Juice mix with a large ice cube, really well. This produces an almost egg white-like foam to which the cayenne pepper and sea salt can adhere.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients well, with one large ice cube and strain into a chilled couple glass.

description: Originating from the savoy Cocktail Book, the Maiden’s Blush (No. 2) is an enchanting mix of Absinthe and Gin with just a delicate hint of Grenadine. Incredibly simple to make but boozy enough that we hope that someone is seeing the maiden home.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients well in a mixing glass with cracked ice and fine strain into a cocktail glass.

description: If you’ve ever thought that your chocolate deserved to have more of a peppery, smoky edge, then Cocoa Smoke is the cocktail you’ve been looking for. With Mezcal, Ancho Reyes, Crème de Cacao (White) & a little extra Chocolate Bitters, this drink’s name says it all.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled couple glass

description: If you love a little rhyming slang with your cocktails, then the Randy is a perfect choice. The verbal link creates a perfect base with the Port and the Brandy, while the Orange and Vanilla flavours dial this drink up to the next level.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: If chilli spice smothered by honey with vanilla vodka and a little Lime is the combination of taste sensations you are after, then the Spicy Fifty should be very much on your radar. Created by Salvatore Calabrese, this drink was the signature offering on the first menu of the bar Fifty in London.

directions.instructions: Muddle chilli in the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients and shake with ice before fine straining into a chilled glass.

description: The Zucca Highball is a flavoursome variation on a classic highball. The slightly smoky sweetness of Zucca Rabarbaro makes it a perfect match for a blended Scotch, while the Honey Syrup gives a little sweetness and the and the Soda Water lightens everything up.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled tall glass and stir. Top with Soda Water

description: A riff on the El Presidente, the Cuban Liberal is a sadly forgotten classic. The White Rum is softened by Italia Vermouth but then taken up a notch with the addition of the French Amer Picon Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: When you think of cocktails made with Limoncello, it’s hard to go past Salvatore Calabrese’s creation Salvatore Meets. Created in 2015, the drink is basically a refreshing, zesty Lemon Daiquiri topped with a splash of Champagne.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass. Top with Champagne.

description: If you want to experience the lighter side of the Allspice Pimento Dram, then you can’t go past a Dram Rickey. The combination of Allspice Pimento Dram, Lime Juice and Soda Water makes this drink sweet, spicy and refreshing.

directions.instructions: Add the Dram and juice to a Collins glass over ice. Top with the soda water.

description: If you are going to call a drink Bitter-Sweet, then including the combination of a bitter red liqueur, Dry Vermouth and Amaretto is incredibly apt, and exactly what you should put in it.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled rocks glass

description: As delicate as it’s colour, the Raspberry Gin Sling is the perfect mix of Raspberries and Juniper.  Ideal for long summer afternoons, this drink is simple, easy and bursting with succulent fruity flavour.

directions.instructions: Combine Raspberry infused-Gin and simple syrup in a mixing glass and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
directions.garnish: To infuse Gin – Pour a bottle of London Dry into a large clip-top container, then add 250-300g of Raspberries and let infuse for 7-10 days.

description: Printed in 2009 in the book Sips & Apps by Kathy Casey, this version of the Montréal cocktail uses Rye, Sweet Vermouth, Pernod Anise and Peychaud’s Bitters for a sweet rye manhattan with French Creole influence.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Approaching Patrón Perfectionists, I really wanted to create a drink that highlighted the delicious caramel, honeyed notes of Patrón Reposado while still providing a delicious umami experience for the drinker. The use of coriander, soy sauce and Patrón Reposado in a drink was an inspiring experience. The Mamacita was a pleasure to create and make and I hope you enjoy – Grace Rawlings – Memphis Slims House Of Blues – Adelaide

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker, hard shake to bruise coriander leaves to extract flavour. Fine strain into a chilled coupe.

description:
Infused tea into a syrup can be one of the easiest ways to add tea’s flavors to a drink and the Scarlot Glow uses Hibiscus Tea, with it’s gentle sweet floral notes to balance the complex mixture of pisco, yellow Chartreuse and grapefruit juice.
“After an amazing week of experimenting with tea flavours, Vanessa felt particularly drawn to the bolder and brighter flavours that the more floral offerings imparted. This resulted in her quite quickly concluding that the flaming red of Hibiscus was definitely her cup of tea.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: After working with Robert Petrie of Bob’s Bitters to make a reproduction of Abbott’s Bitter, Jake Burger created his first Manhattan riff at the Portabello Star in London. The Portabello Star Manhattan has Rye, Dry Vermouth, Sweet vermouth and a dash of Abbott’s Bitters and is a must-try for fans of the classic.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Based on the Rosy Deacon, a classic cocktail from the Stan Jones’ Complete Bar Guide, this drink was reimagined and rounded out by Jim Meehan at PDT in New York around 2009. With Gin, Sloe Gin & Ruby Grapefruit Juice, it is the Absinth wash that gives the drink it’s ‘green’ name.

directions.instructions: Rinse the glass with Absinthe. Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into the Absinthe-coated glass.

description: The combination of Pear and Pimento Dram in an Allsorts Inc is amazing. Add to that Mezcal, Blanco Tequila, Lemon Juice, Falernum & Orange Bitters, for a cocktail that has all the flavour elements from spicy and sour, right through to sweet and fruity.

directions.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice and add all ingredients. Shake until well chilled, then strain into rocks glass filled with ice.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Developed by Beloved in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

description:
Simple and clean, the Autumn Fizz is the perfect way to celebrate the change of seasons. Mixing Gin, Lemon Juice, Agave Nectar and crisp Sparkling Apple Cider, this is a drink that gives a gentle nod to the nippy weather ahead.
“Being someone who usually prefers admiring nature from a distance, Vanessa thought she as taking the beginning of their second week of camping in here stride. But no matter how much they were roughing it, she did insist that they at least showed a little civility, and at least dress for cocktail hour.”

directions.instructions: Shake Gin, lemon Juice and Agave in an ice filled shaker. Strain into an ice filled glass and top with Sparkling Apple Cider

description: This is a Daiquiri that takes no prisoners. Made with Overproof Rum, Green Chartreuse Lime Juice and Falernum, this drink was created by Gregor de Gruyther at LAB bar in London in 2005.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a chilled glass

ingredients: 1 bottle Experience Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon
description: The perfect fruity summer beverage, the Classic Sangria is a traditional Spanish wine punch that blends Red Wine, Cognac, and a variety of summer fruits. The trick with a Sangria is time, where the longer the fruits and wine get to know each other before you add the Soda, the better.

directions.instructions: In a pitcher, combine orange, lime, apple, grapes, brandy, and red wine. Stir to combine and refrigerate 1 hour (or overnight). To serve, add soda and ice.

description:
Playing up the banana flavour two ways: with Banana-infused Tequila and Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane liqueur, the Banana Hammock offers a tropics-inspired Margarita. Created at Coral Wig in Baltimore, the drink is brightened up with Yuzu Juice and MSG Solution
“During her break, Vanessa had a chance to catch up with one of her favourite guests, a woman who had bartended in New York in the late 80s. The woman was fascinated by the ingredients available and the drinks that Vanessa was able to create. “In my day,” the woman quipped, “if we did anything more complicated than a Vodka Soda, it was a big night”

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
directions.garnish: Himalayan salt blend for rim & grated nutmeg

description: Inspired by a hot Peruvian summer, The Falso Spitz bring a little of Peru to your glass with a combination of Pisco, Aperol, Grapefruit Juice & Elderflower Tonic Water for a drink that will definitely quench your thirst.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients, except the Tonic Water, into a chilled glass over ice. Top with Tonic Water.
directions.garnish: Basil sprig and a twist of Grapefruit peel
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by David Romero Castro for Bottega Dasso in Lima, Peru.

description: An easy equal parts cocktail, the Spicy Dead Lady intertwines smoky Mezcal, and bittersweet Aperol. The drink is rounded off with the soft, tropical spices of Falernum and the tang of a little Lime but finishes with the heat of Hellfire Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients together in a shaker tin with ice. Strain into a Coupe glass
directions.garnish: If you can’t get Hellfire Bitters, a thin slice of fresh habanero pepper added to the shaker tin will also add a small amount of heat
directions.more_about_this_drink: Lime wheel

description: Combining two of the best tastes of summer, the Sparkling Spiked Peach Lemonade is the perfect batched cocktail if you’re after that allusive hit of summer holiday nostalgia. Using a Vodka base, this drink adds a Peach Puree and Lemon Juice that combine to produce a juicy, sweet drink with a little tang.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in a large pitcher and add ice.

description: Often used to qualify women as seductive or ‘dangerous’, the name Pantera Rosa actually mean Pink Panther (yes, as in the films /animated series).In cocktail terms though, it describes a fresh, vibrant and fruity drink with Gin, Raspberries, Limoncello, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup

directions.instructions: Muddle raspberries in the base of a shaker tin and then shake with all other ingredients. Fine strain into a chilled coupe glass.

description:
Probably one of the best known punches, the Fish House Punch is a classic, dating back to the early 19th Century. Dry, a little sour and with an underlying fruit flavour, this drink combines Cognac, Golden Rum and Peach Brandy.
“Although Vanessa still wasn’t convinced by her manager’s idea to add a selection of peach cocktails to the menu, one advantage she could see in that change was that it gave her the opportunity to push one of her favourite classic punch cocktails.”

directions.instruction: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: Highlighting the characteristics of raw liquor, the Albino Old Fashioned is made on a base on White Whisky. Muddled Grapefruit is added for its tangy quality, as are muddled Brandied Cherries for their complexity and of course a dash or two of Angostura Bitters are added to balance everything out.

directions.instructions: Muddle 2 Brandied Cherries with a wedge of White Grapefruit in a heavy-bottomed Old Fashioned glass. Remove the grapefruit wedge for easier drinking. In the glass, add White Whiskey, Simple Syrup, Angostura Bitters and ice then stir to chill.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Tad Carducci for (the now closed) Bar Celonacomes in Brooklyn.

description: For a flamboyant mix of tart and sweet, you can’t go past a French Martini. Easy to drink and very fruity, this cocktail offers a delightful mix of Vodka, Chambord & Pineapple Juice.

directions.instructions: Pour the Chambord, vodka and pineapple juice in a shaker. Add ice and shake like a tambourine. Strain into martini glass.

description: You can’t do Wimbledon without Strawberries and cream, so the Wimbledon Martini allows you to embrace Strawberries in liquid form. Created in the 90s, this Rum based cocktail incorporates fresh Strawberries, Strawberry Liqueur and, of course, a little cream.

directions.instructions: Muddle Strawberries in the base of a shaker, then add all the other ingredients to an ice-filled shaker and shake. Fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: Bring on the sun, the summer, the heat … and then you’ll have the perfect conditions for this refreshing little beauty. A Grapefruit Julep is a mix of Vodka, Grapefruit Juice, Grenadine, Honey, Mint Leaves & Lime Juice and utterly tasty.

directions.instructions: Stir honey with Vodka at the base of a shaker until Honey is dissolved. Add all other ingredients and shake with ice and strain into a glass filled with crushed ice.

description: Well, now it comes down to it, as we explore the Devil’s Soul, which is as you might expect is spiritous, smoky, earthy, bittersweet, floral, and understandably complex. While some may describe this drink as short and evil, the combination of Rye, Aperol, Averna, Mezcal & St Germain is really just what we need today.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description:
The Esplanade Mezcal Swizzle proves that not all Swizzles need to be made with rum. This drink, as the name suggests, mixes the earthiness of Mezcal, with the nuttiness of Sherry for a tasty riff on this tropical, summer classic.
“While Vanessa was putting the final subtle but somewhat suave touches on the new cocktail menu, Juan (her faithful PA), was contemplating his new Louis Vuitton-inspired mantra … WPWT? (Would Pharrell Wear This?) While he had no intention of outshining Vanessa on opening night, he did intend to create a bit of a social media stir (or was that perhaps a social media swizzle?)”

directions.instructions: Combine all of the the ingredients in a Collins glass. Fill the glass halfway with crushed ice. Stir with a swizzle stick until the glass is frosty.

description: The Trinidad Sour may not be a drink that is quite to everyone’s tastes – especially with so much Angostura Bitters – but with Orgeat, Lemon Juice & Rye, this concoction created by New York bartender Giuseppe Gonzalez certainly has an allure.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: Created at Quill in the Jefferson Hotel, Washington DC, the Red Rover feels a lot like a sophisticated Sangria (minus the fruit salad). With Shiraz Red Wine and Navy Rum, the Black Raspberry Liqueur (Chambord) adds that necessary fruity edge.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass.

description: Created in 2010 by Fraser Campbell at the Alchemist in Melbourne, the St Croix Sunset is a beautifully coloured little concoction. With Rum, Apricot Brandy, Campari, Orange Juice, Lemon Juice and Vanilla Syrup, this is not only fruity but bittersweet as well.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: An Old Fashioned doesn’t always have to be made with Whiskey, and a Black Apple Old Fashioned shows that Jägermeister can be a nice alternative, especially when mixed with a little Apple Brandy and Apple Bitters.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled tumbler and stir.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Sother Teague at Amor y Amargo in New York

description: For a spicy and warming on the rocks cocktail, the Old Mill can’t be beat. Peaty Islay Malt & Calvados combine with a good dose of Ginger Wine to create a cocktail that’s ideal for sipping when the temperature drops.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice filled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2014 by Andrea Buttier for The Loft, Clapham Common.

description: Named after the Ed Sheeran song, The Hills Of Aberfeldy is a stunning twist on a highball that is perfect for those moments when you long for the smell of heather. A beautiful mix of Scotch, Benedictine, lemon Juice and Ginger Ale, this drink is easy to drink with a little spice.

directions.instructions: Add Scotch, Benedictine and a squeeze of a Lemon wedge to an ice-filled highball glass, then top with Ginger Ale

description: Whether you’re making a toast to a winning horse or simply taking a break with friends on a Saturday afternoon, the Woodford Spire is as simple to take as it is to drink. Woodford Reserve’s Kentucky Derby cocktail, the Woodford Spire, is an excellent mix of Bourbon, Cranberry Juice and Lemonade.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: If you love a Whiskey Sour, then a Tequila Sour, using 1800 Tequila, is bound to be a hit. Balancing spice flavours with a citrus kick, the cocktail mixes Reposado Tequila, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup, Orange Bitters & Egg White.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with NO ice. Hard shake for 15 seconds. Fill shaker with ice and hard shake for a following 20 seconds. Double strain into a coupe glass
directions.garnish: A few drops of Angostura Bitters

description: If you’d like your Cognac with some sweet herbal and Ginger notes than a Mon Dernier Mot (My Last Word) is for you. The Cognac melds beautifully with the spicy Ginger Liqueur and the herbal Chartreuse for this nice little riff on the classic.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and the fine strain into a chilled Coupe glass
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created in 2015 by Edward Godard at Berlin Bar in Melbourne

description: Due to its colour, you might think the Grasshopper is a 1970s creation, but it was actually first shaken back at the turn of the last century.  A combination of equal parts crème de menthe, crème de cacao, and cream this drink is a perfect minty after-dinner treat.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: The grasshopper is believed to have been invented by Philibert Guichet from the iconic French Quarter restaurant Tujague’s in New Orleans, while he was at a cocktail competition in New York.

description: Bourbon and melon combine in the light and refreshing Melon Splash. The Bourbon pairs wonderfully with the Midori, the Lemon Soda brings it all together and the squeeze of Lime Juice provides just the right amount of tartness.

directions.instructions: Build the Bourbon and the Midori in an Old Fashioned glass and stir. Top with Lemon Soda and a squeeze of Lime

description: Appearing originally in Esquire’s Handbook For Hosts (1949 edition), the Poet’s Dream is very much a dream of a cocktail. With Gin, Benedictine, Dry Vermouth & Orange Bitters, this drink has a wonderfully subtle honeyed and herbal flavour.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixer glass then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: The name of this drink, Psychopathia Sexualis, will immediately catch your eye and of course demand an explanation. It is based on the controversial German 1886 book of the same name that deals with the psychology of deviant sexual behaviour. With Gin, Sherry, Dry Vermouth, Sweet Vermouth & Orange Bitters, this is a drink that doesn’t require any masochism but hey, if sadism is your bent and you want to bring some into the preparation, then you do you …

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice ad strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: The recipe for this drink as it appeared in Grosby Gaige’s Cocktail Guide And Ladies’ Companion (1941) sadly does not stipulate the type of Sherry to be used. While Simon Difford  chose the slightly rich Palo Cortado Sherry, we could not get hold of it, so went for the more accessible Oloroso.

description:
If you are after a drink that perfectly balances fruit, spice, and everything nice, then Cargo Plane will help you imagine that you are watching the sunset on an island beach. Created by Matheson Reece, for Therapy in Adelaide, this cocktail features Rumbullion! Spiced Rum, Aperol & Banana Liqueur.
Image – Matthew Kroker

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a Nick & Nora glass

description: Created by Kelsey Ramage of Trash Collective, the Apple Core Sour takes a sustainable approach by using the part of the apple you might normally throw away, and then mixes it with Vodka, Honey, Aquafaba and Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Muddle apple core in a shaker. Add all other ingredients and shake. Fine strain into a rocks glass

description:
If you are looking for the perfect Fall cocktail, nothing says ‘falling leaves’ better than a Pumpkin Spice Latte Cocktail. With Kahlua, Vodka, Espresso, Pumpkin Spice Syrup and Milk, this is a nicely boozy way to drink your coffee.
“To Vanessa’s mind nothing extinguished the memory of a long flight better than a good cocktail. Thankfully, here faithful PA Juan, was ready at the apartment with the perfect Fall concoction. After all, don’t all girls just love the taste of Fall?”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker for 15 – 20 seconds, to get that smooth, velvety foam going. Strain into a glass, ensuring you don’t forget that beautiful foam.

description: No matter where in the world you are or what the weather is doing, there is a comforting simplicity in drinking a cocktail with bright, refreshing flavours that indicate that, yes, the spirit of spring is eternal. Spring Eternal mixes a house-blended Rum, Apple Lemongrass Wine and Aquafaba for a radiant, frothy sour.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Watermelon and Cucumber are the perfect flavour pairing if you are looking for a fresh and invigorating cocktail. Add to that some Gin and Soda Water and you have a watermelon Cucumber Cooler, the cuatro of refreshment.

directions.instructions: Muddle 2 slices of cucumber in the base of a cocktail shaker, then add Gin, Watermelon, Lime Juice, salt and Simple Syrup. Shake, then strain in a chilled glass with ice and top with Soda Water

description: As long as you can get you hands on Strawberries, any time of year is perfect for a Spring Fling Cocktail. With the fruity depths of Cognac, the herbal slug of Becherovka and the acidity of Lemon Juice, this is a perfect brunch sipper.

directions.instructions: Muddle strawberries in mixing glass. Add rest of ingredients and ice. Shake and strain over ice in rocks glass.

description: A speciality of Miss Emily’s Blue Bee Bar in the Bahamas, the Goombay Smash will take your taste buds to the tropics. This potent Tiki-style drink features Navy Rum, Coconut Rum, Cointreau, Pineapple Juice & Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: The Bootsy Collins amps up the colour, flavour and potency of a Tom Collins with the aid of the ruby-hued Lillet Rouge. Add to that Vodka, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup, and this riff is as funky as its bass guitarist namesake.

directions.ingredients: Combine all ingredients into an ice-filled shaker and shake. Strain into an ice-filled glass.

description: Created in 2017 by Tony Conigliaro, the G&T Royale is a classic, summery aperitif gin cocktail. With flavour hints of Vanilla & Orange, this drink mixes Gin with crisp  Tonic Water and enlivening everythiung with a couple of shots  of Champagne.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled glass and lightly stir

description: If you’ve been thinking to yourself that your Manhattan doesn’t have enough mandarin notes, then you’re in luck with Bonaparte’s Manhattan. With Rye, Sweet Vermouth, and Mandarin Liqueur, it is made drier and all the more complex with the addition of Averna.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a coupe glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: It was created in 2017 by Philip Bischoff at the Manhattan Bar in Singapore.

description: We’re going back into the cocktail annals for this one, with the Sangaree’s origins dating back to the late 1700s. It takes its name from the Spanish word for blood, Sangre, and this version comprises Old Tom Gin, Sugar Syrup and Tawny Port.

directions.instructions: Shake Gin and Sugar Syrup with ice and strain into a chilled glass. Pour the port wine (which will sink to the bottom) and mix, leaving a think clear layer at the top.

description: The name gives away the fact that this cocktail is a distant riff on the classic Manhattan. What the name doesn’t indicate is that it has echoes in its taste of another classic the Dark ‘N’ Stormy.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail glass and then strain into Old Fashioned glass.

description:
If you love an Italian Spritz, then why not go a little further east for a Metaxa Peach Spritzer. Citrusy, refreshing and just a little bit bitter, this drink is the perfect vehicle in which to try this Greek Brandy-like liquid.
“Vanessa’s manager was delighted they would finally use the Greek Brandy-like liquid that had been sitting on the back-bar. A former bartender had assured him it would be the next big thing, but like so many predictions, it had remained unopened.”

directions.instructions: Add Metaxa to a red wine glass. Add Bitters, Tonic Water and ice and stir. Top with Prosecco

description:
Obviously the Golden Sazerac is a riff on a classic Sazerac, the official cocktail of New Orleans. Created by iconic bartender Giuseppe González, the drink swaps out Rye for Cognac, Simple Syrup for Golden Syrup and ups the bitters ratio.
“Escaping to a mate’s Creole cottage for a riff on the most New Orleans of drinks, Vanessa contemplated that sometimes the simplest changes can have the most impact. A change of location, a change of ingredients, a change of pace had all lead her to see the city through a new lense.”

directions.instructions: Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe, discarding any excess, and set aside. Add the cognac, syrup and bitters to a mixing glass with ice and stir until well-chilled. Strain into the prepared rocks glass.
directions.garnish: Twist of lemon peel to release oils (then discard)

description: What happens when Japan meets Italy? Well, a discerning Cocktail that perfectly balances sweet, bitter and savoury of course. Toki Americano has a wonderful, yet unexpected combination of Japanese Whisky, Cocchi Americano, Amaro Nonino & Grapefruit Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice and stir. Strain into a chilled coupe.

description: Created at the RedBar Brickell in Miami, Honeymoon Beach demonstrates that there is no more perfect match than White Rum and Raspberries. Simple, clean and refreshing, the drink also incorporates Pineapple Juice, Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup.

directions.instructions: Muddle raspberries in a cocktail shaker. Add remaining ingredients with ice. Shake and strain over ice.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Honeymoon Beach was created by Marco Balza, Beverage Director for Last Call Group in Miami

description: For a Negroni variation that takes us south of the border, we have an Ancho Reyes Negroni. In this equal parts drink the Gin is swapped out for Tequila, adds the spicy flavour of Ancho Reyes Liqueur, a little Cynar and the Sweet Vermouth from the original.

directions.instructions: Combine and stir all ingredients, then strain over ice in a rocks glass

description: The Americano is based on the old 19th-century Italian cocktail the Milano-Torino, which has Campari and Martini Sweet Vermouth. The story goes that when American came over to Italy during Prohibition, they liked to temper the drink with Soda Water and the locals nicknamed this new drink the Americano.

directions.instructions: Stir Campari and Vermouth in a cocktail glass filled with ice, then strain into a highball glass filled with ice and top with Soda

description: Whether you are coming into spring or experiencing the joys of an Indian Summer, The Duch Connection is a lovely, refreshing twist on a G&T with Genever instead of Gin and beautiful colour from the Lillet Rose and Peychaud’s Bitters

directions.instructions: Stir Genever, Lillet Rose & Peychaud’s Bitters in an ice-filled highball glass, then top with Tonic Water

description: This may seem like a very simple libation but the Highball Mizuwari is a Japanese cocktail that’s all about the Whisky—and the ritual involved. Even before you add the Soda Water, this is a drink that is all about the stirs, so make sure you count them at each stage.

directions.instructions: Stack several large cubes of ice in a highball glass. Pour the whisky into the glass and slowly stir it 13 and a half times. Fill the glass with ice again, and top with sparkling water. Stir three and a half more times to finish the drink.

description: Adapted from a recipe created by John Robinson at The Hive in Arkansas, the Holy Joe Cocktail uses Irish Whiskey, Sweet Vermouth, Apricot Liqueur, and Cynar for a boozy, bittersweet aperitif that is perfect as a nightcap.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: This wonderful mix of St Germain, Vodka & Champagne may seem innocent enough, but trust us, when we say that this is one cocktail that definitely has a glint in its eye. The Twinkle cocktail may appear light and airy but be aware that it packs quite a punch.

directions.instructions: Shake the Vodka and St Germain with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass. Top with Champagne (or Prosecco).
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Tony Conigliaro at the Lonsdale in London in 2002.

description: If you are after an almost mesmerising cocktail then you can’t go past the wonderful flavours of the Hades Cocktail. The wonderful spice of Kraken Rum, is added to the caramel sweet yet slightly bitter finish Averna, then brought together with the bitter-sweet palette of Rosso Vermouth.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, and stir until properly chilled and diluted. Strain into a stemmed wine glass.

description: Late at night, there is nothing more tempting than the bittersweet and citrusy notes found in a Monte Manhattan. A riff on the classic Manhattan cocktail, this aperitivo has Montenegro, Rye, Bourbon and a dash of Angostura.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: Rather spiritous, Archibald’s Last Memory mixes with Rye, Fernet Branca, Benedictine & Maraschino Liqueur. Even though it is intended to be drunk without ice, on-the-rocks does help round out the edges and open the complexity.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass (no ice).

description: With its root in the video game Red Dead Redemption, the cocktail Marston’s Revenge is a drink as nicely complex as the character itself. You won’t need to be too tactical with this drink as it is a mix of Reposado Tequila, Yellow Chartreuse, Lemon Juice and Grapefruit Bitters

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker then double strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: It doesn’t take Google Translate to determine that the Ultima Palabra is a riff on the Last Word. With most of the usual suspects, this equal-parts drink, created by Simone de Luca at High Road House Club in London, swaps out Gin for Mezcal and adds a good measure of Pineapple Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: If you are after a bold and spicy tequila cocktail with nutty almond undertones and a little sweetness, then the Pink Elephant is your drink. Reminiscent of a Singapore Sling, this drink was created by Leo Robitschek at NoMad London.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: Drinking an Irish Car Bomb is probably one of the more preferable ways to let your taste buds explode. With a little Irish Whiskey, a little Bailey’s Irish Cream and a lot of Guinness, it’s not hard to detonate this decadent pleasure.

directions.instructions: Add the Baileys and whiskey to a shot glass. Drop the shot into a half-pint of the beer.

description: Who doesn’t love a riff on a riff and that’s exactly what you get with The Bee’s Bodice.Created by Luke Hanson at Dr Inks Curiosities in Exeter (UK) the drink was based on a riff the bar had formally done on the Bee’s Knees. With Lavender-infused Vodka, Suze, Honey Syrup, Lemon Juice and Grapefruit Bitters this drink has a cleansing bitterness amid a honeyed floral flavour.

directions.instructions: Strain all ingredients with ice, then strain back into the shaker and dry shake, then fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Adapted from the 1937 menu from Bar Florida in Havana, the Daiquiri No. 4 is a wonderful Daiquiri riff that combines Gold Rum (rather than the usual White Rum) to the mix of Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup, and adds a little Maraschino Liqueur for good measure.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with finely crushed ice and strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Constantino (Constante) Ribalaigua

description: There is something wonderful about the combination of Bourbon and Raspberry Liqueur, especially when you add to that mix Cranberry Juice, Lemon Juice and Sugar Syrup for the slightly sweet, but amazingly fruity balance of a Marquee cocktail

directions.instruction: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: The subtle dark fruit and chocolate tones of Dark Ale combine wonderfully with the spice of Ancho Reyes and the rich, smoky flavours of a good single malt Scotch in the cocktail Beer & Loathing.

directions.instructions: Slowly shake all ingredients with ice and strain into rocks glass. Add a large cube.

description: The lovely and light Oaza Cocktail blends Becherovka, with Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup. A bit of a riff on the classic Gimlet, this is a truly refreshing drink with a nice little spicy kick.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into an ice-filled glass

description: You may not have thought it, but Apple Juice and Elderflower Liqueur work really well with Canadian Whisky. If you want to test this idea, give an Elder and Wiser cocktail a try, using the oldest continuously produced Canadian whisky, Elder (you know, just so the name makes sense…).

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a rocks glass.

description: Created by Harry MacElhone of Harry’s New York Bar in Paris, in the 1930s, Between The Sheets is derived from that other classic cocktail, the Sidecar. A boozy mix of  White Rum, Cointreau, Cognac & Lemon Juice, the name is apt if you drink too many.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled Couple glass.

description: If you’re gunning for the perfect Irish Cream cocktail than the Smith & Wesson might be the just pull your trigger. With Vodka, Kahlua, Irish Cream & Half & Half, this is a drink that comes in with all guns blazing

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled rocks glass, then stir

description: One of the few cocktails that can be served both hot and cold, the Pilgrim is a warming mix of Rum, Grand Mariner, Orange & Lime Juices, Pimento Dram & Angostura Bitters. To serve hot, gently simmer ingredients in a saucepan.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: What happens when you mix Marker’s Mark Bourbon with Sipsmith Gin? Well, a Marksmith of course. And when you add a little Sweet Vermouth to the mix it’s like a slightly more boozy Manhattan.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass, stir, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: If you are after a simplified riff on the classic Mai Tai, then Grand Marnier offers you the Grand Mai Tai. Concentrating on only Jamaican Rum, using Lemon juice instead of lime and Orgeat as the only sweetener, this drink puts Grand Marnier centre stage.

directions.instructions: Combine all liquid ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake briefly. Strain into a Collins
directions.garnish: Lime slice, mint and pineapple frond

description: It is believed that Julio Bermejo from Tommy’s restaurant in San Francisco has a legendary knowledge of Tequila. With that knowledge, he created the Tommy’s Margarita, a simple but classic riff on the original that’s made with Agave Syrup but without the traditional Orange Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Shake all the ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass

description: The traditional Bramble has been around since the 1980s but we’ve adapted it a little to make it even fruitier. In our version we’ve swapped out traditional Simple Syrup for a Blackberry Simple Syrup, then added it to the traditional ingredients of Gin, Lemon Juice and Créme De Mûre.

With Grapefruit Vodka and Grapefruit Juice, the Grapefruit Drop is best described as the Grapefruit lovers Cosmopolitan. Refreshing and enlivening with zesty citrus this drink also has Lemon Juice, Triple Sec and Simple Syrup.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: If you’re interested in paler version of the traditional Harvard Cocktail, then a Fair Harvard is for you. While the traditional Harvard has Brandy & Sweet Vermouth, the ‘fair’ version is the perfect mix of Pisco, Bianco Vermouth & Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients except the lemon twist in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled, about 30 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe. Express a lemon zest over the drink
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Robert Simonson in 2016 for a reception at the School of Architecture, Harvard

description: If you are after the spicy, full-flavoured taste of the South, then you’d better be making a New Orleans Mule. A wonderful combination of Bourbon, Coffee Liqueur, Pineapple Juice, and of course Lime Juice & Ginger Beer, it will have you saying Laissez Les Bons Temps Rouler.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice and fine strain into an ice-filled collins glass. Top with Ginger Beer

description: As you might assume from the name, the Tobacco Road cocktail utilises the smoke from Mezcal which it adds to the briny sherry and vegetal Cynar for a drink with a rich Tobacco aroma (with a hint of salt to bring out the flavours).

directions.instructions: Add all ingre3dients to. rocks glass with a large cube of ice and stir

description: An agave-based riff on a Moscow Mule, the Minted Mule mixes Silver Tequila, Ginger Beer, Lime Juice and Mezcal to create a more complex version of the original with hints of smoke mixed with ginger flavour and citrus notes.

directions.instructions: Shake Tequila and Lime Juice in an ice-filled shaker and strain into an ice-filled glass. Add Ginger Beer, then top it off with a float of Mezcal
directions.more_about_this_drink: This was created by Pete Vasconcellos of The Penrose, New York City

description: Who doesn’t love a riff on the Last Word cocktail? This variation, the Other Word, was spotted at the Vanish in Los Angeles and puts together a nice mix of Mezcal, Yellow Chartreuse, Agave Syrup, Maraschino Liqueur and Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass.

description:
It doesn’t take a saint to want to be stranded with this sweet little tropical drink. The Shipwreck Saint offers an infusion of Rooibos Tea into White Rum and another of Cocoa nibs into Triple Sec that add a new dimension to the typical Spiced Rum, Demerara Syrups, Lime Juice and Pineapple Juice.
“With all the fervor surrounding South Africa winning the Ruby World Cup, Vanessa was strangely drawn to the Rooibos Tea. Although normally she found it far too sweet, she did rationalise that the tea’s nuttiness infused it into a tropical-style drink would, like the Springbok’s win, provide a flavourful, yet nail biting finish.”

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with a few ice cubes. Strain into a cobbler or Collins glass over crushed ice. Top with more crushed ice.
directions.garnish: Orange half-wheel & a light dusting of finely ground coffee.

description: Toffee AND Coffee? Yes please! Creamy Toffee meets the indulgent Salted Caramel Flävar in the Sticky Toffee Espresso Martini. This drink is a flavour sensation, hands down and a delicious twist on the Dick Bradsell classic.

directions.instructions: Make the Espresso ahead of time and allow to cool, (or use Cold Brew Coffee). In a cocktail shaker, add ice, then all other ingredients and shake. Strain into a Martini or Coupe glass and wait for the foam to settle before serving.

description: If you are going to drink, then who wouldn’t want to drink like Clint Eastwood? This Manhattan variation is made using Bourbon, a little Sweet Vermouth, and a few dashes of Orange Bitters for a cute little variation on the classic.

directions.instructions: Maraschino Cherry

description: The easiest way to think of the  Jalisco Pear Cocktail is as an Autumn Margarita. The natural pairing of Pear Liqueur & Pimento Dram is a classic combination and when mixed in with Tequila & Lemon Juice, the result is just begging you to curl up with it by the fire.

directions.instructions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add tequila, pear liqueur, allspice dram, and lemon. Shake and strain into an ice-filled old-fashioned glass.

description: A perfect summer aperitif, this fruity and light cocktail is as easy to make as it is to drink. Truly, there is nothing complicated here, so much so that the ingredients are all in the name (Chambord, Vodka, Lemonade). Tres easy! Tres chic!

directions.instructions: Fill a High Ball glass with ice. Add Chambord & Vodka, then top with Lemonade.

description: A beachy play on the classic, this Negroni riff features soft Lillet Blanc in the place of traditional vermouth, with a hint of grapefruit bitters to round out the package. It’s the perfect Negroni for channeling warm summer vibes.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients and stir with ice to chill. Pour into a small tumbler filled with a single large ice cube
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created by Meghan Wright of Mazama Wares in Portland

description: When Richard Boccato and Michael McIlroy worked together at Little Branch in New York City they collaborated to create an American Trilogy. This riff on the Old-Fashioned mixes Brown Sugar with a ‘half-rye & half-Applejack’ backbone to shift the classic into a slightly darker place.

directions.instructions: In a Rocks glass, add Sugar Cube and saturate with Orange Bitters. Gently muddle to make a granulated paste. Add Rye and ice

description: If you are looking for a cocktail with a rich Blackberry flavour and a stronger Ginger finish, then you can’t go past this little beauty which really is Berry Nice. With Blackberries, Vodka, Chambord, Lemon Juice and Ginger Beer, this is both refreshing and super flavoursome.

directions.instructions: Muddle Blackberries in the base of a shaker, then add Vodka, Chambord & Lemon Juice. Shkae with ice and strain into an ice filled glass. Top with Ginger Beer

description: If you love a Margarita but somehow feel that they generally need a bit more oomph, then a Ginger Margarita might just be the drink you’ve been waiting for. With Tequila, Lime Juice and Ginger Liqueur, this is a lovely spiced twist on the original.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: The Japanese Maple is the perfect sour cocktail to start the night right. Simply add a little Lemon Juice, to the Japanese Whisky and balance everything out with Maple Syrup and Egg White, for a perfect, tasty libation.

directions.instructions: Dry shake (without ice) all ingredients, then shake again with ice and fine strained into a chilled glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2009 by Damian Windsor at the Roger Room, LA

description: If you love a Paloma (and realistically, who doesn’t), then why not make it brim with the colour of Plum Liqueur. The Plum Paloma, created by La Contenta in New York, combines Tequila or Mezcal and the usual Lime Juice but adds a little Plum Liqueur for a colour we all love.

directions.ingredients: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain over ice. Top with grapefruit soda.

description: An infinitely drinkable cocktail, the Wink is a seductive little libation that tempts you with every sip. Reminiscent of a Sazerac but with Gin and Cointreau, this cocktail has an Absinthe wash that sets the stage for this delicate yet fruity concoction.

directions.ingredients: Pour Absinthe into an ice-filled glass. Top with chilled water and set aside. Separately shake other ingredients with ice. Discard the contents of the original glass (Absinthe, water & ice) and strain the drink into the empty Absinthe-coated glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2002 by Tony Conigliaro at The Lonsdale in London

description: In bar speak, a boomerang is a drink sent from one bartender to another via a trusted intermediary. Longtime baijiu-bartender Paul Mathew unveiled the Bittersweet Boomerang (with Baijiu, Yellow Chartreuse, Creme De Cacao & Cynar) at the 2017 Tales of the Cocktails as a special gift to the bartenders in attendance.

This drink comes from Ted Saucier’s 1951 book, Bottom’s Up & is basically, a Vodka Mojito.  Served straight up, Hi Ladies is a tasty mix of Vodka, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & just that little bit of muddled Mint.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: If you like your citrus on the tarty side and lots of it, then a Kumquats, Lemongrass & Rum is a drink that certainly won’t disappoint. With Kumquat Juice, Kumquat-lemongrass Syrup and Rum, this drink has a perfectly balanced zing.

directions.instructions: In a mixing glass, combine rum, kumquat-lemongrass syrup, fresh kumquat juice and ice. Shake and serve over the rocks.
directions.kumquat-lemongrass_syrup: Chop two stalks of lemongrass into 2 inch (5cm) pieces, then crush with a muddler to release the juice. Combine lemongrass, 2 cups water and 3/4 cup sugar in a small saucepan. Squeeze one cup of halved kumquats into the lemongrass and water, and drop the pressed kumquats into the saucepan. Bring to a boil. Lower heat, cover and simmer for about 30 minutes. Let it cool in the refrigerator. Strain.

description: Created at NYC’s legendary Milk & Honey, the Greenpoint is a riff on the Brooklyn, which is, of course, a riff on the classic Manhattan. With Rye, Yellow Chartreuse, Sweet Vermouth, Angostura Bitters & Orange Bitters, this is a nice boozy, yet slightly herbal variation.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2006 by Michael McIlroy at Milk & Honey, New York

description: In 1824, Dr Johann Siegert produced his first aromatic bitters in Angostura, Venezuela. One hundred and ninety-four years later, Siegert’s Sparkling Cocktail with Amaro di Angostura, Earl Grey Tea Syrup, Lemon Juice & Tonic Water pays homage to the man.

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled highball glass. Top with Tonic Water and gently stir.
directions.garnish: To make Earl Grey Tea Syrup – Make a Simple Syrup with 1/2 cup of Sugar & 1/2 cup of Water. Remove from heat and add Earl Grey Tea tea bags and let stand for 15 minutes. Remove tea bags and let syrup cool before pouring into an airtight container.

description: Designed to bring out the bright grain flavours in Irish Whiskey, The Declaration was created by Ezra Star at Drink in Boston. The cocktail adds Dry Vermouth to stretch out the Whiskey and Lemon Juice to give the drink more life.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixer glass and stir. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: The name refers to the Declaration written in the 5th century by St. Patrick.

description: A Vermouth-based riff on the classic Army & Navy Cocktail. Army, Navy & The Marines keeps the Gin, Lemon Juice and Orgeat of the original but adds a Dry Vermouth and a pinch of Salt.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients in an ice filled cocktail shaker. Shake and then strain into chilled Cocktail glass

description: Tasting a little like a boozy Cherry Soda, you can’t go past a Cherry Smash if you’re after a a sweet little cocktail. The muddled Cherries really make this drinks the luscious Cherry Heering flavour mixes with the Bourbon.

directions.instructions: In a Rocks glass, gently muddle the Cherries to release some of their juices. Fill the glass with ice, add the bourbon and Cherry Heering and stir well. Top with club soda, stir again and serve.

description: Ayurvedic Tea from The Organic Tea project is wonderful herbal blend made with Cardamom and Chamomile. We have used the tea to create a simple syrup that pairs beautifully in this sour with a blanco Tequila.

directions.instructions: Make up a Simple Syrup (1 cup Sugar & 1 cup water) then steep 4 tea bags of Ayurvedic Tea for 30 minutes. Once the Ayurvedic Simple Syrup has cooled, combine with Lime Juice and Tequila in a cocktail shaker. Fill with ice and shake until well chilled and strain into the salt rimmed coupe glass.

description: Whether you look at this as a Mezcal cocktail, an equal parts cocktail, three-ingredient cocktail or simply as a Negroni riff, the Mezcal Negroni is the perfect modern cocktail, as Mezcal can easily stand up to the strong personalities of both Vermouth and Campari.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled rocks glass with ice
directions.more_about_this_drink: This recipe is taken from Robert Simonson’s book Mezcal & Tequila Cocktails

description: Created by Steve Dragun at Lucy’s Lounge in Brooklyn, the Far East Peach is a perfectly balanced equal parts cocktail. With Yuzu as the star, this drink also combines Rye Whiskey, Mezcal & Crème de Pêche.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker. Shake and strain into a Nick & Nora glass

description: Created by Rool Buckley at Café Lebowitz in New York in 2003, the Riviera Breeze is a summertime cooler that combines the wonderful flavours of aniseed and citrus to really live up to its name.

directions.instructions: Add Pastis and Orange Juice into an ice-filled glass. Top with Ginger Ale and stir

description: Dry and delicate, this modern version of the classic Bamboo Cocktail was adapted by Joaquín Simó in New York. Mixing Fino Sherry, Dry Vermouth, Sugar Syrup, Angostura Bitters and Orange Bitters, this dry is also aromatic and complex.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: To balance the use of Overproof Rum in his Tai Du Mai, a riff on a classic Mai Tai, Erik Hakkinen at Roquette in Seattle added Cognac instead of dark rum, as well as a little Pineapple Syrup to the usual Lime, Orgeat and Triple Sec

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain into a pebble-filled glass

description: Like the Julep, smashes have come to include all sorts of fruit, and this one showcases sweet, ripe strawberries. Muddle those Strawberries with a good dose of Gin, and a little Sugar Syrup, Lime, Strawberry Shrub and a topping of Soda Water.

directions.instructions: In a tall glass, combine the sugar and a squeeze of juice from the lime wedge. Muddle with the back of a spoon to dissolve the sugar. Add the sliced strawberries and lightly muddle. Fill the glass with crushed ice and add the Gin and Strawberry Shrub. Top with a splash of club soda

description: Created by Sam Ross in 2004 at Milk and Honey in New York City, the Old Maid has an English garden party attitude. With Gin, lime, mint, and cucumber. this drink zings with freshness.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker and then add all other ingredients. Shaker and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: The name Santa Cruz Sour was often used in the oldest cocktail book to reference a Rum Sour, so it’s not surprising that Bar By Rhys chose it for its Rum Sour riff. Providing a nice touch of Tiki, the drink mixes the bar’s house-blend Rum, Pineapple Juice, Ginger Cordial, Sour Mix & Aquafaba.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, then dry shake, before straining into a rocks glass with ice

description: To some a Smoky Martini, is considered one of the best of the variations. Traditionally (and this is the version we drink), the cocktail builds on the classic Martini with Gin & Vermouth but adds an amazing smokey flavour with peated Scotch.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Now if you’re going to grab a bottle of Cointreau, it seems only sensible to make a Cointreau Cocktail. A nice bittersweet concoction, this drink mixes Cointreau (obviously) with Sweet Vermouth (we’ve used Punt e Mes) and a few dashes of Aromatic Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir until well chilled and strain into a cocktail glass.

description: When it comes to Blackberry Cocktails, there’s nothing more special than the drink an Especial Day. With muddled Blackberries, White Rum, Sweet Vermouth, Créme De Mûre, Pineapple Juice & Peychards Bitters, the colour and flavour of this drink is beyond par.

directions.instructions: Muddle Blackberries in a shaker, then add all other ingredients. Shake with ice, then fine strain into a chilled glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2005 by Tonic Kacaj at Maze, London

description: You’ve got to love the Aperitif love, especially when it’s for Lillet Rouge. So grab a little Lillet and mix it with Gin, Clemintine Juice, Lime Juice and Angostura Bitters to create the drink, Lillet, My Love.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker and shake. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: With it’s smokey flavour and citrus undertones, the Earl Grey Cider Cocktail has a true Autumnal feel. When added to the Bourbon, Lemon Juice and Apple Cider, the Earl Grey Tea highlights the complexity and depth that Tea can bring to cocktails.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice filled cocktail shaker. Shake well and strain into a Rocks glass filled with ice.

description: If you’ve ever wondered about what a creamier spin on the Aperol Spritz would be like, then Cotagna’s Aperol Fizz is well worth a try. With Aperol, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup, Egg White and Soda Water, this frothy twist was created by Jason “Buffalo” LoGrasso of Cotogna in San Francisco.

directions.instructions: Add Aperol, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup, and Egg White to a cocktail shaker. Shake vigorously without ice for 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white. Add ice and shake until very cold, about 15 seconds. Strain into two small juice glasses.

description: While you may not immediately think of cantaloupes in cocktails, their soft sweetness can work beautifully, as is shown by the fruity and aromatic mix in the ginn-based drink, the Cantaloupe Smash

directions.instructions: In a shaker tin, muddle cantaloupe balls with the liquid ingredients. Add mint leaves and lightly press to express oils. Add ice and shake, then double strain over crushed ice.

description: Sitting proudly within the tiny cocktail movement, the Three Gulps Martini was fashioned by London bar, Tayēr + Elementary. A four to one ration martini, this drink incorporates Vodka, Vermouth di Torrino, and Sherry.

directions.instructions: Sir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: A riff on the modern classic, the Debonair, the Elegente is as stylish as its name. Created by Robert Simonson and published in his book, Tequila & Mezcal Cocktails, this drink replaces Scotch with Mezcal and adds a good belt of Ginger Liqueur for a little zing.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir and strain into a chilled glass

description: Created by Simon Difford in 2006, the Sidecarriage is a wonderfully light and tasty riff on the Sidecar Cocktail. With the Lemon Juice of the original, there are also hints of cider that comes through the Calvados Brandy and a nice little twist from the Elderflower Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass.

description: If you want an Amaro-based variation on the Highball, then the A.L.O could be the cocktail for you. Mixing Amaro di Angostura, with Angostura Bitter, Lemon-Lime Soda and a dash of Orange Bitters, this mix up is pure Angostura perfection.

directions.instructions: Pour Amaro and Lemon Lime Soda over ice in a highball glass. Top off with more ice, add bitters and stir gently to incorporate all ingredients.

description: With a thick, syrupy texture and a rich, fruity flavour, Paradise #3 should really be your #1. The Gin & Apricot Brandy Liqueur plays nicely with the Passionfruit and neither are overwhelmed by the Orange Juice.

directions.instructions: Cut a Passionfruit in half and scoop out flesh into a shaker. Add other ingredients and shake with ice. Fine strain into a chilled Martini glass.

description: The most classic, and some might even say the best, of all the sours, is the Whiskey Sour. It’s all about balance, so even if you don’t usually like Whiskey, the combination of  Bourbon, Sugar Syrup & Lemon Juice, just can’t be beat – it’s a classic for a reason.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice. Shake, then strain into an ice filled Old Fashioned glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: The first printed record of the Whiskey Sour appears in 1862 in Jerry Thomas’ How to Mix Drinks, though the recipe likely dates back many years earlier.

description: With a classically-inspired approach, Plain Sailing is a stirred cocktail created by Paige Walwyn in Chicago, which presents a straightforward mixture of Gin, Blanc Vermouth, Manzanilla Sherry and Sloe Gin.

directions.instructions: Rinse a Nick & Nora glass with absinthe and set aside. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled. Strain into the prepared glass

description: If you’re looking for a plain old Negroni, then, of course, you’ll mix Gin, Campari and Dry Vermouth but if you want something a little different, why not add Aprés Tea (Lemongrass, Liquorice & Lemon Verbena) and create the very tasty Aprés Negroni.

directions.instructions: Add Tea infused Gin, Campari & Vermouth into an ice filled mixing glass. Stir for 20 seconds, then strain into a rocks glasses filled with ice.

description: Tasty, foamy, and refreshing, Konrad Kantor of New Orleans’ Manolito has created the Amaretto Sour Frappé which is, as expected, a riff on an Amaretto Sour with a splash of Pineapple Juice blended into the mix.

directions.instructions: Add Lemon Juice, Pineapple Juice, Sugar and 10oz pebble ice to a blender. Blend slowly then add Amaretto and blend for a further 30 seconds. Pour into a coupe glass

description: If you are after a laid-back, fresh-from-the-garden drink, you won’t go wrong with trying the Rhubarb and Grapefruit Collins. With Rhubarb Gin, Ruby Grapefruit Juice, Honey Syrup & Soda Water, this long, effervescent drink has a certain classic minimalism.

directions.instructions: Shake the gin, grapefruit juice and honey together in an ice-filled shaker. Fine strain into an ice-filled glass, then top with Soda Water

description: There are a few different Afterburner cocktails around but the one that we are doing today is a simple but effective mix of Coffee Liqueur, white Overproof Rum and White Créme De Menthe which creates a smooth, peppermint-laced coffee drink.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into glass and stir. Flambé, then extinguish the flame. Take care of the hot glass rim.

description: Why stop with decorating your altar with sugar skulls when you can decorate your cocktail with sweetness, too? The Boxcart features lightly aged Patrón Reposado, Citrónge Orange, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and the addition of a little extra sweetness with a sugar rim.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in a shaker with ice. Strain into a chilled and rimmed coupe.
directions.more_about_this_drink: This drink recipe and image are courtesy of Patrón Tequila

description: It’s well known that author Normal Mailer is very much a pre-writing drinker. His smokey Martini-style creation, the Berlin Station Chief with Gin and Single Malt Scotch first appeared in his 1991 novel, Harlot’s Ghost.

directions.instructions: In an ice-filled mixing glass combine Gin and Single Malt Scotch, then stir to combine. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

description: If you want a fun and delicious drink that’s a bit more under the radar than a Margarita or a Paloma, you should try a Mexican Firing Squad. The Grenadine adds only a little sweetness and you can also top with a little Soda Water if you want to create a longer, cooling drink.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: First documented in Charles H. Baker’s ‘Gentleman’s Companion’ as having been discovered at the La Cucaracha Bar in Mexico City in 1937.

description: Sweet and graceful, the Honey Rose Margarita is a great riff on the classic. With the Tequila and Cointreau that you would expect, the drink swaps out the Lime Juice and replaces it with Lemon and adds a delicate floral edge with Honey Syrup and Rose Water.
