directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Recipe adapted from cointreau.com

description: The Berry Barracuda has, as you might assume, a bit of a bite. That, of course, comes from the Age Balsamic Vinegar. But it’s the combination of Whiskey and Strawberries that makes this cocktail stand out. Really it’s a combination of unusual flavours that works like a dream.

directions.instruction: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. Shake, and double-strain into a coupe.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Developed by the legendary New York bar The Dead Rabbit

description: Drinking Tequila is a bit of club and now that’s official with the Tequila Club Cocktail. A riff on the Pega Club, this drink has Tequila, Dry Orange Curaçao, Lime Juice, Lavender Bitters and Angostura Bitters and yes, has a bit of a Margarita feel as well.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2017 by Simon Gifford at the Cabinet Room, London

description: “Recuerdo,” the Spanish word for “memory,” and remembering loved ones is essentially what Día de Muertos celebrations are all about. Featuring the light oakiness of Patrón Reposado complemented by brown sugar, citrus, and egg whites, this is a cocktail you’ll want to remember.

directions.instructions: Dry shake all ingredients (without ice) to combine. Add ice and shake again. Strain into an ice-filled glass.
directions.garnish: * Tisana: Dried hibiscus, dried apple, lavender and strawberry.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Skull candy

description: While the average spicy Margarita can be a bit of a cliché, it really is a flavour combination that works. But if you’re after a bit of an alternative take, then the Mexican Razor Blade is a variation that’s anything but average.

directions.instructions: Add ingredients to a shaker. Shake with ice and strain into a Coupe.
directions.garnish: Float a couple of Cucumber slices then sprinkle with Cayenne Pepper
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created Dan Greenbaum of New York bar, Attaboy.

description: If you are poolside this summer, then a Guava Daiquiri is the perfect drink to have in your hand. light, refreshing and summery, Guava Juice makes the perfect addition to the Rum, Cointreau and Lime of the original.

directions.instructions: Muddle mint in the base of a shaker tin, then add ice. Add the remaining ingredients and shake. Strain into an ice-filled glass and top with soda water

description: Pink Gin started as a medical cure, when sailors in the Royal Navy were given Angostura Bitters as an antidote for seasickness. Of course the Angostura tasted nicer when mix with a little Gin and bartenders, the Schofield Bros. have made it better with a little sweetness & Peychaurd’s Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: If you like a Manhattan but ever wondered what it would be like if it was slightly fruitier than making an IVO Cocktail is a must. Simply swap out the Sweet Vermouth for Dry, add it to the Bourbon and Angostura Bitters and throw in a little Chambord.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Charlotte Ashburner in 2009 and named after Quo Vadis, London

description:
While tea is often steeped when used in a cocktail, this Japan-inspired drink from bartender and distiller Allen Katz, sees matcha powder added directly. As well as the Matcha, 14 Hours Ahead incorporates Gin, Lemon Juice, Lime Juice, Honey Syrup and heavy cream.
“After taking some of the teas back to a friend’s bar, Vanessa decided to add a little Matcha to the mix, as she had always wanted to go to Tokyo. And while Japanese bartenders would be horrified at her lack of precision, she reasoned that since they were 14 hours ahead, whatever messy experiements she did now, would already be perfected in their timezone.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker (you can dry-shake—without ice—first, then add ice and shake again to chill). Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.

description: Named for the bluegrass that grows in Bourbon country, the Bluegrass cocktail was created by Hayden Lambert at Merchant Hotel in Belfast. Embracing the Cucumber, Bourbon and the bittersweet orange of Aperol, the drink also has Simple Syrup as well as both Orange and Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker, then add all other ingredients. Shake and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: With Bourbon, Raspberries, Crème de framboise, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup & Soda Water, the Mrs Robinson (No.1) is definitely a cocktail that is trying to seduce you.

directions.instructions: Muddle raspberries in the base of a shaker, then add the next four ingredients. Shake and fine strain into a rocks glass, stir and top with soda water.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2000 by Max Warner at Long Bar Sanderson, London

description: Nothing brings the sun as much as the inclusion of a little Passionfruit in your cocktail. With Gin, St Germain, Passionfruit Juice, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup and a dash of Orange Bitters, the Sun Fruit Cocktail is the perfect drink to celebrate the summer.

directions.instructions: Mix the Gin, St Germain, Lime Juice, Sugar and Orange Bitters into a cocktail shaker. Strain the juice from Passionfruit pulp and add before shaking. Strain into a cocktail glass.

description: If you are looking for a refreshing beer cocktail that’s an alternative to drinking straight beer then the Czechmate has day-drinking written all over it. The Becherovka blends harmoniously with a Pilsner and they are both strengthened by the Vodka and Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake the first four ingredients with ice and strain into an ice filled glass. Top with Pilsner.

description: Created by San Francisco bartender Cynthia Tran, Tropic Like It’s Hot is a light and refreshing rum cocktail that utilises yellow Chartreuse, Lime Juice and the aromatics of Pineapple Sage infused Aperol.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then pour into a ice filled glass.

description:
Simple, bubbly and refreshing, Frankly My Dear is easy to make and offers a bubbly, refreshing, fruity sip that features Peach Puree as well as Tequila, Cointreau and Lemon Juice, all topped with Prosecco.
“Although she was aware that Peach Fuzz was the Pantone colour of 2024, even a Peach & Prosecco cocktail could not convince Vanessa that peach should be used in every cocktail on the new menu.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients (except Prosecco) in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a highball glass. Top with Prosecco

description: A wonderful combination of Rum and Apple flavours, the Puerto Apple is definitely a drink that should be on your must-try list. With White Rum, Applejack, Lime Juice & Orgeat, the apple flavour peaks through in this fruity, flavoursome concoction.

directions.instructions: Fill a shaker with ice cubes. Add all ingredients. Shake and strain into a rocks glass filled with ice cubes.

description: First created in New York by Brian Miller at the Pegu Club, the 19th Century. A Bourbon-based variation on the 20th Century cocktail, this drink also has White Creme de Cacao, Lillet Rouge and Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients into a shaker filled with ice. Shake, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: A lovely low-alcohol twist on the classic London Calling, this drink mixes gin, Fino Sherry and Soda Water for a refreshing after-dinner drink or all-day sipper.

directions.instructions: Combine gin and sherry in an ice-filled highball glass. Top with Soda Water.

description: Working with Seedlip’s tagline for Notas de Agave, the Seedlip Paloma presents all the bright, zesty flavours that you would expect from a Paloma, but by adding this non-alc spirit, you’re choosing differently.

directions.instructions: Add all of the ingredients except the club soda into a cocktail shaker. Shake & strain into a highball glass. Top with soda and add fresh cubes of ice.

description: Simone de Beauvoir was entranced by Apricot cocktails. They were to her (and her fellow existentialists – yes, Jean-Paul Sartre we’re looking at you) a key to understanding phenomenology: it exists to be enjoyed and it existed because it was enjoyed. For us, The Woman Destroyed is just a drink with Scotch, Sweet Vermouth, Apricot Liqueur and Cynar (but yes, it was enjoyed).

directions.instructions: In an ice-filled mixing glass combine all ingredients and stir, then strain into a chilled coupe glass.

description: The Mexican marigold flower, known as cempasuchil, is traditionally used to decorate Día de Muertos altars, and, in the case of the Marigold Mule, it makes its appearance in the form of a garnish alongside, Patrón Silver, St. Germain, fresh lime juice, and ginger beer.

directions.instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice,then addfirst three ingredients before topping the drink with ginger beer.
directions.more_about_this_drink: This drink recipe and image, come via Patrón Tequila

description: Perfect for a hot summer night, the Lychee Lime Fizz is light with the subtle taste of Lychee. Start by muddling Mint Leaves and Lychees in Lime Juice & Honey Syrup before adding Vodka then top with Soda water, for a perfect drink to beat the heat.

directions.instructions: Muddling Mint Leaves and Lychees in the Lime Juice & Honey Syrup. Add Vodka and shake, before fine straining into an ice-filled Collins glass and top with Soda Water

description: No one knows who invented the Alabama Slammer, but legend has it that this cocktail was first shaken at the University of Alabama in 1975. The sweet mix of Southern Comfort, Sloe Gin, Amaretto and Orange Juice is supposedly the signature drink of the Alabama Crimson Tide football team.

directions.instructions: Add all the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake. Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.

description: If you are looking for a perfect spirit to pair with Italicus, then you really can’t go past the addition of Gin. Add to that the citrusy aromatics of Lemon Juice and the silky texture of Egg White and Simple Syrup, you have a perfect drink in the form of a Gin & Italicus Sour.

directions.instructions: Dry shake all ingredients, then add ice and shake again. Strain into a cocktail glass

description: There’s nothing like a bit of Mint Tea and Gold Rum to get your party started right. With added Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & Mint, this Daiquari-style long drink is the perfect summer cooler.

directions.instructions: Muddle Mint in a shaker and add all other ingredients. Shake well with ice then strain into an ice filled Highball glass and top with Soda Water

description: Based on the traditional Irish Coffee, The Blizzard Cocktail adds a bit of Hazelnut flavour and a good dose of Irish Cream Liqueur to the mix, which makes it the perfect way to either start or end St Patrick’s Day.

directions.instructions: Add whiskey, half and half and Bailey’s to a mug, then stir. Add hot coffee and top with whipped cream

description: Mamie Taylor was a famous opera singer around the turn of the 20th century and one story goes that a Rochester, New York bartender created this drink at her request sometime around 1899. This tall cooler is a simple three-ingredient cocktail, that blends Scotch, Lime Juice and is topped with Ginger Beer.

directions.instructions: Pour the whiskey and lime juice into a highball glass filled with ice. Top with Ginger Ale
directions.more_about_this_drink: Thirty years after its creation, the Mamie Taylor appears in Albert Stevens Crockett’s 1935 The Old Wardorf-Astoria Bar Book was sadly never managed to recover from Prohibition and has since faded from the limelight.

description: If you are after a slightly more complex, yet beautifully herbaceous Martini-style cocktail, then The Frank O’Hara is a great place to start. But don’t be mislead by the simplicity of this drink, as the botanicals in both the Gin & the Strega blend harmoniously.

directions.instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: If you love a Negroni but are after something a little less robust than Sweet Vermouth, then give a Lillet Negroni a try. With Gin, Campari & Lillet Rose, this is the perfect summertime variation on the classic.

directions.instructions: Mix all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass and strain into an ice-filled Old Fashioned glass.

description: There’s definitely nothing suburban about the Subourbon Cocktail. With Blackberries, Bourbon, Sweet Vermouth, Cranberry Juice and Angostura Bitters, this fruity, long, Bourbon laced drink is ideal for balmy summer nights with the neighbours.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into an ice-filled glass.
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Adapted from a drink created in 2010 by David Steenkamp at Jamie Oliver’s Berbecoa, London. The original was sweeter and fruitier with a dash of Créme De Mûre.

description: If you love a traditional Whisky Highball but regret that they’re not more tropical, then Tony Roehr at Noble Experiment in San Diego has answered your call. With the Aperol and Passionfruit Syrup you’ve been missing, the Tropical Popsicle has a fun, tropical vibe.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients (except Soda Water) in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Soda Water

description: Replacing both the Vodka and Triple Sec with Rosé Port gives the Rosé Port Cosmopolitan an added depth and flavour that allows the drink to remain balanced, quaffable and incredibly easy to make.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and fine strain into a Nick & Nora glass

description: Toss your G&T aside, we’re submerging ourselves in vibrant ’70s colours with an M&T. “M&T?”, you ask. Well, obviously it’s a Midori and Tonic Water with the added citrus hit of a little Lemon wedge.

directions.instructions: Pour Midori and Tonic water into an ice-filled glass and stir.

description: The easiest drink you could ever make, a Slane & Ginger is essential for any Irish whiskey lover’s drink menu. This refreshing highball is nothing more than a shot of Irish whiskey topped with ginger ale and a squeeze of Lime Juice but none the less, perfection.

directions.instructions: Pour Whiskey into an ice-filled highball glass and top with Ginger and a squeeze of Lime.

description: If you love a little coffee flavour then the Kraken Espresso might make a welcome change from the usual. With the spice of Kraken Rum, the almond-y taste of Amaretto, a little Vodka and finishing with a good jolt of Espresso, you’ll be surprised at how well they work together.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients together with ice and then strain into a Coupe glass

description: With the Añejo Smash, you discover what happens when the Margarita grows up. With Añejo Tequila, Grand Marnier, Agave Syrup, fresh Mint and lemon wedges, this is a cocktail that demonstrates what happens when aged Tequila gets a splash of minty freshness.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice. Shake, strain into a rocks glass packed with crushed ice.

description: Created by Will Ballantine at Wild by Tart in London, the Brasil is a lovely mix of citrus and herbaceous flavours, with Cachaça, Lemon Juice, Yellow Chartreuse & Simple Syrup

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: Cucumber and Basil are truly a winning combination and they work really beautifully in the light, refreshing Cucumber & Basil Smash. Simply muddle Cucumber, Basil, and Simple Syrup before adding the Gin & Lemon Juice.

directions.instructions: Gently muddle Cucumber, Basil leaves and Simple Syrup at the base of a shaker tin. Add Gin and Lemon Juice and shake. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

ingredients: 60ml Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description:
The English may have invented the Summer Cup (a traditional, flavour-packed summer punch), but it seems it took the Australians to perfect it. Using a mixture of the newly released Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup and Ginger Ale, the Hickson Rd Summer Cup Cocktail helps to cool everything down as you breathe in the summer heat.
Image and recipe kindly provided by Hickson House Distilling, Sydney

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled highball glass and stir
directions.garnish: Mint sprig, fresh berries and cucumber slice

description: Fresh, crisp apples makes this wonderful riff on a Gin & Tonic ideal for Autumn afternoon sipping. Designed specifically to be made with Caorunn Gin, due to the spirits natural affinity with red apple yet, at a pinch, this cocktail can really be made with any strong botanical Gin.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients, except Tonic Water but including apple wedges, to a large goblet or wine glass with ice. Top up with Tonic Water.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by James Sutherland for 56 North Bar in Edinburgh

description: Very much a showstopper, the Rhubarb Sour is a delight of a drink. With the taste of Rhubarb breaking through the sherbert-like flavour of the lemon and sugar, the drink is smoothed out by the egg white and grounded by the Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double stain into the other half of the shaker and empty the ice. Dry shake, then pour into a Collins glass with ice

description: Inspired by the classic Army & Navy cocktail, the Strawberry Bearcat was created by John Ploeser at Brooklyn’s Featherweight. With a definite nod to Tiki, this drink is made with gin, orgeat syrup, lemon juice and muddled strawberries.

directions.instructions: Muddle strawberries in the base of a shaker, then add ice and the rest of the ingredients and shake. Fine strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: One of the joys of Equal Parts Cocktails is that they are a breeze to measure and mix. With a delightful mix of Brandy, unsweetened Cranberry Juice, Simple Syrup & Lime Juice, the Cran-Brandy Cobber is just such an easy cocktail.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice filled shaker. Shale well, then strain into a Julep Cup or large Rocks Glass over crushed ice
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: This cocktail appears in Kara Newman’s book, Shake. Stir. Sip. (pub. 2016)

description: Have you always loved the idea of a Cosmopolitan but wished it didn’t have Cranberry Juice? Swap it out now for Aperol and you have an Aperol Cosmpolitan that’s a little bit more grown-up but with the same tart bite.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a couple glass

description: Built on a split-base of Tequila and Mezcal, the Mezcal Sun-Risa, created by Ignacio “Nacho” Jimenez at Ghost Donkey, is lengthened by Orange Juice, Bitter Orange Juice and topped with spicy Hibiscus-Habanero Syrup

directions.instructions: Build the tequila, mezcal and bitter orange juice in a Collins glass over ice. Carefully pour the hibiscus-habanero syrup over the top, to float.

description: Standing for Benedictine and Brandy, the B&B Cocktail is a simple mixing of two spirits. One of the best classic cocktails, it is an icon of sophisticated drinking and makes an ideal after-dinner drink or nightcap.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a balloon glass with ice

description: Blackberries are a good way to incorporate a summer vibe in your cocktails and a simple version is the Blackberry Tonic. A wonderful combination of a semi-sweet Vermouth, with Crème De Mûre and Tonic, will soon have you forgetting your G&T’s.

directions.instructions: Add Vermouth & Crème De Mûre to a chilled High Ball glass with ice. Top with Tonic Water
directions.garnish: Fresh Blackberries and a Lemon wedge

description: Created by Shannon Tebay at Death & Co, the Sundial is a frothy, rich and complex Cognac cocktail with Cherry Eau de Vie, Orgeat and small doses of Elderflower Liqueur and Amaro.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice. Strain into a chilled coupe.

description:
Created by the 2016 patrón Margarita Of The Year finalist from Dallas Stephen Halpin, the Smoked Mangonada Margarita features bright citrusy and fruity flavours complemented by just the right amount of smokiness.
“Picking up another shift at a recently opened rooftop bar, Vanessa was enjoying her time back behind the stick. Like the view it offered, this bar was a little loftier than the usual haunts that she used to work, so it didn’t take long for her to realise that you could tell as much about a venue from the bottles it kept its well, as you could from the menu or the guests.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain over fresh ice into a double old fashioned glass
directions.garnish: Tajin (a chili lime salt) rim & slice of fresh mango

description: Created in the 1930s at a Bermudian nightclub of the same name, the Ace Of Clubs is a wonderful classic to drink while you’re playing cards. This rich Daiquiri riff, prepared uses Aged Rum, Lime Juice and with the lush flavour of Crème de Cacao.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: When a Bamboo Cocktail and a Vodka Martini love each other very much, the result is Well Fortified. With Moscatel, Vodka, Dry Vermouth, Fino Sherry & Bison Grass Vodka, this boozy, aromatic aperitif combines a trio of fortified wines.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass then strain into a chilled glass

description: Found in the late Gary Regan’s book Negroni, The Stiletta is an exercise in flavour combinations.  Created by Phil Ward, the drink combines Star Anise infuse Campari with Sweet Vermouth and Blanco Tequila.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled cocktail glass
directions.garnish: To make the Star Anise infused Campari, combine 20-star anise pods with one bottle of Campari in a jar. Seal and shake gently. Let infuse overnight. Strain through a double layer of dampened cheesecloth.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Star Anise

description: For a sweet little cross-continental journey, why not join us for a little drink we created called Rome Via Tokyo, where Sake and Limoncello show that travel can open a world of flavours

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double strain into a ice-filled rocks glass.

description: Created at Trick Dog in San Francisco in 2013, the Polar Bear is a riff on the classic Stinger Cocktail. While Mezcal and Créme de Menthe may not seem like natural allies, with. a little Blanc Vermouth and Angelica Tincture (which can be swapped out for Celery Bitters) this drink just works.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker (yes, this is a shaken cocktail) and strain into a chilled glass.
directions.garnish: Angelica Tincture – Combine 2 oz Angelica Root and 16oz of a neutral overproof spirit in a glass jar to infuse for two weeks before straining. Will last indefinitely at room temperature. Note – of Angelica Root is hard to come by a couple of dashes of Celery Bitters can be used instead.
directions.more_about_this_drink: None

description: As the snake from the Garden Of Eden would tell you, no harm ever came from a little Original Sin. Of course, he wasn’t creating it with Vodka, Sake and Honey Syrup but luckily you can …

directions.instructions: Pour Absinthe into an ice-filled glass and top with water. Separately, Stir first three ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass. Discard contents of the Absinthe-coated glass and fine-strain contents of shaker into the glass with ice

description: There was never such a set of distinguished writers than those that sat around the Algonquin Round Table. Although they mainly drank Martinis, they also indulged in the hotel’s namesake drink with Rye, Dry Vermouth, Pineapple Juice and Honey Syrup.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: As you might assume, the Algonquin Round Table was in the Algonquin Hotel in New York and those that sat around it included Dorothy Parker, Harold Ross and Robert Benchley to name but a few.

description: If you are after a Martini-style cocktail that has a little bit of sweetness through the addition of Old Tom Gin and Benedictine D.O.M Liqueur, then the Ford Cocktail might just be ideal. Yet keep in mind it is the addition of Orange Bitters and the Orange zest that truly make this drink.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled glass

description: With fresh herbal notes, the Gold Metal is a light, modern, citrusy cocktail. With Reposado Tequila, Yellow Chartreuse, Lemon Juice and Maraschino Liqueur, this is a drink that certainly goes for the win.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into an ice-filled glass.

description: For a truly sunny sipper, you can’t go past the bright yellow look of a Sunflower Cocktail. After a Absinthe rinse, add Gin, Elderflower Liqueur, Lemon Juice & Orange Liqueur in equal parts, for a drink that will really brighten up your day.

directions.instructions: Rinse a cocktail glass with a little Absinthe and discard. Shake all other ingredients together with ice and then strain

description: Created by Ivy Mix from Brooklyns Leyenda, the En Cuarto is an equal parts cocktail with a Latin edge. With a name meaning “in fourths” or “in quarters”, this drink is a variant of a Martini with Pisco, Gin, Dry Vermouth and Sweet Vermouth.

directions.instructions: In an ice-filled mixing glass combine all ingredients and stir. Strain into a chilled Martini glass

description: With the Pompier cocktails as his entry, it’s easy to say that children’s author, essayist, and Pulitzer Prize winner E. B. White is still the authority on The Elements of Style. This refreshing, low-alcohol highball with Vermouth, Créme de Cassis and Soda Water, will clear the proverbial cobwebs and put a little spritz in your step.

directions.instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice. Add vermouth and crème de cassis. Top with club soda.

description: With the Lilikoi Sunset, Mauro Hernandez at Strong Water in Anaheim has created a Daiquiri riff that is a passionfruit version of the original. Leaning into the tropical nature of the drink, this riff uses Passionfruit Syrup and a touch of funk with Jamaican Rum.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: The Grand Sidecar is the signature classic for Grand Marnier cocktails recipes. Truly refreshing and perfectly balanced, the Grand Sidecar effortlessly marries the citrus notes of Cordon Rouge’s bitter orange liqueur with the intensity of Cognac.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled cocktail shaker, then shake vigorously until well chilled. Strain into prepared coupe glass and serve.

description: Are there any words in the English language better than Bittersweet and Bubbly, especially when used together to describe a Montenegro Spritz. And it really couldn’t be easier, as all you need is Montenegro & Prosecco to make this drink an occasion.

directions.instructions: Add Montenegro to a large ice-filled wine glass and top with Prosecco

description: Rum and coffee are natural bedfellows, so work together beautifully in the El Cafecito. With Dark Rum, Coffee Liqueur, Licor 43, Simple Syrup & Chocolate Bitters, this is a tasty drink that is the perfect way to end the night.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients (except bitters) in an ice-filled shaker. Strain into a rocks glass, then add bitters

description: Defying its name, the Black Rock Chiller is a perfect example of the trend for serving room-temperature cocktails. It mixes a big, sweet, menthol hit of Fernet Branca, with the wonderfully herbal quality of Añejo Tequila and bitter Suze.

directions.instructions: In a rocks glass, combine all ingredients. Stir briefly.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Sother Teague, at Amor y Amargo in the East Village NYC

description: If you are feeling a little brash, then you can’t go past a Cheeky Negroni. Fragrant & beautifully balanced, this drink retains the simplicity of the original, with equal parts Aperol, Lillet Blanc & Hendricks Gin

directions.instructions: Fill a mixing glass with ice. Add gin, Lillet Blanc, and Aperol. Stir well. Strain into an ice-filled old fashioned glass. Twist grapefruit peel over the drink to express oils.

description: A riff on a Rum Negroni, Little Cuba blends flavours of chocolate and raisin with a delicate herbal spice. Created by Lisa Kempen at Deadshot in Auckland, this drink stirs Cacao & Coffee Spiced Rum with Cynar and Sweet Vermouth.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass with a large ice cube

description: Created in 2017 by Loris Carotenuto at the Dorchester Hotel in London, The Queen’s Steeple is a bittersweet, orangey aperitif. Dominated by Montenegro Amaro, this drink also incorporates Cynar, Italicus and Boker’s Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: A non-alcoholic riff on an Amaretto Espresso Martini, the Deja Brew will indeed feel familiar to a coffee cocktail lover. With non-alcoholic Amaretto, non-alcoholic Coffee Liqueur, Little Drippa and Vanilla Syrup, this drink is delicious and sophisticated.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: A bit of a riff on the classic Brandy Metropolitan, the Capetonian embraces the best of the Mother City. With a mix of one of the Cape’s finest Brandy’s (Joseph Barry VSOP), Caperitif (a local Dry Vermouth), Angostura Bitters, as well as a local Fynbos Bitters (Naartjie Spice Bitters which can be subbed for Orange Bitters)

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Unlke the South American river of the same name, the Orinoco cocktail is a wonderful mix of Cachaça, Apple Juice, Fino Sherry, White Creme de Cacao, all sweetened with Orgeat Syrup.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Adapted from an originally blended drink created in 2015 by Sergio Padillaat Boca China in Barcelona

description: How good the mix of Strawberries, Raspberry Liqueur and Maple Syrup are with Bourbon will truly make you blush. The Bourbon Blush was created by Simon King at MJU in the Millennium Hotel, London way back in 2003.

directions.instructions: Muddle strawberries in the bottom of a shaker. Add ice and all other ingredients, then shake. Strain into chilled glass.

description: Created by Emily Lanthorne at The Courtesy in Winter Park Florida, the Tequila-based Bella Donna combines bright, tropical notes with Aperol and Pineapple Syrup with a hint of herbaceousness from the Ancho Reyes Verde.

directions.instructions: Rinse a glass with Ancho Reyes Verde, discarding the excess, then fill it with ice. Shake all of the remaining ingredients with ice, then double-strain into the prepared glass

description: The Floridita Margarita, created back in 1999 by Robert Plotkin and Raymon Flores of BarMedia, is a beautiful blush coloured drink that combines Ruby Grapefruit Juice, Cranberry Juice, Lime, Cointreau & Tequila.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: This drink comes via cointreau.com

description: Created as a digestif, After Hours is a Martini-style cocktail with a delicate liqueur richness. With Gin, Maraschino Liqueur, Kummel Liqueur and Orange Bitters, this is drink has a lightly spicy and faintly nutty flavour.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: The Lanique Rose Clover Club is a sweet, floral and silky smooth riff on the classic Clover Club, substituting Lanique and Vermouth for Gin and Lime Juice for Lemon.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe glass

description: If you like your cocktails with a vibrant colour and a strong, fruit, Raspberry taste, then a Tartini is the cocktail for you. With Vodka, Chambord, Cranberry Juice and a bunch of muddled Raspberries, this drink may have a ’90’s edge but still works well today.

directions.instructions: Muddle Raspberries in the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients, shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: Sure, the Parmesan Cheese Espresso Martini may have been a cocktail that went viral, but it does have its virtues. The concept of pairing coffee and cheese goes back centuries and although it has had mixed reactions, for our money, you can go past the subtle savoury and salty element that the Parmesan adds.

directions.ingredients: Pour vodka and coffee liqueur into a cocktail shaker, then add Little Drippa and ice. Shake until chilled and fully mixed and pour into a martini glass

description: Forget Tequila Soda. Instead, go for the cunning highball mashup created by the Hellbender Nighttime Café in Queens, the Margarita Soda. Simplicity is the key to this drink, which uses the base of a Tommy’s Margarita topped with club soda.

directions.instructions: Rim a Collins glass with sea salt. Add the first three ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled. Pour into the prepared Collins glass, top with club soda, and stir.

description: With a distinctly Asian vibe, the Ichijiku (pronounced thee-zhee-kush) is as clean in flavour as it is elegant. With Fig Liqueur, Sake, Coconut Water and Aromatic Bitters, this drink should be sipped slowly and savoured.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: If you are after an Old Fashioned riff with a warming complexity then a Walnut Old Fashioned should hit the spot. So further spike your Bourbon & Orange Bitters with a little Walnut Liqueur for a drink that glides effortlessly down your throat.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir until chilled. Strain into an Old Fashioned glass with fresh ice.

description: If your looking for a laid-back, fruity, slightly sweet Mojito riff, than a Baja Mojito is definitely your drink. Most often found on holidays or by a pool, the Gold Rum, Passionfruit and Passionfruit Liqueur all combine for drink that says RELAX in capital letters.

directions.instruction: Cut Passionfruit in half and scoop flesh into a glass. Add Mint and gently muddle, before adding Rum, Lime Juice and crushed ice. Stir drink to mix before sizzling in the Passionfruit Liqueur
directions.more_about_this_drink: Adapted from a recipe by Wayne Collins in London

description:
The Rhubarb Crumble certainly does not disappoint if you love dessert cocktails. With Rhubarb Gin as the flavour backbone of this drink, it is nicely accompanied by Ginger Cordial and Clementine Soda Water.
Note: Mediterranean Tonic can be used in place of Clementine Tonic & Ginger Cordial can be swapped for either ginger or gingerbread syrup

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: As the name suggests, The Dude Abides is a riff on a White Russian but more than that, the drink with it’s Brandy, Vodka, Amarula and Cold Brew Syrup is a tribute to the Cohen Brother’s The Big Lebowski itself … right down to the ‘rug’ the drink is presented on (it really ties the drink together …)

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice filled shaker, then strain into a small glass sphere with crushed ice
directions.garnish: To get the full effect, place on mini Persian carpet and light the cassia quill “joint”

description: This simple and tasty 2:3:8 recipe is not as sour as a traditional sour (which is usually 3:4:8 – three-quarters sour, 1 part sweet and 2 parts strong) but the bite of the Ginger Syrup definitely makes up for it.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled coupe glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Found in Sasha Petraske’s book Regarding Cocktails

description: If you are after an aperitivo that is not only whisky-laced but also has bittersweet mingled with complex herbal notes, then the Yamabuki is the cocktail for you. Other than being a fun name to say, the drink mixes Japanese Whisky, Bianco Vermouth, Montenegro Amaro & Orange Bitters

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice ad strain into a chilled glass

description: The Tipperary first appeared in recipe books around 1916 but it hit its stride when it came out in Harry MacElhone’s 1922, ABC Of Mixing Cocktails. With the addition of Sweet Vermouth and Green Chartreuse, this is a wonderful Irish Whiskey-forward nightcap.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain to a chilled glass

description: If you’d like your Old Fashioned to have more orange sweetness with notes of Vanilla and oak, then a Grand Old Fashioned is what you should be making. The drink replaces the usual sugar with Grand Marnier for a smoother, more elegant finish

directions.instructions: Build the cocktail in the double rocks glass by first adding a dash of aromatic bitters directly into the glass. Next, add Grand Marnier, followed by the Bourbon. Add a large block of ice and stir until well incorporated and cold.

description: The tart, sweetness of Kumquats mixes really well with Gin, as can be seen in The Luxembourgh cocktail.  With Gin, muddled Kumquats, Rosemary-infused Aperol, Sugar Syrup, a sprig of Rosemary and Soda Water to top, this is a delightful fruity drink.

directions.instructions: Roughly slice 4-5 fresh Kumquats and muddle with Rosemary leaves and Sugar Syrup in the base of a shaker. Add Gin, Aperol and ice and shake vigorously. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass, then top with Soda water.

description: If you used to spend your holidays berry picking as a child, then a refreshing Hedgerow Tonic will definitely bring back some memories. Mixing Gin and floral Elderflower with a combination of fruity spirits, this drink is very much a celebration of summer foraging.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients in order to a High Ball glass over ice

description: Created in 2010 by Dick Bradsell, the Triple A is the ideal modern classic that will start your night off right. As you might assume the use of Absinthe, Apple Juice and Orgeat (Almond), are the three elements that denote its name.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Adapted from Stanley Clisby Arthur’s 1937 book, Famous New Orleans Drinks and How To Mix ‘Em, this Rye-based riff on a Manhattan is made sweeter with herbal Bénédictine, while bittered with Peychaud’s and Absinthe

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: Created by Eric Tecosky at a club on Sunset Boulevard back in the 1990s, Surfer On Acid is the Jägermeister cocktail you don’t expect. Combine Jägermeister with Coconut Rum Liqueur and Pineapple Juice for a very fruity but only slightly sweet drink.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description: If you’re after a Daiquiri-style cocktail that includes a nice dose of Tawny Port than you’ve got to try a Havana Cobbler. With White Rum, Tawny Port, Green Ginger Wine and Sugar Syrup, this drink might seem a little unusual but it has a wonderful spicy flavour.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and then strain into a Rocks glass filled with crushed ice.

description: Sometimes you just need the sweet/ sour that only Pomegranate gives to get the night started right. Thankfully, the Side By Sidecar not only includes the Cognac, Cointreau & lemon Juice of the original but also provides a nice Pomegranate Liqueur kick.

directions.ingredients: Moisten the rim of a chilled Martini glass and coat it with sugar. Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake vigorously and strain into the prepared glass.

description: Life is a bit of a gamble, so why not enlist the aid of a cocktail like Lady Luck. With Gin, St Germain, Pear Nectar, Lemon Juice & Grapefruit Bitters, this is a drink that will certainly help you play your cards right.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a shaker with ice. Shake well then strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: If you are anything like us, then you can’t go past a little Evening Passion. We love it due to its smokiness (via Mezcal), its fruitiness (via Passionfruit Juice & Passionfruit Syrup), its lightness (via Soda water) and let’s face it, it’s really easy to drink.

directions.instructions: Pour Mezcal into an Old fashioned glass filled with ice. Add Passionfruit Juice, Lime Juice & Passionfruit Syrup. Stir then top with Soda Water

description: You don’t get more classic than the Daiquiri, but if you want to switch it up a bit then turn to the Black Daiquiri. Add the spice of Kraken Rum, the full flavour of Demerara Syrup and the wonderful sour of fresh Lime Juice and you have a Daiquiri in a different dimension.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in cocktail shaker with ice cubes. Shake until shaker feels frozen on the outside and strain into cocktail glass

description: For a Sherry-spiked twist on the Bee’s Knees, you can’t go past an O’Henry. With Gin, Lemon Juice, Honey Syrup & a float of Manzanilla Sherry, this cocktail offers a nice, sweet start to the weekend.

directions.instructions: Combine gin, lemon, and honey syrup in a cocktail shaker with ice; shake for 10 seconds. Strain into a chilled glass and float sherry on top.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Bryce Gilmore in Austin

description: A Bourbon & Jam is an easy mix of Blackberry Jam, Bourbon, Lemon Juice and a tiny bit of Honey. This drink, with its use of jam, is the perfect way to get the flavour of Blackberries, if the fruit is out of season.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice. Strain into an ice-filled Rocks glass and add Soda Water to top

description: Created for the 2017 World Class final competition by Kaitlyn Stewart, Spilt Milk is a riff on a Cobbler, with milk liqueur standing in for the sugar and a cherry shrub for the fruit.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake. Fine strain into a mini milk bottle (or small highball) over crushed ice.
directions.garnish: Lemon twist and a gingersnap cookie

description: Audrey Saunders created the French Pearl in 2006 at the Pegu Club NYC as a tribute to 19th-century Parisian architecture. It mixes notes of anise, botanicals, lime, and mint for a drink that is both fresh and complex.

directions.instructions: Add Lime Juice, Simple Syrup and Mint to a shaker tin and muddle. Add the Gin, pastis and ice and shake, then fine strain into a chilled coupe

description: Created by Jillian Vose when she was at Dead Rabbit in NYC, Psycho Killer combines Irish whiskey, white creme de cacao, banana liqueur and coffee nib-infused Campari for a drink that’s lush, bold, yet not overly sweet.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass

description: There can be no better combination in a cocktail glass than Vodka, Coffee & Whiskey (cream), so why not stor up the Muddy Water as it’s not a drink that will confuse matters in any way.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled glass

description: With its name taken from the SE Hilton book, The Outsiders, Stay Gold Ponyboy, Stay Gold is as vibrant in taste as it is in colour. With Bourbon, Thyme-infused Aperol & Dry Vermouth, you really won’t want to say goodbye to this slightly bitter, earthy flavoured drink.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a coupe glass
directions.garnish: To create Rosemary-infused Aperol: Place three long sprigs of fresh rosemary into a bottle of Aperol and let infuse at room temperature for three days.

description: If you are after a little Caribbean buzz, our #COTD a Jamaican Honey Bee is flying straight for you. If you’re not a fan of big Rum drinks or strong cocktails, this is certainly a drink for you and an ideal hot weather thirst quencher.

directions.instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, and fill the mixing glass three-quarters full with ice cubes. Cover with a shaking tin and shake vigorously for 15 seconds. Double strain (through a cocktail strainer and a fine mesh strainer) into a cocktail glass.

description: If you are looking for a more vegetal Baijiu Cocktail to try then Don’t Skip A Beet is definitely worth making. With Baijiu, Gin, Beet Juice, Lemon Juice & Grenadine, this is a well-rounded drink with a more savoury slant.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker tin and shake. Fine strain into Rocks glass.

description: Providing a floral and slightly sour flavour profile, Apricots are the perfect accompaniment to Bourbon, as they mellow out the oaky bite. Created by Fitz Bailey, Brown-Forman mixologist, Summer At The Grove is the perfect Bourbon cocktail, with its Apricot Syrup and muddled Apricots.

directions.instructions: Grill apricot and muddle with bourbon. Strain into a rocks glass, and add one cube of ice, bitters, and syrup. Stir and serve.

description: There is something truly delectable about a good kiss and it seems that French kiss (No.3) does not disappoint. With an underlying character of Cognac, the Lime Juice then tames the flavours of raspberries and the rich almond flavour of Orgeat.

directions.instructions: Muddle Raspberries in the base of a shaker, then add the other ingredients. Shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created in 2015 by Chanelle O’Connor at Salomontini Le Resto in London

description: Created by Seth Brammer at the Filament in Dallas Texas, Brooklyn’s Finest is a nicely spiced riff on the classic Brooklyn cocktail with Cognac, Rye, Vermouth Amaro, Falernum and, of course, Angostura Bitters

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass

description: With a wonderful dry finish, the Arnaud Martini is a classic cocktail with an interesting balance of Blackcurrent, Vermouth and Gin. Named for the pre-ward French actress, pianist and singer Yvonne Arnaud.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: A delicate Gin sour, with lots of green tea flavor up front and an earthy, sweet-and-sour finish. Once the Gin is infused with Green Tea (which only takes a couple of hours) add Lemon Juice and Honey Syrup for

directions.instructions: Combine the Gin, Lemon, and Honey Syrup in a shaker filled two-thirds with ice. Shake well and strain into a chilled cocktail glass
directions.garnish: To infuse Gin – Combine half a bottle of gin (375 ml) with 2-3 green tea bags and let infuse for 2-3 hours

description: A riff on the Manhattan, the Emerald is not only an easy drink to make, but it is one that allows your choice of Irish Whiskey (and Sweet vermouth) to truly shine through.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass

description: Originating back from Jerry Thomas’ day, the Prescription Julep gives a nod to the days when Juleps used to be prescribed for medicinal purposes. And who wouldn’t want to be prescribed a refreshing mix of Rye, Cognac, Mint Leaves, Sugar Syrup and Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Add Mint Leaves and Simple Syrup to a Julep tin and lightly muddle. Add Cognac, Rye and Orange Bitters and stir. Top with crushed ice and stir again. Top with more crushed ice.

description: Nothing makes the rich almond flavour of Amaretto come to life better than honey and if you then mix that with Cognac and Islay Single Malt Whiskey, you get the brilliantly balanced Homely Smoke.

directions.ingredients: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled glass

description: Nothing goes better with Vermouth than fruit, as is seen with Django Reinhardt. Created by San Diago bartender Erick Castro from Polite Provisions, this is a cocktail that blends Dry Vermouth, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and some muddled Orange slices.

directions.instructions: Combine Vermouth, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup in an ice-filled shaker and then strain over ice

description: There is no drink that could sound better right now, than the Feel-Good hit Of The Summer. Created by New York gastropub Moonrise Izakaya, this drink is a wonderful mix of White Rum, Cognac, Pineapple Juice, Orange Juice, Coconut Cream & Water.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients and mix well. Pour into an ice cube tray and freeze for 3-4 hours. Remove ice cubes from tray and blend at high speed until pourable

description: Created by Dale “King Cocktail” DeGroff, the Irish Blonde is a boozy but bright Irish Whiskey cocktail that mixes in Dry Orange Curaçoa, Fino Sherry and a dash of Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled glass

description: While this Daiquiri variation is called the Winter Daiquiri, don’t let the name fool you. This drink is equally at home poolside as it is fireside. The duo of Rums makes this cocktail more complex, with Banks 5 Island Rum adding depth and Black Strap Rum adding notes of molasses, coffee, and cloves.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled glass

description: There’s no better way to celebrate Easter than with the Easter Cocktail. Created by Simon King at the MJU bar in the Millenium Hotel in London, the Vanilla Vodka in this drink really lifts the Crème de Cacao, while the Cardamom adds a little sweet spice to the mix.

directions.instructions: Muddle cardamom pods in the base of a shaker. Add all other ingredients and shake with ice. Fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Simon Difford has adapted this recipe to add 0.5oz of Egg White with an additional dry shake

description: When you get a mix of Bourbon, Coconut Liqueur, Grape Juice, toasted Coconut Syrup, Lemon Juice and black food jell together, for a drink that is carbonated for a tropical soda feel, then you know some sort of shape-shifting Trickster must be involved.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients, then carbonate and serve
directions.garnish: For carbonation – if you are making this at home, the easiest way to carbonate the drink is to get the mixed drink as cold as possible before funnelling it into a siphon or whipper. (if using a siphon, remove the tube from the seal ring when closing the top and always adhere to the maximum fill volume). Charge the siphon with a carbon dioxide bulb. Shake, then store in the fridge for a minimum of two hours (longer if possible). With the canister upright, slowly release the pressure by pressing the lever down (a little at a time over half an hour, storing in the fridge between each release, once there is little pressure left, carefully open the top and serve.

description: Who needs Vodka when you can create an Espresso Martini-style cocktail with Tequila. 1800 Tequila have created a Tequila Coffee that incorporates Tequila, Coffee Liqueur, Créme de Cacao, Cold Drip Coffee and a little Pedro Ximenez Sherry.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients, minus cream, to a mixing glass filled with ice. Stir down until diluted and chilled. Single strain into a chilled coupe glass. Using a ‘sauce’ bottle float cream on top of the drink
directions.garnish: Vanilla Cream – Add thickened cream, sugar cubes, and vanilla extract to a small sauce bottle and shake for around 30 seconds until light and fluffy

description: Tatanka is the Native American word for buffalo which of course refers to the Bison Grass Vodka used in this drink. Reminiscent of Earl Grey Tea, the Tatanka is perfectly balanced with the addition of Apple Juice and a dash of Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description:
If you’ve never had a Haitian Rum cocktail before, then Maiden Voyage is aptly named. So, crack open the Rhum Barbancourt and mix in a little of the wine-based Aperitif, Cardamaro, before adding Lemon Juice, Maple Syrups and a dash or two of Peychard’s Bitters.
“Although she couldn’t deny that she loved the cocktails she ot to try at events like New Orleans Cocktail Week, sometimes the more cultural aspects of a city, like its music, were for Vanessa, the real highlight.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then fine strain into a chilled coupe

description: You can’t get a better cabin fever cure than the Cabin Fever Cure Flip. If the general creaminess added to two different types of rum and the sweet spice of Benedictine of this drink doesn’t stop you from climbing the walls, then nothing will …

directions.instructions: Dry shake all ingredients until the egg and cream are emulsified, then add ice and shake again to chill, then strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

description: The Fourth Regiment is a Manhattan riff that uses a trifecta of bitters, in addition to the Rye and Sweet Vermouth, to propel itself to the next level. The Orange Bitters adds a citrusy zing, the Angostura Bitters adds a wonderful spice, and the Celery Bitters adds a nice savoury element, that makes this drink unique.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir. Strain into a chilled Coupe glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: First printed in Charles H. Baker’s 1939 book, The Gentlemen’s Companion

description: It’s said that the Seapea Fizz is named for song writer and composer Cole Porter (the sound of the name mimicking Porter’s initials, C.P.). The pale green cocktail is a simple—yet bracing—mix of sugar, lemon and absinthe, but this somewhat astringent mixture is not to everyone’s taste.

directions.ingredients:
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry shake. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
Strain into a coupe and top with soda water.
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: The cocktail first appears in Frank Meier’s The Artistry of Mixing Drinks from 1934

description: As one of the world’s best selling spirit, Gin really does serve a crown, but for the moment it has a cocktail. Created by Jonathan Lind, the Gin Crown mixes Gin with its older cousin Genever with a little Walnut Liqueur and a good dose of Ginger Beer.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients except the ginger beer in a shaker with ice and shake to chill. Strain into a Collins glass over a large ice spear. Top with ginger beer

description: Created by St Germain global ambassador, Camille Ralph, the Cyn Cyn is a lighter, more delicate riff on the Negroni. The combination of Cynar, and St Germain is harmonised beautifully with the Dry Vermouth to really bring out the floral elements.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice filled mixing glass. Stir and then stir into a chilled Coupe glass.

description: A reinvention of the classic Old Fashioned, the Slane Fashioned is created with flavours that highlight their signature triple casked process. With Slane Irish Whiskey, Oloroso Sherry, Demerara Syrup, Angostura Bitters and Barrel-Aged Bitters, this is an Old Fashioned with an Irish lilt.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass. Stir with ice. Strain over a single large ice cube in a rocks glass.

description: The Drinkaterium is a beautiful Gin based cocktail that is a distinctive blend of aniseed flavour from the Wild Fennel and Citrus with the Lemony flavour of the Spekboom.  If Spekboom is too hard to find, the Lychee Spekboom Syrup can be subbed for a Lychee Lemon Syrup.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a Collins glass

description: A bit of a margarita variation, the El Jerez mixes Tequila, Fino Sherry, Grapefruit Juice, Lime Juice & Agave Syrup. The fino sherry lengthens the drink and tones down the citrus and tequila a bit while keeping up the acidity.

directions.instruction: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass

description: If you like a Rusty Nail Cocktail, then the Very Rusty Daiquiri might be just up your alley. With smooth Caribbean Rum mixed with the spiced Whisky-flavour of Drambuie, this is a cocktail that is both rich and satisfying.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients very well with ice and double strain through a fine mesh tea strainer into a chilled martini glass.

description: The combination of beer and berry flavours never hurt anyone and once you add a little whiskey, this is the perfect barbecue cocktail. In fact to not make it this weekend, might be thought by some to be Beyond The Pale.

directions.instructions: Add Syrup and Whiskey into a chilled glass and stir. Add the blackberries, bruise them with the back of a spoon and stir again. Top with Pale Ale.

description: Named of course after the 1930s fictional pilot and adventurer, the Biggles Sidecar is basically a ginger flavoured riff on the classic Sidecar cocktail. With Cognac, Ginger Liqueur, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup & Peychaud’s Bitters, this is one drink that will have you repeatedly landing back at the bar.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Like a Gingersnap Cookie but in liquid form, the Gingersnap Cocktail is a wonderful evening sipper. With Amaretto, Amaro Di Angostura, Scotch, Ginger Liqueur & Lemon Juice, this drink is smooth, spicy and an all-round crowd pleaser.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice. Stir until chilled and strain into a Cocktail coupe.

description: Created by Patrice Plante from Canada for Campari’s Red Diaries (2017) campaign, the Alpha is as rich in colour as it is in flavour. With muddled Raspberries, Campari, Blanco Tequila, Agave Syrup, Lemon Juice and a dash of Orgeat, this is a truly transglobal drink.

directions.instructions: Muddle Raspberries in the base of a shaker, then add all other ingredients. Shake with ice, then fine strain into a chilled glass

description: The Ruby Negroni could best be described as a great starter Negroni. If you find the bitterness of Campari & Gin a little too much, then this drink allows you to sweeten up the mix with the addition of a little Raspberry Syrup, Port, & Prosecco.

directions.instructions: Add Gin, Campari, Port and Syrup to an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir well and strain into a Champagne flute, then top with Prosecco

description: Ideal for sitting on the porch on a hot summer day, a Sweet Tea Bourbon is a perfect pitcher cocktail. With muddled Mint and Orange slices, this cocktail also combines Black Tea, Agave & Bourbon, for a relaxing libation.

For those moments when you need a little bubble and glam, there is no more accessible drink than the Glitterati. With Don Julio’s Rosado, grapefruit and lime juices and agave syrup, the bold colour is met with a tingling effervescence from the sparkling Rosé

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a coupe glass. Top with sparkling rosé

description: Originally created at Bar Opiume in Singapore, the Crossbow cocktail is sophisticatedly dry. With Cointreau and Crème de Cacao, the drink has a wonderful chocolate orange taste laced with gin.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Created in 2015 by Scott Burgess at Some Place in Liverpool (UK), Le Chateau has a distinctly European vibe. Served straight up,  this cocktail uses Cognac as the base, adding herbal Benedictine and bittersweet Aperol as the supporting liqueurs.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled glass.

description: No matter whether it’s an election year or not, there is no better aperitivo to drink than a Mount Rushmore. Created by Patrick Pistolesi at Drink Kong in Rome, this cocktail has Bourbon, Montenegro, Fino sherry and a splash of Coffee Liqueur that make it an interesting alternative to a Boulevardier.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into an ice-filled rock glass

description: While you could think of Fancy Free as simply a riff on a Whiskey Old Fashioned, where the Maraschino takes the place of sugar, there is much more to this drink than that. Surprisingly dry, the mix of Bourbon & Maraschino is made all the more aromatic with both Angostura & Orange Bitters.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: The Cheshire Cat is certainly a cocktail that will put a big grin on your face. A twist on the classic Vieux Carre Cocktail, this substitutes Scotch for Rye Whiskey and Cherry Heering for Sweet Vermouth and it’s all balanced with a nice dose of Punt E Mez.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass, then strain into an ice filled glass
directions.garnish: Lemon zest twist around Rosemary sprig & Cinnamon stick

description: In Poland, Bison Grass Vodka and Apple Juice are a classic combination and when you add an equal part of Honey Liqueur, well, then, you have a Martini like no other.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Dick Bradsell created this drink for his Polish father-in-law, Victor Sarge.

description:
The Maple Leaf cocktail is a simple, reasonably mellow, yet moreish riff on a Whiskey Sour with a silky Bourbon and tart Lemon Juice, both of which are sweetened with a thinned Maple Syrup.
“While Vanessa often found it easy to set hearts on fire, building a simple camp fire had proved a smidge more difficult. Luckily Juan had been able to throw together a Whiskey Sour riff with hints of caramel that seemed perfect for the occasion. While the night air was still a little warm, this drink was a reminder that this would be their last summer break, with more autumnal weather was soon to come.”

directions.instructions: Combine­ all of the ingredients­ in ­a ­shaker­ and­ fill ­with ­ice. ­Shake ­to chill,­ strain­ in to ­a­ chilled ­glass­

description: Suze has often been associated with artists, so it’s no surprise then that Maggie Eckl at Dead Rabbit named this drink, The Artist’s Muse when she created it in 2016. Bittersweet and fruity, this cocktail has Pisco, Suze, Crème de Pêche, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and Egg White.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain back onto the shaker. Then dry shake and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass

description: Interestingly, the Torpedo Blu is named after a 1960s Italian song. That aside though, it has a nice mix of  Tequila, Chambord Liqueur, Simple Syrup, Lime Juice & Elderflower Tonic. With such a combination, this is a drink that will take you on a journey from Mexico to the Italian Alps.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients (except Tonic Water) into a shaker. Shake well and strain into a highball glass full of ice. Top with Tonic water
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Paolo Sanna from the Banana Republic bar in Rome

description: This pandemic has given tequila lovers the opportunity to experiment at home, and home is the exact inspiration for Homespun. I love low prep and replicable drinks that everyone can enjoy and taking everyday ingredients out of my own pantry was an authentic way to make that happen – Bec Bailey – Cielo Rooftop – Brisbane

directions.instructions:
Add all ingredients except the powdered sugar go into a shaker. Stir ingredients briefly to agitate the marmalade into the mix.
Shake hard and fast and double strain into a nick & nora. Garnish with powdered sugar dusting.

description: Created by the late Sasha Petraske at his famous Milk & Honey, the Apple Jack is obviously, rich in apple flavour. As the name suggests, the drink is a sweet and sour mix of Applejack Brandy, Apple Juice, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and finest strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: When creating this drink, Sasha Petraske was inspired by the Apple Jack Rabbit in The Savoy Cocktail Book

description: Sometimes referred to as an Alpine Spritz (due to the inclusion of Elderflower), the Hugo Spritz is a palate-pleasing Italian Aperitif Spritz. Refreshing and light, the combination of Elderflower Syrup, Mint & Prosecco make this an ideal cocktail for the summer months.

directions.instructions: Muddle the Mint and add the Elderflower Syrup the Prosecco and Soda Water. Stir, then add ice.
directions.garnish: Mint leaf and slice of Lemon.

description: Utilising Tequila Don Julio Rosado, a silky-smooth tequila finished in Ruby Port Wine Casks as a base, the Rosado Spritz is the perfect Paloma riff to sip in the sun by the pool.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a coupe glass with cubed ice. Top with Sparkling Grapefruit Soda

description: Whiskey and Sake come together with Ginger Liqueur to create this ode to the Manhattan, the Manhattan Love Story. Sake takes on the modifier role (typically played by Vermouth in a Manhattan) and the ginger liqueur gives it a sweet and spicy undertone.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled mixing glass. Stir well, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: Gary Regan, in his book Joy of Mixology, adapted the original 1930s recipe by substituting Amaretto for Crème de Noyau and dropped the Orange Bitters. He, of course, tweaked with the ratios a bit but thankfully kept the Gin, lemon Juice and Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: Lighter and zestier in flavour than the original Paloma, the Swedish Paloma is a riff that swaps out tequila for Grapefruit Vodka. To that is added Grapefruit Juice, Lime Juice, Simple Syrup and Soda Water.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients (except Soda Water) with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass. Top with Soda Water

description: Doomed to sail the seven seas forever but unable to make port, The Flying Dutchman is a legendary ghost ship. In liquid form, she mixes Gin, Green Melon Cordial, Green Apple Juice, Lemon Juice and, of course, a dash of saline solution. If seen on the ocean, she is a portent of doom. Seen in a glass, she’s topped with Prosecco, dill oil and a sprig of dill and far less ominous.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker tin and fine-strain into a Nick & Nora
directions.garnish: 3 dots of dill oil and a sprig of dill

description: Believed to be one of the best of today’s Sherry cocktails, Remember The Alimony, is a wonderful slow sipper. In addition to the Sherry, the drink combines Cynar & Gin for a wonderful cocktail that will definitely become a modern classic.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients except the orange twist in a rocks glass filled with one large piece of ice. Stir until chilled, about 30 seconds.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Dan Greenbaum in 2012 at the short-lived NYC bar, The Beagle.

description: Mixing fresh cucumber and gin with the herbaceous flavour of Green Chartreuse will result in a Lone Palm. This drink is vibrant and ultra-refreshing, created by Diego Valencia at ARCA in Tulum.

directions.instructions: In a shaker, muddle the cucumber with the simple syrup and lime juice. Add the gin, green Chartreuse and ice. Shake until chilled, then strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

description: When a cocktail has the name Cognac, we all know what the dominant spirit will be but what you may not have guessed is the South African liqueur that it mixes so well with. Van Der Hum is a Tangerine Liqueur, so it’s complex citrus flavours play beautifully with Cognac & St Germain.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a coupe glass
directions.garnish: Vanilaa & Lemon Icing Sugar Rim & a dehydrated Orange slice

description: As the name suggests, the Negroni Bianca Bergamotto is a Bianco Negroni with added bergamot citrus complexity. With Gin, Bitter Bianco Liqueur, Italicus and Bianco Vermouth, this drink was developed to help promote Italicus when it launched.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled glass and stir

description: How could we resist combining two of the world’s greatest loves – Gin & Coffee? With Coffee Liqueur, Gin & Tonic Water, the Turbo G&T will definitely get your night (or day for that matter) started right.

directions.instructions: Pour the gin over ice into a Collins glass. Add the cold brew Coffee Liqueur, then top up with tonic water.

description: Bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler of Portland’s Clyde Common created this extravagant twist on a whiskey sour. With Marmalade as the star, it mixes beautifully with Bourbon, Lemon Juice and Egg White.

directions.instructions: Combine bourbon, juice, syrup, marmalade, and egg white in a shaker filled with ice and shake. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. Add bitters, and using a toothpick, swirl into whites.

description: Although Toronto is a Manhattan riff, it gets its name from the use of Whisky from north of the border. Although the Canadian Whisky is there to tame the bitter bite of the Fernet Branca, it joins Sugar Syrup & Angostura Bitters for a drink that’s rich and bitter.

directions.instructions: Orange peel
directions.garnish: The Toronto appeared in David A. Embury’s Fine Art Of Mixing Drinks, 1948 in which it was mentioned that it could also be served in an Old Fashioned glass.

description:
If you are after a tropical cocktail that doesn’t get too sweet, then the robust How To Kill A Friend is an option that you may not have considered. Similar to the classic Jungle Bird, this drink includes Mezcal, Campari, PX Sherry, Triple Sec, as well as Pineapple and Lime Juices.
“Like so many women before her, Vanessa couldn’t resist a soft opening. And while the night had gone off without a hitch, the early morning found her outside, sitting on the curb with a cocktail in hand. While she loved her friends, there were times when their insistence that they were, in fact, true Mezcal connoisseurs, made her contemplate how simple it would be to find a whole new use for a ice mallet.”

directions.instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker tin with ice and shake to chill. Strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice

description: A wonderfully light and tempting drink, the Hotel Georgia was named after the hotel of the same name in Vancouver which opened in 1927. The drink itself is assumed to be dated from two decades later in the 1940s and combines Gin, Orgeat, Lemon Juice, Orange Flower Water & Egg White.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain back into the shaker. Dry shake (without ice) and fine strained into chilled glass.

description: If you are in a bit of a jam with the flavour of your cocktails, might we suggest a Blueberry Jam & Prosecco Cocktail? Luckily, not as sweet as it sounds, this drink has a nice tart edge thanks to the Blueberries, Lemon Juice and dry Prosecco.

directions.instructions: In a cocktail shaker combine Jam, Lemon Juice & Vodka with ice. Shake vigorously and strain into an ice-filled Rocks glass, then top with Prosecco.

description: Created at Cape Town’s The Queen’s, yet named, of course, for the region where the main spirit, Glenfiddich Whisky, is from, the Speyside is as gentle and fruity as its namesake with Honey Syrup and Peach Bitters

directions.instructions: Muddle half a Granny Smith apple in a shaker, then add the rest of the ingredients. Shake and then fine strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.garnish: Grated nutmeg, apple fan and edible flowers

description: Created in 2003, by Murray Stenson at the. Zig Zag Café in Seattle, the Chas has a wonderful tang. With great Bourbon personality, the drink is uplifted with hints of Almond and Orange.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: An Amaro twist on the classic Margarita, the Monterita is a wonderful bittersweet drink that replaces Cointreau with Montenegro Amaro. Add to that a little Lime Juice Juice and Agave Syrup and you have a citrusy Italian riff.

directions.ingredients: Shake all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker and strain into a chilled glass

description: For an Absinthe tipple that contains serious magic, you can’t go past the Necromancer. The Absinthe & Lillet Blanc are brightened up by St Germain and a dash of Gin. A riff on the even more classic Corpse Reviver, this cocktail casts a spell of its own on all who drink it.

It’s as if Fernet Branca and Cold Brew Coffee were made for each other and they play delightfully in the Light Flight Cocktail. They seem to be having so much fun, that floral St Germain joins them, as does a good dose of Tonic.

directions.instructions: Add Cold Brew, Fernet Branca & St Germain to an ice-filled Collins glass. Lightly stir, then top with Tonic Water

description: Created by Jess Yurko from the Queensyard in New York, Migratory Coconuts is definitely a baller of a rum Cocktail. With White Rum, Coconut Syrup, Lime Juice and garnished with Hibiscus Ice, this is one drink you want in your hand for a New York summer.

directions.instructions: In a shaking tin, combine Rum, coconut Syrup, lime juice and mint leaves, shake with ice to chill, strain into a glass through a fine strainer. Top with Topo Chico (or any good quality club soda or soda water)
directions.garnish:
Coconut Syrup
32 oz coconut water
24 oz white sugar
Combine ingredients in a pot, bring to a boil and whisk. Cool, then store.
directions.more_about_this_drink:
Hibiscus Ice
1/2 oz Dried Hibiscus Flowers
32 oz Water
Bring water to a boil, steep dried hibiscus in water for 15 minutes. Strain the hibiscus flowers out of the tea, pour into ice molds, and freeze.

description: A favourite for prohibition drinkers, the Chrysanthemum is a complex, zesty and potent drink that shows Vermouth off beautifully. With a little Benedictine and Absinthe added to the mix, this is definitely a drink that has stood the test of time.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in an ice filled mixing glass. Stir and then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: In this 1930s The Savoy Cocktail Book, Harry Craddock wrote “Well known and very popular in the American Bar of the S.S. Europa”. (Europa was a passenger liner than travelled between Germany & New York)

description:
One of the most visually impressive classic cocktails, the Ramos Gin Fizz is all about the dry shake and the extended shaking required to achieve the towering soufflé. While the ingredients may look simple, this drink is a bit of a workout but well worth the effort.
“Taking in the best of New Orleans Cocktail Week, had lead Vanessa to the iconic Bourbon Street. After popping onto a few bars, she decided to do the most touristy thing she could by ordering the most iconic classic the city had to offer. Luckily, she eventually found a bartender athletic enough to bring her request satifacturally to a head.”

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients except for soda to a cocktail shaker. Shake for as long as you can without ice (at least two or three minutes). Add ice and shake until well chilled. Strain into a Collins glass, adding the soda water at the same time.

description: Nothing is better at the end of a long day than the wonderful combination of flavours that is found in the Susquehanna Cocktail. The spice of the Rye cuts perfectly through the sweet almond flavour of the Amaretto for a drink that will certainly make your day.

directions.instructions: In a mixing glass with ice, combine Rye, Amaretto, and Angostura Bitters. Stir well, until well-chilled and strain into a Rocks glass with fresh ice.

description: If you’re after an “extra dirty” Martini but with a touch of spice, then the Salt & Pepper Martini, created by Michael McIlroy at Temple Bar in NYC, is your answer. The Celery Bitters, Manzanilla Sherry and Saline Solution add that dirty element, while the Liqueur and pepper garnish add the spice.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir to combine. Strain into a coupe.

description: If you are after a cocktail that is well balanced with a rich fruity flavour, then you can’t go past the Godfrey. With Blackberries, Cognac, Grand Marnier, Crème De Mûre, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup, this is an ideal drink for humid summer days.

directions.instructions: Muddle Blackberries in the base of a shaker, then add all other ingredients. Shake with ice, then fine strain into a glass with crushed ice.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Salvatore Calabrese at the Library Bar, Lanesborough Hotel, London

description: A refreshing, summery twist on the classic, the French Negroni cocktail will have you instructing the cabana boy to keep them coming. An equal parts drink like its name-sake, the cocktail mixes Pampelle, Gin & Vermouth Blanc – trés delicious!

directions.instructions: Pour each of the ingredients into an ice filled rocks glass, then stir

description:
While you might think of the Paloma as the ultimate Tequila cocktail, swap that out for Mezcal and add a little IPA beer and you’ve got a cocktail that enhances the original in the most delightful way.
“Although Vanessa had been determined to spend the day sight seeing in Singapore, by late afternoon she found herself seeing the city from a barstool. But as afternoon melted into night, she came to the realisation that the best way to get to know a city is to drink with the locals.”

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with 2 ice cubes and whip. Pour into an ice-filled, salt rimmed glass
