description: Fruity and incredibly accessible, this is one of those cocktails that everybody likes. With Vodka, Raspberries, Lillet Rose offset by citrus and Peychard’s Bitters this is one cocktail that is eminently quaffable.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker then fine strain into a Collins glass with ice

description: Created by Matt Tocco at Strategic Hospitality in Nashville, the Byrrh de Garde is a shaken, somewhat fruity/somewhat bitter highball cocktail that’s between a Whiskey Sour and a Byrrh Cassis.

directions.instructions: Shake the Bourbon, Byrrh, Grenadine and Lemon Juice in an ice-filled shaker, then top with Soda Water

description: Created at the former Brilliantshine in Santa Monica, Fly By Night is anything but. With an harmonious mix of Scotch and Ginger, this drink is boosted by the addition of both Angostura and Paychard’s Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a glass with one large ice cube and stir

description: The Marigold Spritz is an easy to drink cocktail with a Tequila base. It utilises the delicate quinine bitterness that you normally find in Tonic Water and balances it beautifully with the sweetness of the Peach Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in an ice-filled glass and lightly stir.

description: Adapted from a recipe in W.J. Tarling’s 1937 Café Royal Cocktail Book, the San Francisco is wonderful spiritous, fruity and aromatic. With Sloe Gin, Dry Vermouth, Sweet Vermouth, as well as Orange & Angostura Bitters, this has a lovely complexity that will make it one of your favourites.

directions.instructions: Stior all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Created by David Wondrich, the name Sourise is a play on the French word for smile. Embodying one of the best threesomes on the bar, the Almond, Cognac & Raspberry will certainly give you something to smile about.

directions.instructions: Dry shake all ingredients before shaking again with ice. Then fine strain into a chilled glass

description: There is nothing quite as interesting as the taste of Tequila when it’s laced with Maraschino Liqueur. If you then add some sour Grapefruit and Dry Sherry to balance everything else, well then you have The Marguerite.

directions.instructions: Shake first four ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass, then top with Soda

description: Baijiu is one of the most consumed spirits in the world, so why not explore it through a variation of one of the world’s favourite cocktails, the Hong Kong Margarita. With Baijiu, Lime Juice, Agave Syrup, Jalapeño, Cucumber & Mint, this is a perfect introductory drink to this popular spirit.

directions.instructions: Muddle Japapeños, Cucumber & Mint leaves in the base of a shaker tin, add the rest of the ingredients and fill with ice. Shake and strain into an ice-filled Rocks glass.

description: While more modern recipes for the Bamboo cocktail call for equal part measurements, this 2 to 1 ratio is thought to be the original recipe. With Fino Sherry, Sweet Vermouth and Orange Bitters, this drink is balanced and complex.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and then strain into a chilled Nick & Nora

description: If you love a good classic Italian dessert, then the Tiramisu Cocktail with Espresso, Marsala and two types of liqueur may just be the perfect (although decadent) cocktail for you.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then double strain into a chilled glass

description: If you need to rise again then there’s no better way to do than with the Lazarus. A flavoursome combination of spirit and coffee, the drink mixes Vodka, Cognac, Coffee Liqueur and Espresso Coffee.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass

description: Creating a beautiful balance that allows the cherry flavour to shine through, the Vanderbilt is as rich in as its namesakes. Combining Cherry Heering, Cognac, Sugar Syrup & Angostura bitters, this drink has been adapted from Harry Craddock’s 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a cocktail glass

description: If you’re going to go no-alc, then darling … you’d better go pretty. And that is exactly what you’ll get with the Watermelon Sour, which mixes Seedlip Garden with the rich colour of a Watermelon and Basil Shrub , with a little eggwhite for froth.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker and strain into a chilled coupe
directions.garnish:
Watermelon-Basil Shrub – Remove the rind of 300g watermelon, deseed and roughly dice, and place into a glass jar. Lightly crush to extract the juices. Mix in 125g Caster sugar until the fruit is totally covered. Stir to evenly distribute the sugar. Close the jar with the lid and allow to macerate in the refrigerator for 24 hours. After macerating, add 100ml White vinegar and 20 Basil leaves, and stir, allowing to infuse for a further 24 hours. Pass the syrup through a fine sieve into a sterilized jar, separating the liquid from the solids.
Keep refrigerated and enjoy within a week.

description:
“Salvatore Calabrese’s Breakfast Martini was inspired by his toast and marmalade in the morning, as was this version, which adds egg white for texture and good health.” – Jim Meehan
Images – AJ Meeker

directions.instructions: Measure into a cocktail shaker and shake without ice. Add ice cubes, then shake and strain into a chilled coupe.

description: Created in 2009 by Jeremy James Thompson at Reines Law Rooms in New Yor, Ragtime cocktail is a bittersweet delight. Originally made with Rittenhouse Bonded Rye, this drink blends Ramazzotti Amaro, Aperol, Peychaud’s Bitters & an Absinthe rinse.

directions.instructions: Rinse the mixing g;ass with Absinthe. Stir the rest of the ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: Adapted from a recipe by Danny Gil at Weather Up NYC, the Roman Highball is a refreshing Pimm’s Cup-like drink. With Averna, Ginger Liqueur, Lime Juice & Soda, this is the perfect long drink top have at the end of an even longer day.

directions.instructions: Shake first three ingredients with ice and fine strain into an ice-filled glass. Top with Soda Water

description: Adapted from the recipe in David Embury’s The Fine Art Of Mixing, The Rose #1, was created in the 1920s. Mixing Dry Vermouth, Kirsch Liqueur & Raspberry Liqueur this drink is a wonderful dusky pink with a wonderful aroma.

directions.instructions: Stir ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: While Lime Juice is a mainstay of the original Cosmopolitan, the California Cosmopolitan replaces it with Lemon Juice to add a stronger, more prominent tartness and a bolder, more citrusy flavour.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: If you are after a spicy, rich and bittersweet variation on a Negroni then the apple brandy–based cocktail, Mela d’Alba (or Apple Brandy negroni is for you. Now the trick with this, is to use Bonded Apple Brandy, not just Applejack, ’cause you want the strong stuff.

directions.instructions: Add apple brandy, sweet vermouth, and Campari to an ice-filled Old Fashioned glass. Stir until well chilled, about 15 seconds.
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created by Andrew Friedman of Liberty Bar in Seattle

description: If you’re after a whiskey spin on a Bee’s Knees, then a Gold Rush Cocktail is definitely the drink for you. Added to the Whiskey, there is some Lemon Juice & HoneySyrup, which makes this modern day cocktail feel just like a 19th Century classic.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into an ice-filled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: First made in 2001 by Sasha Petraske at Milk & Honey in New York

description: A riff on the Hummingbird Down, the Rye Hummingbird Down was created by Marcos Tello. A complex sour that has a little fruity spice from the Rye Whiskey, a touch of sweet floral from Honey Syrup, a good burst of citrus from the Lemon Juice, which is all brought together and balanced by a tinge of herbal notes from the Green Chartreuse.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain onto a chilled coupe

description: Using the classic Sour formula that dates back to the 19th Century, the Gin Sour mixes a Spirit (in this case, Gin), with a Sour (in this case, Lemon Juice) and a sweetener (in this case, Elderflower Syrup) for a classic Spring cocktail that genuinely can’t be beat.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry shake, then add ice and hard shake. Stain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description: If you thought making a Negroni was simple, we’ll do you one better with the Wild Rosé Negroni. Using only two ingredients, this Negroni riff mixes Hickson Rd Summer Cup (which is in effect, a combination of the Gin and the Vermouth) with the expected Campari.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain over a large ice cube in a rocks glass

description: Although its origins are unknown, what we do about the Barbary Coast is that it is a Prohibition-era drink. Mixing Scotch, Gin, Crème de Cacao & Cream, this drink takes its name from the nine-block area in San Francisco that was a red-light district frequented by sailors in the mid-19th to early 20th centuries.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker then strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: The drink appears in The Savoy Cocktail Book but there it is served in a highball glass with cracked ice.

description: If you want to up the fruitiness of your Margarita, there is no better way to do it than with a Strawberry Basil Margarita. Let your frustrations melt away as you muddle a few Strawberries and Basil in the base of a cocktail shaker before adding Tequila, Cointreau and Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Muddle fruit and basil in shaker, add ingredients and ice. Shake well and fine strain into salt-rimmed rocks glass with ice.
directions.garnish: Half a Strawberry and a Basil leaf
directions.more_about_this_drink: This recipe comes via cointreau.com

description: A riff on Brazil’s national drink, the Gin Caipirinha obviously swaps out Cachaça for Gin and sugar for honey but at least keeps in the lovely Limes.

directions.instructions: Combine lime wedges and honey in an empty rocks glass and muddle. Fill the glass with ice and add the gin. Transfer contents into a shaker and shake before pouring back into the original rocks glass.

description: The Death Star may have been the Empire’s ultimate weapon but when it’s in Cocktail form, it’s the ultimate drink. It won’t destroy planets, but with Strega, Pisco, Cynar & Grapefruit Bitters, this is a boozy equal parts cocktail could take you to a  galaxy far, far away.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass

description:
If you’ve ever wondered what the contents of a witch’s cauldron might look like, then The Witches Brew provides an answer. Providing a stunning blue colour through the Blue Curacao, this Vodka-based drink adds Pineapple Juice and Grenadine.
“Always one to be in the right place at the right time, Vanessa grabbed a Halloween cocktail as the bar she had randomly dropped into decided to throw an impromtu after-hours Halloween bash. As she looked around the eclectic crowd, she took a sip of the blue concoction in her hand and quickly realised there’s a little witch in all of us.”

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled Martini glass

description: You might imagine that a cocktail called the Devil’s Own would be dark and somewhat depressing but in fact, it’s light and extremely refreshing. Created by Colin Symons in the UK in the 1930’s the drinks has Cointreau, Gin, Dry Vermouth & Aromatic Bitters.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir well and strain into a Coupe glass.

description: If you are after a light, refreshing, long drink, then there is no better pairing in the cocktail world than Gin, Cucumber & St Germain. Created by Anthony Street at The Everleigh in Melbourne Australia, the Easy Street cocktail is definitely poolside worthy.

directions.instruction: Muddle cucumber in the base of a shaker, then add Gin, St Germain, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup and shake. Strain into a chilled glass and top with Soda Water

description: Interweaving the fruity sweetness and tart of Cherry Heering liqueur with the strong herbal notes of Green Chartreuse, the Campbeltown has a backbone of Scotch, which adds a well-balanced depth and richness.

directions.instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, express the oil of a lemon peel, and discard the peel.

description:
Slightly sweet with a touch of bitterness and a hint of citrus, the Princeton is a classic drink that dates back to the early 20th century. Named after the Ivy League school, this is a drink that, due to the Port float, has a rich, velvety finish.
“With the festive season coming up, Vanessa thought it was financially wise to extend her time behind the stick and pick up shifts where she could. Just her luck that tonight was an event for leering Ivy League alums who, while being impressed by her skills, were ever curious about the nature of her ‘real job’.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a chilled coupe

description: Perfect for a summer day, the Hong Kong Mule is the perfect way to utilise the strong aromatic and fruity flavours of the Chinese spirit, Baijiu. Combined with Lime Juice and Ginger Beer, this is refreshing and light.

directions.instructions: Squeeze lime juice into a Collins glass (or Moscow Mule mug), then add ice, Pouring in the Baijiu and top with cold Ginger Beer

description:
Gathering fall favourites of apple and cinnamon mixed with the deep autumnal flavours of Cognac, make The Harvest a winner if you are trying to put yourself in the mood for fall.
“Although normally known for her gregarious nature, Vanessa was finding conversation with the Ranger a little stilted. Having exhausted the variety of birds that he and Juan (her faithful PA) had seen that day, Vanessa found that not even the tasty Cognac cocktail was doing much to break the awkward silences.”

directions.instructions: Shake into an ice-filled shaker before straining into a coupe glass

description: Creating a link to one of Cause & Effects’ four main pillars, the ocean, Whale of A Time shakes up Gin, Tequila and Blue Curaçao for a bright, refreshing drink that is reminiscent in tone to a Margarita.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients and fine strain into a rocks glass

description: Created at The House Of Machines in Cape Town, the SmokeRoni is an Agave Negroni riff that really brings the smoke to the glass. Combining Montelobos Mezcal, Tequila, Sweet Vermouth & Campari this is a drink that captures the depth that you’ve been missing

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain over large ice

description: If Bourbon with a hint of Elderflower, Cloves and Lime, is a taste that you crave then the Ninth Ward is well worth exploring. Paying homage to the New Orleans neighbourhoods hit hardest by Katrina, as well as being play on the Ward Eight, this is a drink that definitely grows on you.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Brother Cleve for Tales Of The Cocktail in 2008

description: How do you make a Daiquiri variation more fun? Well by add Lychees of course. The BGL is a wonderful mix of Basil, Ginger Liqueur & Lychees added to a base of Golden Rum, Lime Juice & Sugar Syrup, for a spicy rethink of a classic.

directions.instructions: Muddle Lychees & Basil with Lime Juice in the base of a shaker. Add the rest of the ingredients and shake. Fine strain into an ice-filled Old Fashioned glass

description: While a Mint Julep can be wonderful on its own, adding a little tartness to the mix can really take this cocktail up a level. The Passionfruit Julep takes the basics of the classic with Bourbon, Mint & Sugar Syrup and adds Passionfruit pulp to truly enliven a lazy, summer afternoon.

directions.instructions: In a Rocks glass, gently muddle the Mint leaves with Simple Syrup and then add Passionfruit pulp. Pack the glass with finely crushed ice. Pour bourbon over ice, and mound more ice into the top of the glass.

description: Dominated by the sweet and spice finish of Toki Whisky, the Zamazaki is wonderfully bright with strong citrus notes. The drink was named after Japan’s first commercial distillery, opened by Suntory in 1923.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to shaker tin and reverse shake, add ice, shake again and strain into a coupe glass

description: If you like drinks that have ingredients that don’t seem like they would go together then The Last Mechanical Art is well worth trying. The dark, deep cocktail combines the bold flavours of Mezcal, Cynar, Punt e Mes & Campari

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into a chilled coupe
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Maks Pazuniak and published in beta Cocktails, when both he and Kirk Estopinal were working at Cure in New Orleans back in 2011.

description: If you’ve been thinking that your Bee’s Knees is lacking a little spice, then making a Bee Sting will have the impact you’ve been craving. With Ancho Reyes added to the Gin, Lemon Juice and Honey Syrup, you’ll certainly get a buzz out of this drink.

directions.instructions: Chill a cocktail glass. In a shaker, combine all ingredients with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into an ice filled glass.

description: If you find Rye a little overwhelming, then why not tame it just a little by making a Phish Hook cocktail. With an enchanting mix of Rye, St Germain, Punt E Mes & Maraschino Liqueur, this is a variation on the Red Hook.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a glass

description: Created by Kaleb Cribb at Holeman and Finch in Atlanta, Mad Man is the perfect Bourbon cocktail to sip. Combining two kinds of bitters, this drink adds a touch of sweetness with cinnamon-agave syrup.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain into a cocktail glass

description: The Old Elk Buck proves itself to be a genuinely versatile cocktail that is not only refreshing but also comes with an added Ginger kick. With Bourbon, Lemon Juice, and Angostura Bitters also added to the mix, this drink is a super easy drink that never disappoints.

directions.instructions: Shake the first three ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled highball glass. Add Soda Soda Water to top
directions.garnish: Add a layer of Angostura Bitters, then further garnish with a Lemon wheel and a Mint Sprig.

description: With a garden-to-glass approach, the new menu at Cause & Effect Bar, Cape Town, has used cocktails to highlight four of the bar’s main producers. The Morgenhof utilises the bar’s red wine cordial sourced from the Stellenbosch wine estate of the same name, which has prioritised the maintenance of its environment.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a rocks glass with ice
directions.garnish: Expressed Orange rind & Grated Tonka Bean (served in a light-up peacock)

description: Created by Jean-Paul Bourguignon at Mietta’s Restaurant in Melbourne, the Japanese Slipper is an ’80’s drink that has been having a bit of a resurgence. With Midori, Cointreau and Lemon Juice, this is a sweet and sour drink with some serious tang.

directions.instructions:
Add Midori, Cointreau, & Lemon Juice to an ice-filled shaker tin. Shake and fine strain into a Martini glass.
Blend to combine, and strain into a Martini glass.

description: A riff on the classic Rusty Nail, the Rusty Ringo, created at Bar Goto in New York, uses Calvados as a base but dials back the Scotch and finishes with a nice touch of Drambuie.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir for 60 rotations. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

description: Designed to be the perfect cocktail for all the antiheroes (nautical or otherwise), Poor Unfortunate Souls is a wicked mix of Kraken Gold Spiced Rum, Blue Curaçao, Raspberry Syrup and Lemon Soda.

directions.instructions: Build Gold Spiced Rum, Blue Curaçao and Raspberry Syrup in a chilled glass and then top with Lemon Soda

description: A little like spiked Orange Juice, the Mandarin Mint Julep could easily be thought of as a ‘Breakfast Julep’. The combination of Mint, Mandarin Juice and Bourbon are awesome together and will easily ease you into a little day-drinking, Julep-style.

directions.instructions: In a mixing glass add bourbon, mint, mandarin orange juice, and mandarin orange segments. Muddle mixture and add crushed ice to serving glass. Strain mixture into serving glass

description: Boozy and complex, Home On The Range first appeared in the 1941 book Crosby Gaige’s Cocktail Guide & Ladies’ Companion. With Rye, Dubonnet, Cointreau & Angostura, this drink has the delicate combination of fruit, spice and bitterness.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: This cocktail was a favourite of the late Sasha Petraske (although he used Bourbon instead of Rye and Sweet Vermouth. instead of Dubonnet.

description: In the same way that a made man is traditionally seen as “untouchable” by fellow criminals, in the world of cocktails a Made Man offers a taste you can’t refuse. A great little bittersweet digestif, the Fernet Branca adds a smoky note to the Rye, Yellow Chartreuse and Cherry Brandy combo.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: While being a little boozy, the Gennaro Sidecar manages to create a perfect balance between sweet and sour that is sometimes lacking from the original. With Cognac, Cointreau, Limoncello & freshly squeezed Lemon Juice, this riff is the perfect cocktail package.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.

description: The Almost Rye is a relaxing drink made from Bourbon Whiskey, Pimento Dram and Orange Zest. Interestingly, the flavor combination of Bourbon and Pimento Dram results in a drink that has a taste very similar to a good straight Rye Whiskey, but with an added bonus of Orange.

directions.instructions: Fill a Rocks Glass with ice. Add Bourbon & Pimento Dram and stir carefully.

description: If you’re looking for a Rhubarb-flavoured riff on a Negroni, then the Rhubarb Lucca Negroni is definitely the one to make. Created back in 2001 by Jonathan Abarbanel at Quo Vadis in London this drink brings a nice tartness to the classic.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into an ice-filled glass and stir

description: If you think the Old Fashioned is a little too old fashioned or could just do with a coffee infusion, then a Cold Fashion with Rye Whiskey and Coffee Liqueur is the cocktail you should be making tonight.

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in an ice-filled glass, then stir

description: The Nippon Cocktail is a tasty little drink that is perfect for the weekend. A delicate balance of Whisky, Sweet Vermouth and a touch of Ginger Liqueur spice will make this drink, by Guiseppe Gallo, a favourite.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice and strained into a chilled glass

description: Best described as a fruity riff on a Rusty Nail, when you get a Black Eye, we suggest that you drink it rather than wear it. Created in 2008 by Simon Lamont at Jardine in Cape Town, this drink mixes Blackberries, Raspberries, Mint Leaves, Irish Whiskey, Drambuie and Crème de Cassis.

directions.instructions: Muddle Blackberries, Raspberries & Mint in the base of a shaker. Add other ingredients and shake with ice, before fine straining into an ice-filled glass.

description: The Bermuda Highball is a little unusual as it combines two spirits that you might not have thought work together – Cognac and Gin. But once you have added the Bianco Vermouth, Orange Bitters and Soda Water to the mix, then you can be sure that this is a refreshingly different twist of the classic highball.

directions.instructions: Pour Cognac, Gin, and Dry Vermouth into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with Ginger Ale

description: Swap out the Gin in a Negroni for Rye Whiskey and you get the delicious Boulevardier. With Rye, Sweet Vermnpouth & Campari, the drink is more complex as its Gin-based predecessor, but the Whiskey adds warmth, making it perfect for autumn and winter drinking.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients into a rocks glass over ice and stir. (Or add all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, stir and pour into a coupe.).
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Harry McElhone at Harry’s New York Bar in Paris and the drink appears in his 1927 book, Barflies and Cocktails.

description: As the name suggests, the Night Cap is perfect for late-night sipping. With Cognac, Gin, Crème de Cacao & Lime Juice, this drink was created at Sloppy Joe’s bar in Havana

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: This adapted recipe was published in Beachbum Berry’s Potions Of The Caribbean

description: Sometimes, in a bar, a customer can be the inspiration for a drink as is the case with the Desire Lamp. This drink was designed to satisfy the desire of a customer who wanted the perfect, refreshing combination of floral flavours with Vodka and Elderflower Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into an ice-filled highnall glass.
directions.garnish: Lemon Verbena sprig or a twist of Lemon
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created by Miguel Giao for the Columbus Cocktail & Wine Bar in Faro, Portugal.

description: Perfect for Cinco de Mayo or really any time when a bit of spice can add that edge to your night, the Mexican Chile Margarita has the Tequila and Lime you love, with the addition of Mexican Chile Syrup and Soda Water.

directions.instructions: Combine Lime Juice, Tequila, and Mexican Chile Syrup in an ice-filled glass. Top with soda water and enjoy.

description: If you’re looking to make a Last Word, but you’re out of Maraschino Liqueur, then this handy riff is a perfect choice. A little sweeter than the original, the Green Eyes No.2  was created by Andrew Volk at Portland Hunt & Alpine in Portland.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain back into shaker and then dry shake before fine straining into an ice-filled glass

description: For a fantastic Mule riff, you really can’t go past the fresh combination of flavours presented by the Garden Mule. Fresh Blueberries, Cucumber and Mint are the highlights of this refreshing cocktail with Vodka, Lime & Ginger Beer providing the base.

directions.instructions: Muddle Cucumber, Blueberries and Mint leaves in a shaker. Add ice, Vodka & Lime Juice and shake. Fine strain into an ice-filled Highball glass and top with Ginger beer

description: The Black Russian is obviously named for the black depth in colour of the Coffee Liqueur and the fact that Vodka is Russian. It is believed to have been created in 1949 by Gustave Tops at the Hotel Metropole in Brussels.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain to a chilled rocks glass with ice.
directions.more_about_this_drink: The drink was made as a tribute to Peale Mesta, the United States ambassador to Luxembourg at the time.

description: For a warm and refreshing cocktail, you can’t go past a Prague Cooler. This drink mixes Becherovka with Rum, a Honey-Ginger Syrup (infused with Cardamom and Cinnamon), two kinds of Bitters, a splash of Lime Juice, and topped with Soda Water.

directions.instructions: Combine Becherovka, Rum, Lime Juice, Syrup, and Bitters in a cocktail shaker filled with ice; shake vigorously and strain into a Rocks glass filled with ice and top with Soda Water
directions.garnish: (To make the Syrup – Combine honey and ½ cup water in a 1-qt. saucepan over high heat; boil, then remove from heat. Add 2 Cardamom Pods, a stick of Cinnamon, some Lemon peel and a thinly sliced piece of Ginger and let sit for 30 minutes. Strain, and chill until ready to use.)

description: Whisky and Vermouth is a classic combination at the best of times but becomes truly delightful through the coffee twist found in Highland. Cape Town’s latest speakeasy, The Queen’s has mixed Dalmore 12 Scotch Whisky with coffee-infused Antica and topped it with an expresso and Branca Menta foam.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice, then strain into a Nick & Nora Glass
directions.garnish: Espresso & Branca Menta foam + star anise

description: If you are after a wonderful balance of flavours then a Lotus Blossom Martini should be the next cocktail you make. With Pear Vodka, Sake, Simple Syrup, Lychees and a Lime wedge, this is one drink that is both complex and delicate.

directions.instructions: Muddle Lychees, Lime wedge & Sugar Syrup before adding ice, Sake & Vodka and shake well. Fine strain into a chilled Martini glass.

description: The trick with any Blackberry cocktail is to ensure that you get the balance of tart and sweet just right and on that point, the Blimey does not disappoint. With its Blackberries, Lime and Creme de Cassis this is a drink that will have you singing its praises.

directions.instructions: Muddle Blackberries in a shaker base, add all other ingredients and shake with ice. Fine strain into a glass of crushed ice.
directions.more_about_this_cocktail: Created in 2002 by Simon Gifford in London

description: Just as easy and delicious as the original, this vibrant green riff will become a favourite. Replacing Cointreau with Melon Liqueur, the Midori Margarita otherwise pairs Midori with the Tequila and Lime Juice of the original.

directions.instructions: Pour all ingredients into a shaker tin filled with ice. Shake and then fine strain into a Martini glass rimmed with salt.

description: If your keen on having a nice G&T at the end of the day, it’s a fair bet you won’t be opposed to a Lillet Rose Tonic as well. Simply replace the Gin with Lillet Rose, add Tonic as usual and garnish with a nice Lime wheel – it’s trés simple and trés delicious.

directions.instructions: Pour Lillet Rosé into a glass full of ice , then top with Tonic Water

description: Created around the mid-1880s, in honour of the Broadway musical of the same name, the Adonis is one of America’s true classic cocktails. Although this recipes uses the Sweet vermouth and orange Bitters from the original, it replaces the Fino Sherry with Oloroso Sherry and adds a little Sugar Syrup.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and then strain into a chilled glass

description: If you are after a Daiquiri with a more tropical edge, then you can’t go past the Prestige. With Aged Rum, Pineapple Juice, Dry Vermouth, Falernum and Lime Juice, this drink was created by Dale Degroff in New York in 2002.

directions.instructions: Shale all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass

description: With a nice Ginger kick, the Diamond Elixir is definitely the jewel of Vodka Cocktails.  With a wonderful mix of Ginger Liqueur, Lillet Blanc, Pineapple Juice & of course Vodka, this little drink is sure to become a favourite.

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients over ice in a mixing glass and shake until well chilled. Serve in a chilled cocktail glass.

description: If you thought that Falernum Cocktails would not include Scotch then an Ode To Viceroy will prove you wrong. A slightly peaty Scotch is ideal for this cocktail that mixes it with the zing of Ginger Syrup and the spice of Falernum, all balanced out by fresh Lime Juice,

directions.instructions: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice. Shake to chill, then strain into a rocks glass and garnish.

description: While Momisette may be French for “tiny mummy,” this drink is anything but tiny in flavour. A combination of Pastis, Orgeat, and Sparkling Water, it is a refreshing drink with a silky smooth flavour and texture.

directions.instructions: Add Pastis and Orgeat to an ice-filled Collins glass, then top with Soda Water

description: If you thought a tasty Sidecar riff had to use Cognac, then why not try the Tahona Sidecar. With Reposado Tequila instead of Cognac & Dry Curacao instead of Cointreau, the only thing that’s consistent is the Lemon Juice, part of the name and a taste that will have you making a second …

directions.instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass and shake vigorously with ice to chill. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass that is rimmed with superfine sugar.

description: There’s nothing more tempting than nostalgia and chocolate, and the Salty Smoked S’mores Boulevardier has both. With Bourbon, Campari, Sweet Vermouth and a little Crème de Cacao (and, of course, marshmallow for a garnish), this is a drink that will remind you of summer holidays

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice. Light a marshmallow on fire, and cover it with the rocks glass to extinguish and capture smoke. Strain cocktail into glass
directions.garnish: Rim the side of the glass with melted chocolate and (before it hardens) roll the glass in powdered graham cracker. Garnish with speared smoked marshmallows.

description: If you’re looking for an aperitivo that will quench a thirst, then the Fumata Bianca is dry, lightly bitter and smoky enough to do the job. Created by Timothy Miner in New York in 2016, this drink has Suze, Dry Vermouth, Mezcal and Soda Water

directions.instructions: Stir first three ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass and strain into an ice-filled highball glass. Top with Soda Water

description: The Lion’s Tail is a rich, spicy, classic cocktail from back in the 1930s. A bit of an oddity, this cocktail is most definitely Bourbon based but otherwise has all the trappings of a Tiki drink with Lime Juice & Pimento Dram.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into chilled glass.
directions.more_about_this_drink: Adapted from a recipe that first appeared in Café Royal Cocktail Book. As it has Bourbon, it is assumed that it refers to ‘twisting the lion’s tail’ which was American slang at the time for provoking the British.

description: A nice fruity twist on the traditional Caipirinha, a Raspberry Caipirinha. With Raspberries, Mint, Cachaça, Raspberry Syrup, Lime Juice and Soda Water this is the ideal drink for those wonderful Indian Summer days on the patio.

directions.instructions: Muddle Raspberries and Mint with Raspberry Syrup. Add ice, Lime Juice & Cachaça. Stir and top with Soda Water

description: The Charlie Chaplin is a bit of a forgotten classic cocktail, which was invented in New York’s Waldorf Astoria Hotel in 1920. With an equal mix of Apricot Brandy, Sloe Gin and Lime Juice can be rather thick and sweet, so be sure to give it a hearty shake.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled shaker and hard shake. Stir into a chilled cocktail glass.

description: Mixing the wonderful combination of Amaro and Sherry, the Cobble Stone Highball is a simple, long drink, further cooled by the inclusion of muddled cucumber and a topping of sparkling wine.

directions.instructions: Muddle cucumber slices in a shaker. Add the remaining ingredients (except Sparkling Wine) then shake with ice. Strain into a glass and top with Sparkling Wine.

description: Who doesn’t love a long drink that combines the bitter brightness of Campari with the herbaceous nature of Gin? Now mix in the richness of Orgeat and the sour of Lemon Juice and you have The Chestnut Cup, created by The Chestnut Club in Santa Monica.

directions.instructions: Combine all the ingredients in a shaker and add a single ice cube. Shake to combine, then strain into a glass filled three-quarters with ice cubes. Top with crushed ice

description: Light, easy and undeniably drinkable, the Bourbon Sunrise is the perfect brunch with-friends cocktail as it mixes Bourbon with the juices of Orange, Mango and Lemon, with Honey Syrup and Angostura Bitters.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a chilled Rocks glass

description: We’re not sure whether this Negroni variation will make you feel like you are staying in a lodge but finding out will certainly be a flavoursome experience. The Campari and Sweet Vermouth are the same, but the Gin is replaced with a little Scotch and Coffee Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Stir all the ingredients with ice to chill. Strain over a large ice cube in a rocks glass.

description:
“Classic perfume-making—including traditional botanicals and aroma combinations—inspired Wilderton co-founder and distiller Seth O’Malley’s formulation of Earthen and Lustre; which perform like the acclaimed singer in this ethereal Manhattan.” – Jim Meehan
Image – AJ Meeker

directions.instructions: Measure into a chilled mixing glass, then add ice cubes. Stir and strain into a chilled coupe.

description: A little trivia to start this recipe – did you know, it takes 75,000 saffron flowers to make one pound of saffron spice. So when NY restaurant Junoon created their Saffron Sunrise, they were creating something very special with the Ten To One White rum, by adding Orange Juice, Fernet Branca, Cap Corse Quinquina, Lime Juice & Apologue Saffron Liqueur.

directions.instructions: Shake ingredients together with ice. Strain into an old-fashioned glass with one big ice cube
directions.garnish: Grapefruit slice & a pinch of saffron.

description: Created by Alex Blair at OK Omens in Portland, Oregon, Lovage: A Battlefield is a highball riff that blends the soft floral botanicals of Cocchi Americano and the bittersweet flavor of Suze for a long, refreshing cocktail with depth.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to an ice-filled glass and stir

description: If you want a bit more oomph to your Old Fashioned, then how about adding a bit of coffee. For this Cold Brew Coffee is the trick, added to Bourbon, Simple Syrup, Orange Bitters, Angostura Bitters & a good dash of Chocolate Bitters.

directions.instructions: Build all ingredients in mixing glass. Stir with ice until chilled. Strain into Old Fashioned glass
directions.more_about_this_drink: Created by Bryan Hutchinson at Black Hole Coffee House in Houston

description: A lovely and light, the Four Aces is a herbal, fruity, well-balanced drink. Created by Damian Winsor at the Roger Room in LA, it mixes Vodka, Lime Juice, Ginger Liqueur, Sugar Syrup, Basil Leaves and seedless White Grapes.

directions.instructions: Muddle grapes in the base of a shaker, then add all other ingredients and shake. Fine strain into an ice-filled glass and top with Soda Water

description:
While it’s true that you can’t go wrong with a Gin Fizz, the addition of savoury flavours makes it all the more right. With Gin, Boardroom Spirit’s Carrot “C” speciality spirit, rosemary simple syrup and lemon juice, this variation on the classic is the perfect Easter weekend sundowner
Recipe and image provided by Boardroom Spirits

directions.instructions: Combine vodka, Boardroom Carrot “C” speciality spirit and lemon juice in a cocktail shaker. Mix and pour into a highball glass with ice. Top with club soda, a squirt of rosemary simple syrup and stir. Garnish with lime slice and serve

description: The Athletes’ Village is a riff on the East Village Athletics Club which is, in turn, a riff on The Last Word. It swaps out Blanco Tequila for Reposado Tequila and Grand Marnier for St Germain, while keeping the Lemon Juice and the Yellow Chartreuse.

directions.instructions: Shake all ingredients in an ice-filled shaker, then strain into a cocktail glass

description: Citrusy and bubbly, the Boat House Punch is the perfect batch cocktail, as it has enough fruity, floral and bittersweet notes to be flavoursome but not clawing. Created by Julie Reiner, it starts with a really simple Lemon Oleo Saccharum before mixing in Gin, Aperol, St-Germain and a range of fresh juices.

directions.instructions: Muddle the lemon peels (save lemons for juicing) with the sugar in a bowl until the sugar looks slightly moistened. Cover and let sit for at least one hour, or overnight, so the sugar can absorb the lemon oils. Add the Gin, Aperol, St-Germain, Grapefruit Juice, Lemon Juice and Orange Juice to a large pitcher or punch bowl. Add the lemon-sugar mixture, and let sit for 15 minutes. Remove the lemon peels, drop in a large ice block, and add the Sparkling Rosé.

description: If you are after an easy, but still quite boozy glass of cocktail bliss, then you really can’t go past a Champagne Smash. With Gin, Lillet Rose, Mint, Lemon slice & Champagne, this is a drink is the ideal bubbly perfection for any occasion.

directions.instructions: In a shaker, muddle a nice slice of lemon and a couple of sprigs of mint. Add ice, gin and Lillet Rosé. Shake for 15 seconds or so to get it good and cold. Strain into a highball glass with ice, then top with champagne.

description: Created by Alfie Spears at Bon Voyage! in San Francisco, A Friend Always could best be described as a “tropical disco-tini” with Gin, kiwi-infused vermouth and spiced falernum, while a dash of orange flower water accents the gin’s botanicals.

directions.instructions: Stir all ingredients in an ice-filled mixing glass, then strain

description: The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Cocktail was originally developed by Trader Vic, as his Tiki version of the Daiquiri. It can be made with either White Rum or Gold, but whichever you choose, make sure you bring onboard Cointreau, Falernum and Lime Juice.

directions.instructions: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and fine strain into a chilled Coupe glass
